reviewText:
Early Access Review

5/15/15 - Just wanted to mention that my hours played is low because my computer melted, but I'm still excitedly following the development of this game!

Intro & Opening Points
To start, I want to alleviate concerns about this title as far as early-access hesitancy and the idea that the game won't get finished. I've been following this game for a couple years, and the devs  constantly update the public on the state of the game with monthly newsletters. Additionally, the game has been funded by two successful kickstarters, and was originally going to be funded out-of-wallet by the devs before it became a crowdfunding success. This is a project of love for them and I don't see them failing to follow through on the title due to financial or personal reasons.

In its current alpha state you should be aware that the game is not finished, but it is feature-complete enough to play and that access to an alpha makes you a tester as much as a player. You cannot expect a bug or crash free experience, and you will be asked for your input throughout the game on how well features or quests are implemented. However, what you are paying for is more than just early access to the game for testing purposes. The Repopulation will be releasing as a free to play game. By purchasing the game on early access, you are recieving the benefits of a Gold Member package once the game releases.

I want to reiterate that The Repopulation has been planned and designed as a free to play game from its inception. This means eventually there will be a cash shop, but the devs have said over and over that it will be for cosmetic and Quality of Life items, and nothing so broken that it will make the game feel Pay2Win. Member packages, which I mentioned before, will be one-time payments that give you perks like extra bank space and cosmetic pre-order" items.

Now that I've got all of that out of the way
date:
I'll move on to the game itself.

How It Plays
I've decided to add a section to the review here that gives an idea of the basics of how the game plays

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is hard.

I'm going to start there. The learning curve is so steep it might as well be a brick wall. Three days in the game and I'm barely comfortable leaving the main city to poke trash mobs, and Ive barely started nibbling on crafting.

This game is also incredibly complex, beautiful, and clearly much loved by its developers.

Dont look here for WoW. Dont look here for SWTOR. This is truly an Old School" game from the days of Star Wars Galaxies or the very first Everquest. This is a game for the MUD nerds and the Tabletop masters with skads of reference material on-hand from the days of grid maps and notebooks.

There is very little hand holding
date: there are no classes. Dont complain about haivng to craft a hundred different sub-components to get your speeder bike. Because that's what this game is about! It's about complexity and spending hours to master some tiny aspect of the game that makes you an invaluable cog in the greater machine. I love this game. I love it /because/ it is overwhelming. It gives me so much content dropped into my lap like a knotted fishing reel that I'll spend forever pulling apart the strands until I understand the mechanism.\n\nThat's what this game is about
recommended: and it does it very well for being so very early access.\n\nNow
hoursPlayed: dont get me wrong. It /is/ still early access. There are glitches
voteText: texture collisions
helpfulPercent: quest-killing bugs
votesHelpful: and the framerates grind a bit. But for all its warts
votesTotal: I can see the diamond underneath
votesFunny: and I cant wait to see where they take it.\n\nIn conclusion : Buy the game with the understanding that this is a HARD game
commentsCount: and it is an EARLY game. But it smacks of nostalgia
column16: and it's a wonderfully refreshing challenge in a world where MMOs are designed to cater to the whiny masses and dragons practically slay themselves."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*edit : They have updated quite alot so this review might not be relavent anymore. Will update once this game get more polished*

I've never played SWG or UO before, so I was kindda curious what the game like, as I was looking for games that put more emphasis on crafting system and economy like Wurm Online and Haven and Hearth does, and I've been dissapointed time and time again with the current ecosystem of MMORPG. All the other MMO that I've played put crafting and economy as a side mini game of grinding that the only main objective is to drain your gold coffers (so you would microtranscation more gold from them). I wanted to find a game that making something is meaningful, not grinding harvesting and crafting by making worthless items just so you can make the end-game items, and any items you made before that is pointless and garbage after you level up a few times. And this game is EFFING it!!

This game will be a complicated game to review, since it does have a huge pros, and also a few deblilating cons.

Pros :- Crafting is meaningful. Each of the item you crafted is useful. Each items made is used in alot other recipes. You can make almost every single item in the game. And you can actually do, without too much of a grinding like in other MMO, you can make alot of things using the lowest quality items and its not a hassle to do it at all. But to make a really high quality items, you need to depend on other and this is where the grind is. How cool is it to be a master crafter of making single core processor motherboard :3
And I must say, when you make something, the satisfaction is astounding. <3

- Fitting system. Fitting system is great since you're not tied to a armor or weapon, and you don't need to change your armor/weapon/accessory every 5 levels. If you found a set that you love you can just stick with it and customize your armor to be what you want. Slashing defense maxed out armor? Full armor penetration defense armor? Hell yeah.

- I haven't experience the player housing, town and shops, but any game with that is a huge plus.

- Living world. Day and Night cycle. NPC have their own schedule like what Ultima 7 had. Alot of MMO keep yapping on and on about how their game is alive and how the city is bustling, yet when you're the only one in the area, its feels like you are in a town fulls of puppet, every NPC just stand there doing nothing. This game means it and NPC will close shop at night, Guard stop patrolling the town outskirts at night, Guard will change their guard post every day. Shopkeeper will go to the disco at night.

- Quest is randomly generated based on a template. Each area have their own quest type and story. Not one player will have the same quest like the other one (kindda). While the quest is not that great and buggy, but its a huge step on the right direction. Each quest is different (somewhat) unlike the old system where the same NPC keep forcing everyone to collect the same bloody 10 animal hide over and over again. This game is on the right path, imperfect but on the right path. While you have to send the cupcake to the guard, your friend might be sending some rose to a girl. <3 and another guy is sending a cupcake to the guy in the pub.

- Away from the stupid classic leveling system. Mega plus. The more you do on certain area the more it will progress, and you will get skill point bonuses also. This is what all MMO should aspire to be.

- Huge world and multiple passanger vehicle and mech!!!

- Dance routine (that give buff to everyone depending on the type of dance and the dance step) and story telling (that also give buff to everyone depending on the type of story, plot-twist and ending, oh and anyone can jump in can contiue to story tell the story started by another.). Make a camp in the wild, and start playing the guitar, dance and storytell, and then go lay teh smackdown on the bandit camp nearby.

Cons :- Early Access : God the game is buggy as hell. I know its early access, and people need to be reminded that the game is buggy and it does takes off the enjoyment sometimes (ok maybe more then sometimes). Wait till the game enter a more stable stage if this is your main concerns.

- Combat is very unpolish, laggy and not particularly fun. Well I've seen worst (aka Fallen Earth) but I hope they can polish it more down the road.

- UI is nasty. just plain nasty and unfriendly. The ingame Map is probably the worst I've seen in any game, hard to read just filled with freaking orange colored dot that can mean anything, even worst when compared to Fallen Earth in-game map (and Fallen Earth UI is first on my Top 10 list of most nasty UI in an MMO). UI is unresponsive, the map (M and Shift-M) is impossible to use. Mini-map should just be deleted for how useless it is.
Crafting UI is bearable, Quest UI is pretty bad. And omg, the talking to NPC UI and speech bubble is horrible nasty piece of buggy crap.
Please dev, fix this at the utmost priority. UI is the most important gateway for user experience in MMO. User spend more time using the UI then combat, then gameplay and all the other thing combined.

- Character Creation is pretty bad too and buggy on top of that :( which is really making me sad.

- Player economy is yet to sprout because of the lack of player. Hopefully this will change once the game goes Free2Play.

Neutral points:- Graphics is way behind, but if you want to play an MMO with beautiful gals with perfect bewbies and booties physics, then the Korean Dev is working hard to make those. I prefer the dev to spend their time making the game mechanics more unique and fun rather then asking them to spend most of thier time making the bewbies bounce prefectly and copy-paste the old, tired and grindy MMO recipe to offset the time wasted. Rather you should just google Porn" watch it then come play this game.
Back to the point I wanted to make
recommended: but it is playable. While I would love this game to have the graphic of TERA and gameplay of Repop (wet dreams) I know thats not possible
hoursPlayed: and I would choose gameplay with a playable graphics any time of the day.\n\n- Very steep learning curve (like 90 degrees steep
voteText: also known as a brick wall)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The repopulation is a burgeoning yet interesting addition to the long list of MMORPGs out there, and you may be wondering why you should buy this one as opposed to any others. Well that's what I am going to explain to you today. The repopulation is currently in alpha stage, soon to be entering closed beta I believe. By buying this game either on steam or from their website you are paying for a game which will, at launch, be F2P, however you aren't just paying for early access you are also paying for a number of benefits outlined here (Repopulation website[www.therepopulation.com]) which includes things such as head start, name reservation the gold and silver memberships (which give you increased bank,character, auction, shared bank and mission slots) and repop tokens. The repopulation steam purchase is the equivalent of buying their $39.99 pledge and works out cheaper than the steam version, on a side note if you buy it from their site then you get receive a steam key as well. Now onto the pros and cons

Pros
-Diverse and free skill tree system (there are no classes so you can specialise how you want to e.g. a flame-thrower wielding diplomat, ironic I know)
-In-depth character customization system (plenty of sliders and the like or a basic system as well)
-Brilliant Crafting System (the system works out so that your character(s) should only specialise in a couple of crafting skils, however if you wanted to be a crafting master and max every gathering and crafting skill you can, this would take a VERY long time)
-Unique quest system (there are different types of quests such as quests tailored to your character, generic quests, quests which can only be completed for a short time, open-world quests involving lots of players, a la defiance)
-Lots more interesting content to come

Cons
-The graphics (when set to maximum are not groundbreaking however they certainly aren't bad or substandard)
-Glitches/Bugs (Although I have experienced next to none many people say they experience lags or crashes)
-Combat (much like the graphics the combat is neither ground breaking nor bad and with some improval, including better attack animations, they will be good)
-Lack of in-depth tutorial (although there is a starting area which does its' best to teach you the basics of the game such as the skill system, combat, crafting etc. it still leaves plenty up to the player to learn. However the community, at least on the EU server, is very friendly and more than willing to help you out)
-Lack of direction (This is, in my opinion, one of the hardest things to get to grip with as after completing the tutorial you have a massive open world ahead of you and very little guidance as to what to do, but in some ways that is the appeal of it as you can, from the outset, go out buy some recipes and/or equipment to start your crafting career,go  kill some mobs, complete some quests, just explore the land, try your hand at some PvP (although that'd be ill-advised), join a guild etc. As part of this is the difficulty of finding NPCs; you have to inquire with other NPCs, use your tracking skill and sometimes just bide your time).

Conclusion
Overall the repopulation is a very immersive and enjoyable game, with a great deal of potential, but whether you buy it now or wait till beta or even launch is really based upon a number of factors; can you deal with a character wipe before launch, do you want these extras such as a headstart, more slots etc, can you deal with an unfinished and sometimes glitchy game and finally can you cope with a game that does not give as much of a helping hand as other MMORPGs. I hope my review helps you to make your mind up and most importantly have fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Initially It was fun and frustrating at the same time...then for a few days it seemed to grind on and on and I didn't see much developing with my charicter...(Because like many I didn't read any of the guides and tried to jump in without a clue.) After I read one of the guides...well...It honestly changed the whole game for me and am now making some really decent headway in charicter developement. It is a little rough on load times and still crashes once or twice every couple of hours, but hey...Its Alpha. It was advertised as such so it has to be expected. Honestly though it preforms better than many games I've tried that were full releases. There is ALOT to do, learn and try in this game. It can be a casual game but it's hard to put it down sometimes even when i'm getting stomped. The crafting system is pretty advanced and it has a new skill system similar to that of EVE online. (Skill books.) plus if you buy the weapon skills you get a free gun, grenade or Sword, ax etc. apropriate to the skill learned. (I.e. you leard automatic weapons you get an assault rifle.) One of my two favorite weapons in game so far are the sniper rifle and flame thrower. (You can also add fittings to the weapons and armor to boost certin atributes.) ....and they have pets! Who doesn't want virtual pets...and no virtual Poo to clean up. They have a limited amount of vehicles that I suggest buying for other players rather than NPCs as the quality, availability, and prices are much better...I bought a light mech...It has a gun...I shoot stuff.
It's a keeper.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I never had the pleasure of playing Ultima Online.  But I was fortunate enough to play SWG (both pre and post Combat Update and NGE).  Much of The Repopulation is very reminicant of my days as a TKM (Teras Kasi Master) trying to get to blue glowy (Jedi), with some notable exceptions.  Therefore, the comparrison that the company makes is a very fair one as far as SWG is concerned.

The game is highly skill based.  There are your main skills (of which there's around 75) and then there are skills within the skills.  I will use the character I have played with the most (I've tinkered with three) to try to illustrate the point.

My main character is primarily a hunter type with some gathering side abilities.  There are several but the ones he specializes in are, mining (minerals and ore extraction from nodes), wood cutting (cutting down trees), and survival (skinning animals and scavenging for water).  There's others but those are the ones I use.  For every mob type there is a set skill pertaining to them.  A common early mob is a Setlang, they are reptilian dog-like creatures.  As you hunt/skin more and more of these creatures you begin to become more and more familiar with them.  So there's your overall skill (say survival) and specific species skill (in this case setlang) the higher they both are the better you do, obviously.  This holds true across the board.   Are you a miner?  What kind of miner are you?  There's a skill for each ore too.  Woods man?  What trees/plants are you good with?

On the flipside.  Lets say you go into crafting.  The same thing applies you have your base crafting schools, lets say chemistry, and then you have all of your chemistry recipes.  They have separate skills associated with each one of them (i'm quite the badass water distiller but i can't do acid extraction for crap).

Harvesting is interesting in that you have several options.  There's auto harvesting (you can put down extractors over some nodes) and there's manual extraction.  Many nodes under manual extraction come with 2 other options enhancement of the node you're on, and enrichment of the area.  As an area is harvested it looses quality and it shows in the nodes.  The immediate and personal fix is by enhancing the node you're working on but it only works for you.  Enriching the area restores the area's quality not just for you but everyone.

The game is in alpha so please expect crashes, bugs and issues. They aren't abundant but they exist, most can be fixed with a soft log.

Pros
Massive skill system
Great in game community
Very ambitious
Rewarding if you're willing to work for it (those who seek immediate gratification go elsewhere)
Decent early teaching methods (nooby training instance)

Cons
Steep price tag for alpha *redacted con, see edit*
Alpha lots of bugs, they're being worked on but it's alpha
Future possibility of microtransactions
Steep learning curve, with many skills hidden" for you to discover on your own
date: and little direction given beyond the original training instance\n\nAll in all
recommended: if they add a twitch based flight aspect I will be at their door screaming "Shut up and take my money".  As it sits
hoursPlayed: for me
voteText: it is worth the early investment.  These guys are clearly serious and want the game to work.  That being said I enjoy alphas and betas
helpfulPercent: and realize many don't.  So if you're one who wants a clean and polished game don't buy in yet.  The game is clean and has some polish
votesHelpful: but isn't finished yet.  They are making progress (think an update comes out today or tomorrow actually) but they've still got work to do.  The price tag of 40 bucks for an alpha is a bit steep in my opinion but being that it harkens back to my days in SWG as much as it did I took the plunge
votesTotal: and am glad I did.\n\nThere's many things that you can do in game that I've not mentioned this is strictly the path of one of my characters
votesFunny:
the character is truly yours when you get in.

Enjoy

-Rk

Edit: Thanks to WubZero for bringing this to my attention.  There's been a price reduction removing that con.  Game is now 20 bucks as opposed to 40 now makes it a very viable competetor in the current market.

They do plan on having twitch based flight once they've smoothed out the majority of the ground game.  So we are at "Shut up and take my money" status."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Did you enjoy playing Galaxies between launch and the CU? Do you like complex crafting systems (the good kind)? Do you like the freedom to level 1 or 2 things or Everything if you want on one character?

The Repopulation might be for you, then.

Use any weapon, or heal.
Tame wild animals, or make your own to fight with and / or for you.
Completely customize the way your character looks on creation, and afterward in-game if you didn't pick the right things. Think about the Saints Row Series - make a normal-looking or goofy character if you want.
Entertain and buff yourself and other characters in rest zones like pubs in and outside. Not near a town? You can pop open a tent and do the same with your group.

Not interested in being a good guy? Stealth your way around and pick pocket / steal from people and shops. Become an assassin with rogue-like abilities - backstab with one or two knives for massive damage. (From my experience, starting out along this path is a little tricky in the current state 7/29/15). There are several skill lines that are beneficial - Stealth, Assassination, Bladed Weapons, Thievery, etc.

Want to build your own robots, vehicles, and other advanced items? You may want to consider joining a nation (guild). Crafting is complex for most advanced items and you may want friendly teams of people gathering to accelerate the process.


The game is early access, which means many things haven't been refined to perfection, and there are still some features on the To Do / To Add" list. In its current state
date: I can still recommend this game to all those interested in it. Be warned; there is a guaranteed wipe slated for the launch of the game. There are only rumours of other wipes between now and then
recommended:
but no official word on any.

There are GMs that occasionally do testing with players ingame to hunt down bugs and troubleshoot various things. Watch General chat for opportunities like these.

On live streams (Twitch) you'll be able to get info on new features

This being another early access game and I a fan of Star Wars galaxies pre-NGE; I will try to keep this review as unbiased as possible. I have not seen a lot of the game yet, and I have spent most of the time I currently have logged trying to fully understand all of the basic mechanics the final product will revolve around. So this is mainly a performance and theory review. Since most of this game is subject to change over time.

There is currently a lot of performance issues for people near or meeting recommended system reqs. The game is playable with my system specs, and in most places I can get 40-60 fps with everything set to low. Granted the options aren't fully developed yet so there is only so much tweaking you can do to enhance game performance. The Hero Engine works in cells. So when you enter a new cell in the world map it can cause a huge drop in frame rates. Another major issue to be noted when considering purchasing this early access is the large memory leak the game has. Generally memory leaks lead to constant game crashes, but this personally isn't the case. The main problems from my experience with the memory leaks is that The Repopulation has a rapid declination of performance over an extended period of play time. Now I am not saying that this won't cause constant crashes for others, and I have ran into a few crashes myself.(The crashes I've had were mainly from tabbing to my second monitor while at the loading screen.)

Now, for the people who want to focus on testing out the crafting system. There is a bug that will frequently cause your recipes to disappear requiring you to reboot the game application in order to continue crafting. Another bug that is somewhat annoying is your inventory and items disappearing.(which will effect people who want to craft, or people looking to test combat). The last two major bugs people should be aware of before purchasing is a game crash on respawn, and your hotbar being bugged on respawn and not showing ability cooldowns.

Performance summary = EA is not for everyone, and if you at least meet recommended system reqs the game will be playable". Keep in mind this is an early access alpha so expect everything to constantly be breaking

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game, when people relate it to SWG, they aren't kidding, it is very similar, all the way down to the HUD.

If you love opening up a game and having no idea what to do and where to go, and the challenge of figuring out the systems in the game and learning how they work and how to get better, this is a great throwback to pre-2004 MMOs.

If you are looking for crisp graphics, tight controls, questing hubs, and a main story with quests, this isn't your kind of MMO, but if you are looking for deep interweaving systems of combat and crafting and skills and armor and weapon, and the ability to make your own choices of how you will progress and what YOU want to do next, this is the perfect MMO for you.

It gets back to letting players make their own stories and define who they are, instead of being told from level 1 what their story is, and following the same path as every other person who has done it before.

The game is still very clunky, and very buggy, you will be confused, you will get lost, quests won't work, NPCs will bug out, they will shoot you through rocks, you will die to poor pathing and agro and bugs, but if you can deal with that, the challenge of figuring out and progressing your character the way you want to is well worth the time IMO.

I would say if you enjoyed SWG the first few years it was out, and you can get over the buggy / clunky feeling, then this game is definitely a must-play for you.

If you don't like the feeling of being lost and not knowing what to do and figuring it out and coming up with your own goals and objectives without being told what they are, and looking for a polished, smooth gameplay experience, then this won't be your kind of game.

After years of playing Star War Galaxies and experiencing the empty hole that could never be filled since its demise, I finally feel like I'm at home again. Open world sandbox, Sci-fi theme, player housing, robust crafting, foraging, mining, etc. All of these qualities are what I have been searching for in a game for YEARS. The Repopulation played at my heart strings. After 2 days of playing it, I can already tell I will be playing this game for many years. My friends and I extend a great thanks to The Repopulation team. You have filled that empty hole in our gaming experience and payed attention to Sci-fi/Sandbox players. We have been ignored for so long. Following the development of this game for 2 years was worth it.

10/10 even though the Alpha play is quite broken. This is expected.

Rest in peace Sunrunner server of Star Wars Galaxies.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

2/25/2015 - In the current iteration I feel the game is still in the core gameplay stage of testing.  If you don't know what that means, probably best to avoid the game until it progresses into a beta stage.  The developers always seem active and open to feedback.  GM staff is usually always available in game if you hit a snag with most issues.  /newbie chat is most times filled with helpful people (so long as you actually paid attention during the tutorial :P).

I would caution you to bring your engineering degree along if you plan on delving too deeply into crafting because it is quite literally rocket science.  Most crafts also have strong interdependencies relying on the other crafting fields, so it's not a recommended solo experience.  And why have we gotten the notion that MMOs should be solo experiences in all things?  You can eventually grand master every skill line on one character, but don't put the cart before the horse.  Soft cap is currently 6k per skill line (when you stop gaining abilities) with hard cap being 60k per skill line (with small gain improvement depending on the skill line after 6k).

This game is trying to recapture many of the sandbox aspects that have been ignored lately in MMOs.  One of the more important being the social aspects that I feel should exist in all MMOs.  You'll need people for far more in this game then hitting the queue button and waiting for a pve dungeon or pvp map with perfect strangers and then never see them again.  Personally I was excited to see sort of a re-imaging of the Entertainer from SWG providing buffs to people who stop into the pub/cantina (the /tip function is also in this game!).

I've also missed my Creature Handler and there's a few different pet style branches here as well.  Animal Handling - tame baby animals in the wild to fight for you/become mounts for you and maintain them with Vet Medicine (or let another vet maintain them for you), Robotics - build your own robot and outfit them with fittings to suit your needs, and Genetic Engineering - take tissue samples and dna samples from various creatures and make your own mad scientst one-shot consumable-on-use clone pets.

There are 75 total skill lines at the moment to discuss (as well as hidden skill lines), so I won't talk in depth about all those, but I encourage to check out the official site and wiki to learn more.

All in all, this game has a solid foundation to be a decent sandbox which the industry is severly lacking at the moment.  If that is a niche you miss or want to delve deeper into; consider backing.  If you'd like to play a more optimized game... continue to wait until this game moves into beta phase (still a few months out from time of posting).

Character Classes suck
Leveling sucks
Npc's suck
Creatures suck
Gathering sucks
Resource collection sucks
Player housing sucks
Player guilds suck
Crafting sucks
Complexity sucks
Learning curve sucks

Anyways, enough about Every MMO re-skin since 2005.

Repopulation, an absolute clean breath of fresh air.  Same list but for Repopulation.

Character Classes , there isn't any, be what you want, when you want, Awesome!

Leveling, There are no levels, its based off skill and experience (hard to explain without 20 paragraphs)

Npc's, they're Npc's, but at least they try talk to you, and dont just repeat the same dialog all the time.

Creatures, Yeah they suck, if taming them and using them as pet tanks sucks, or better yet mounting them...... :P

Gathering, Honestly in my opinion needs a little TLC but still good.

Resource collection, Automated collection via harvesters.... SWG anybody? not quite the same mechanic :(

Player housing, pretty good, still in early stages but you can see the potential.

Player guilds, SHUT UP, they're not guilds they're fecking cities if you want, yes you can join your friends on a huge area claimed as your own. not in an instance either, it's in the real game world....

Crafting sucks, I am afraid it does, if you don't have the patience to make 120+ sub components or get a group, making parts of a larger item. Because if complexity is your thing, it's briliant.

Complexity, if you are sick of that same old gay arsed run to Y kill bunny run back to Z. you are this class you must do this to progress to the next map BS, then this is the game for you, yes it lacks direction as some would say. they are the ones not familiar with what a sandbox is, there is no direction. That is just what a sandbox is.

Learning curve sucks, God Damn right it does, if your are only as smart as a laboratory chimp that is used to whiling away your time in <insert MMO from last decade here>.

BTW I DO NOT USE STEAM TO LAUNCH THE GAME, I HAVE PROBABLY PLAYED 40HRS PER WEEK SINCE I BOUGHT IT.

The Tale of some Bloke

Gather round children and let me tell you a tale of old, there once was a little boy who dreamt of playing Star Wars Galaxies but lacked the funds to pay monthly or at that point even a Computer to play it on. He wished and he wished for a Computer and the money to fund his dream. Time past and he grew older his dream still alight within him he learnt of Computers and their ways, ventured into the PC Gaming community and saught out adventure yet still he did not have the funds to complete his dream and it was put on hold yet again. Time past by till eventually Sony decided to close their Star Wars Galaxies servers forever, the boy was heart broken his dream crushed all hope destroyed, he would never venture to Tatooine and shoot Tusken Raiders, never explore caves on the icy planet of Hoth or slap Gungans because they are so damn annoying on Naboo...

His dream faded into the past only occasionaly reminded of it by Youtube Videos and the odd discussion among fellow gamers. He moved on taking up arms against others in different realms and worlds fighting for different causes a lone wanderer without a home. But then one day he stumbled upon The Repopulation. What is this?" he said aloud in surprise

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1st Impressions review.

I love it so far. You can tell where the team's inspiration came from. It reminds me of the early days of SWG and seems to have the best parts of that game, Anarchy Online, UO, Vanguard, and others.

Even in alpha the game is playable and easily worth the $20. I've been waiting for a game like this since they butchered SWG. I even went so far as to try SWG emulators and others. I played Vanguard until it went offline as well.

The good: Solid base so far. Combat is pretty fun and you get a choice between RPG (tab target) and FPS style. The mission system is convienient and being refined. The skill trees are diverse and varied. The crafting system is complex (see below). There are numerous ways to progress your character (combat, crafting, harvesting, diplomacy, entertainer etc). These  are completley viable playstyles in and of themselves. And you can technically do them all on the same character (classless, lskill point based progression with no limit on skill points accrued). Pets, tamed, bought, built. Yes, you can go tame baby creatures and raise them, build bots, genetically engineer pets, etc.

The bad: I love crafting. I spent at least a solid year on SWG doing that almost exclusively (by hand, no macros). I love the fact they are trying hard to make the crafting (and other professions) viable. That being said, at first glance I think it's a bit too complicated and interdependent at the moment. There are very few (if any) low level recipes that are useful in an of themselves. Interdependence among crafters is forced. Even most low level recipes require components from multiple disciplines. You might as well include harvesting in this as well, as your skill at harvesting affects the quality of raw and refined mats. Unfortunatley it relies on the premise there will be crafters fulfilling all the parts required. A crafter just starting out, who has no money, cannot collect higher grade mats, and/or make high grade end products, will basically be forced to run missions and grind out sub-par items for xp.

Keep in mind this is a first impression and solely an opinion. I may very well change my mind after a bit more time.



That being said, I see HUGE potential. I think they can streamline it a bit, ease up a little on the interdependence, and tone down the recipe complexity a little. Honestly, even if it doesn't change much, I'd still play and most likely craft. I don't see it attracting many crafters in it's current iteration though.

I'll update as the game progresses. This is my first review after years of playing games on Steam. I'm not the guy that generally takes time to write reviews, but I really want this game to succeed. I'm tired of the trash that's being churned out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the few games out there with such depth.  I've just completed my second week on this game and have been amazed by the vastness of the world and item (read: crafting) system.  I've never played Ultima Online or Star Wars Galaxies, but other players ingame say that those are the closest comparisons.  I like to think of The Repopulation as a Runescape on steroids with a touch of EVE Online. While I could talk about various aspects of the game, I'm going to focus on crafting which seems to be the strongest point in the game currently.

Pros - Crafting
There's a highly complex crafting tree for making things like weapons and armor, vehicles, consumables etc.  I specialize in Armor Fittings, which enhance the stats of your armor.  Unlike most MMOs out there, the armor and weapons themselves don't matter as much as the fittings which you insert into them.  In order to craft Armor Fittings I rely on other players to harvest ore, wood and plants which I then turn in to refined metal bars, firewood and chemicals to craft the components that I will eventually need to make a single fitting.  If no one is gathering Calibrite Ore, and the auction house is empty, then I must go out and gather some myself.  Armor Fittings are one recipe of the larger Armor Crafting discipline, which is itself one of several hundred skill paths players can choose from.  The interesting thing is knowing that you rely on other players on your server to gather materials that you can't gather, and to craft items you can't craft yourself.  While you can theoretically DIY, it takes significantly longer than bartering and buying/selling to and from other players.  Plus, advanced items require dozens of ingredients to come together.

Cons - Crafting
The system can be daunting to players who are used to very simple crafting systems like World of Warcraft and other theme park MMOs.  In a theme park MMO you would mine ore, refine it into bars, then use that to create items.  On The Repopulation each ore gives different properties to a finished product (armor penetration, damage, resistance, movement speed, critical hit).  Ores also come in varying grades with a letter prefix A-F and an integer suffix 0-9 which can only be harvested by those with high skill in the corresponding ability.  So to make a very good quality Armor Fitting I would need to hire a Master Miner, and a Master Ore Refiner just to ensure that the metal bars I have are the best possible.  I would also need a Master Forager to gather plants, and a Master Chemist to synthesize the compounds I need.  I could do it all myself, but training 4 skills to such a high level would take months to attain.  Recipes are highly complex, and you will find yourself opening your web browser to check on agents, and sub-ingredients to make those agents quite often during crafting.  Once you do get the hang of it, though, it gets much easier and manageable.

Cons- Other
The graphics leave something to be desired.  The engine seems old, so the models ingame from players to NPCs to the environment are lower quality than most people are used to in 2015.  As an alpha game there are some bugs and glitches that still need to be ironed out.  You can phase through objects when zoning between areas, and the combat seems clunky rather than fluid.  With a still new player base, everyone's still in that learning process so it gets frustrating at times when trying to find others to help you build cities or craft items that you need.  The game is not easy to play and requires some thinking.  After playing the game for two weeks it feels like I took college courses in Chemistry, Geology, Mechanical Engineering.  If you're looking to just zone out, then the crafting system isn't for you.  But the combat and doing missions is still very viable for someone not looking to get too involved.

For a quick overview here are the numbers:
There are about 15 different weapon types you can choose from.
There are currently 100 or so skills you can choose to specialize in.
There are around 1,000 recipes to choose from when crafting.
There are 60,000 levels for each skill.
Level 500 Mining took me about 1 week of gametime to reach, but each higher level takes more and more time.
Simple crafting recipes require about 4 different ingredients to create.
Advanced crafting recipes require about 20 different ingredients.
There are 52 types of harvestable nodes in the game (ores, wood, plants...)
Each harvestable resource can be further broken down or combined with other resources to create even more complex components.

Quick Tips:
There are no levels in this game besides your levels in each skill.  Someone can have 6000 points in Fishing, but have 0 in Combat.
Monsters become easier/harder to kill depending on your weapon type and your armor type.
To get better" weapons and armor
date:
you must add Fittings to them to add stats.
Weapons and Armor have almost no stats besides Physical Resistance without Fittings.
The world is mostly player-owned apart from the starting cities.
The economy is 80% player-run and 20% vendors and NPCs.
The world is large.  It takes a very long time to traverse the landscape on foot
recommended: which is made easier with vehicles."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One word describes this game fairly well: Complicated.

I'm not a person that jumps into an MMO for story honestly so I can't tell you much about that, but what I can tell you is that this game is a complicated mess of wonderful excitement and achievement.  This is a game that won't have you getting bored at end game and making an alt because you can do whatever you want for as long as you want and you'll be playing for ages doing so.  Or if you're like me, you'll be skipping all over the place and end up a confused mess.  This game isn't the prettiest game (yet?) but if you're into crafting, this game has that in spades. If you're into easy questing, once again, it's there.  If you're into exploring, there's a huge map to explore with massive environments everywhere.  If you're into a great community, I haven't met a single unfriendly person yet and I've put a good 40 hours into the game (I was playing before it was on steam)

This game sends you into a world like a baby, confused, barely knowing how to breath, giving you the basics that you need to get by.  You'll learn how complicated the crafting system is, and the basics of crafting but there's so much more to absorb it's quite overwhelming at first. If you ask people though, they'll always help you out.  There's so much to find, so much to do, and so much to craft it's insane. After 40 hours gameplay time I'm just starting to get my bearings on how the crafting system works, I haven't even looked into the housing system or anything else.  I've just been gathering and crafting for that much time.

All in all while you'll start out a bit confused, you'll learn, you'll laugh, you'll love, you'll get frustrated but you'll keep coming back for more.  I highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a deep, complex, smart game to play instead of Collect/kill this many whatever and come back to me" kinda game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is Alpha and obviously has a lot of work ahead of it but what impresses me is most of the major features seem to work.  It has the potential to be the game I will call home for the foreseeable future.  Skill based system, player crafting economy, player housing/cities/nations and many other great features.  It all reminds me of UO and SWG (both early era) which are two of my favorite games.  If you have never played a skill based game before try it with an open mind.  No more leveling, what you actually do is what you become good at.

First off, the game is very rough around the edges.  Its Alpha so expect Alpha.  For Alpha however it is very impressive compared to others Ive backed.  Everything in general works.  It might not be pretty but it works.  My review will just be an example of a single play session as a complete noob:

Log in, check my in game e-mail for any quests Im interested in.  If one looks good I take it, if not I simply ignore them.  I hit the local bar/pub (allows you to enter a resting state that makes entertainment abilities usable) to do some Entertainment activities such as dancing and storytelling (this is the games buff system, the more people around using entertainment skills the faster you seem to stack buffs and of different types).

Once I get 6 stacks of all the buffs I can that last more than an hour, I head out of town, with my Adult Setlang pet and start murdering stuff with my rifle (gaining rifle skill and animal handing doing so).  I harvest any lumber or metal I can find as well as the corpses of the fallen (gaining survival skill and knowledge of what I kill).  Using my survival skills I upgrade the resources harvested as far I can (quality in materials matters to crafters).

Im working on my personal short term goal of building a speeder bike so I focus on the mats needed to create this (found by access an outside website for crafting, expect plenty of this).  If enough time goes by I also use my survival skill to create a camp in the wild to enter a resting state (same as the bar) and refresh my buffs.  If you have 6 stacks with a minute left, it only takes 1 more stack to refresh all stacks to max duration.

I find any baby animals I can tame and do so to raise animal handling.  I also have to craft food for my pets and feed them every hour so they can continue to grow to adulthood.  Eventually Ill be able to turn them into mounts if I choose depending on the animal.

Every fight I gain skill in Stealth, light armor and whatever other skills I use.  If I have to run and heal I gain in healing skill.  What you do is what you become good at, you get the idea.

Thats a very basic example of whats going on and it all works.  The animations are rough, the sounds are not great and not directional, the graphics glitch and the engine lags at times especially around what appear to be server lines but its still Alpha.  If the game can get polished up it will be a real gem.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recomend this game for players at full release.

Currently, it is in early access, and I only recomend it to those who want to bug test, activly give feedback to the developers, and tolerate a game with immense bug and glitch issues. Never buy an early access game unless that is what you are intending. Early access is not typicly for people who want to simply play a game, or people who want to test to see if they will enjoy it later. People who do this usually get a poor first impression and do not enjoy the full game, when they would have loved it at release had they not been turned off by their early access experience.

Now for my actual review:
This game is making huge strides at recreating the Star Wars Galaxies Pre-NGE gameplay. So much to the point that I ditched the emulator for it to participate in this games alpha/beta proccess. I can not give any comparisons to ultima online however, as I never touched that game due to personal circumstances.

What this game does well is truly allow you to be what ever you want, with out a scripted story or class system get in the way. I my self love linear stories for single player expiereinces, but I never could get behind it in an MMO setting.

Other things are:
-Completly open world
-Die hard sandbox
-Caters to both PVE and PVP players without comprimisng either types play quality
(VERY important to me, as I prefer PVE)
-Ability to play your entire time without being a combatant, yet still fill a very important role.
(Weapon Smith, Docter, Entertainer [Yes those are actually a BIG role], Resource gatherer, Cook, etc)
-Ability to build your own cities (As in custom build the structures and interiors) so long as you have the people. If you get enough folk to join you, they will start to fill the NPC pop and provide quests for you
-Better quest system. You get quests in the mail based on reputation. You can filter them to recieve only the quest types you want (I.E. Combat only, Resource gather only, Delivery run only)
- Good Charecter customization
-Excellent skill system
And many more features I can not rememeber at 1:35 AM

This game does have issues, but none of them are really GAME issues so much as BUG issues.

Over all, I highly recomend when it comes out. Right now though, only buy if you intend on bug testing and giving feedback for the devs. I enjoy simply playing it in the proccess, but I also have an abnormaly high tolerance for masive bugs and unfinished features. If you want to enjoy minimal bugs and fully fleshed out gameplay, early access is not for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recently bought this on steam for 15, it truly is SWG 2.
I've been really impressed with the level of customization, especially with player cities.

The crafting system is complex. There is a grading system in place. 50 grade levels with F0 - A9 that applies to components, ingredients and the actual items crafted. There is a big learning curve with the crafting system and it is designed so you are dependent on other crafting professions for certain high level components.

There is the normal AH, accessible from anywhere that also allows you to place work order for others to fill (think EVE).
The levelling system isn't straight forward, it is similar to SWG (from what I can remember) but not exactly the same. You pick up a weapon and the beginner skills, and you level it by using the weapon. When you reach a certain level you unlock an ability, but you do not get the ability yet. There are two ways to attain the ability, one is to spend training points which are given to you for completing missions. Mission completion can also give reward you directly with a choice of ability. It's a little hard to explain.

Another element of the skill/levelling system is Skill Imprinting points. All sorts of in game actions can reward you with SI points, which you can then invest in the relevant skills to give your level a boost.
There are two main factions warring with each other, and you can create your own third faction and align them with either main faction. I've not had a chance to play with this feature yet but as far as I know you can change your alignment at any time.

Combat seems pretty good to me but needs a little work. You can roll like in GW2 and there are a lot of combat classes such as Rifles, Automatic weapons, grenades, aerosol, bladed weapons, unarmed, blunt weapons, martial arts, axe, handguns, probably a few more and you can dual wield some of them. And shields.

There are healing abilities that require a healing scanner in the main hand, so any class can heal but it requires swapping out your weapon.
Anyone can play the entertainer class that dances and tells stories to give buffs. You can only do this in a rest" zone
date: which comes in the shape of inner city bars or player placed tents when out in the wild. You can tame animals with animal handling or buy them from a genetic engineer

reviewText:
Early Access Review

over 500hrs on record, so I'm not a paid hyper.  wish I was one though...*hint hint*

The game is in alpha, if you gripe about buggy stuff in betas, or full releases, stay away from this game in it's current state.  The game needs a lot of polish, and can, at times, rattle a nerve or two.  However, the game is fully playable, has a great community, great staff, and great development team.  You will almost certainly never see anything about thievery in the game.  Arguments are generally quick, and allowed to vent themselves out.  The whole atmosphere of the game is very helpful.

Developers are constant presence on the forums for, both, Steam and the main site.  In-game GM's are a constant, and interactive presence.  9.5 of 10 times you need a GM for something, there is one there for you.  You whispers GM's directly for any questions, or help with bugs.  For the most part, the community will help with trying to resolve your problems before you need to speak with a GM though.  We answer the same tired questions from new people like they did for us when we were new, and nobody complains about it.

Never be afraid to ask any questions in the game.  You'll always find someone to answer your question, and without belittlement.

As for the actual gameplay itself:

Pros -

1. There's an immensely huge crafting system that will wreck your frail little minds.
2. There's vehicles, and mounts.
3.  There's an entire line of skills and crafting focused around taming, training, and healing pets; which can be used as mounts as they evolve.
4. There's PvP.  However, atm the PvP system is a bit goofy, and arena based.  There are PvP contested areas in the world, but not currently activated for PvP combatants.  Like, you can go there, kill mobs and stuff, but can't be Pk'ed.  That will change with upcoming patches.  Also, there will be a hardcore, full Open PvP with loop drops.  This hardcore PvP server will be every definition of Hardcore.
5.  You can mine, fish, gather plants, log, and set harvester machines down to do the looting for you.
6.  The economy is player driven, so there is a lot of trade going on constantly.  I'm not going to lie to you though, at the game's current state, the market hotly debated upon.  There's this whole grade quality vs demand thing vs skill thing going on...  It would read to be more complicated and broken than it really is, so you'd have to experience it for yourself to understand it.
7.  There are many, many different wpn choices you can choose to specialize in.
8.  The world is huge, and it can take a long time to travel to some places.
9.  There's player housing, both, instanced and open world.
10.  There's player built and run cities.
11.  There will be flight.  There was talks that once drakes are tamable, you can fly them as mounts.
12.  There will be space flight, and other planets in future expansions of content.

I'm sure there's a lot I'm leaving out, but I've listed a good bit.

Cons -

1.  Endless bugs and glitches.  (it's alpha, stuff happens)
2.  The whole economy, and crafting system can be very overwhelming to new players.  At times it can still be confusing for old people.
3.  Crafting needs a lot of love.  There are aspects of the crafting system that are hotly debated, and need some serious tweaking.
4.  Not everything is in the game yet.  (like I said, it's alpha.)  Some things you're just going have to cope with.
5.  You will get stuck a lot.  Happens to everyone, and is usually fixable with a number of in-game commands, or other tricks.
6.  Things will go invisible, and you will have to exit to desktop a lot.
7.   The map systems are glitchy, and at times will white-out, blackout, or brown-out; causing you to exit to desktop.
8.  You're going to experience periodic server crashes.  They are not frequent, so you don't have to worry about crashing every ten minutes.
9.  Questing system is glitched, and needs a lot of love.  Some quest you cannot complete, the tracking system is far from helpfu, and the rewards need a tweaking.
10.  There is night and day system in the game in which NPC's are highly reliable on.  Most NPC's are out only during the day, but some are out only during the night.  This can make questing difficult, and confusing.

There's a lot more I could put here, but I'm not here to scare anyone off.  The overall game-play is still very fun, very doable, and highly worth it in my opinion.  As I've repeated several times in this review, it's an Alpha game, we as a player in an Alpha Phase game, you are /will be a tester.  Testers report the bugs encountered to help improve the game.

If you feel you can be patient, helpful, and want to make a difference in something, I encourage you to purchase this game and join us.  We're all friends here; even the people we dislike we get along with.  That's the type of community we have.  A good one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This project is what most 30-something gamers have been craving after being disappointed with a plethora of WOW clones and action-only themeparks over the last ten years. It is the first alpha I found worthy of paying for. A do-whatever-the-heck-you-want sandbox with unmatched versitility. No more running to npcs to get quests-they are mailed to you whilst you are doing whatever else. Don't like the quest? Delete it, another is on the way.  Such is The Repopulation. A bastion of potential. But your fun won't be completely unhindered:

-Unfinished graphics (althought the landscape looks quite good)
-Memory leak from the graphics engine that cause most systems to crash periodically. I experience it about once every 45 mins. with 4gb ram and a 650ti. This will be fixed with the hero 3 engine build at some point before launch.
-A lower frame rate that what you are accustomed to. This is because the game is currently running on Direct X 9c--Direct X 11 is coming, which means higher fps and  better overall appearance. To maximize fps, set draw distance at 50% and turn off shadows and anti-aliasing.

But even with all this, I still keep coming back. This is a noble project and a worthy place for mature gamers to call home.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a displaced veteran of gaming, I found myself wandering from genre to genre, game to game looking for a suitable replacement.  I wanted an experience that I felt I had been cheated of.  My only regret is that I didn't find or try The Repopulation sooner.

There are some games that come along once in a lifetime and build memories that haunt you through every MMO you attempt to play after that.  For me, SWG was that game.  That once, That feeling.....

The Repopulation has filled that void and turned the once in a lifetime into twice.  Still being polished and updated with every patch, this game holds interest and attention with command.  With offerings to suit the crafter, gatherer, warrior, dancer, story teller, medic, doctor, farmer....  you get the picture.  The essence of this game is being.  Simply being.

If you have been looking for a sandbox, this is the one.  No theme park, no single road.  This is truly make your own adventure".  Pair that with enhanced player based cities and housing.  Seiges and a truly player driven economy
date: incredible....  simply incredible.  I would (and have) recommended this to all my friends and SWG displaced communities.\n\nThanks for listening."

For an alpha game to pay $30+- seemed crazy.

From the outstart I had plenty of technical issues. When I hadnt even begin to play the game.  Like most people who spend money on a game(even alphas) I felt seriously frustrated at the black screens (that should have loading bars) camera position glitches, no mouse showing on screen, delay in game play (cause its still downloading game items in the background)

But this was put to rest very quickly because of one simple reason.

Support is AWSOME!!!!!!!!!

Quick turn around times to answering my technical questions like I have never seen before, from any of the major game manufactorers. Less than 15 minutes on my last query !!!!

And to receive an answer that actually solved my technical issue instead of a typcial scripted response, which normaly  sends me down a long winding rabbit hole to never getting my problem solved, made the feeling of being duped out of money disapear very quickly ( unlike my scar from the burn of SimCity, EA I will never forget !)

It gives me confidence that its a well spend investment on a Game, that clearly is drive and funded by the community. As long as they dont lose site of looking after the players needs/wants and problems.  It will always be worthwhile Buying this game now or in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Takes me back to Star Wars Galaxies MMO.  Repop is uniquely deep player-driven organic sandbox me. It is not a themepark, nor is it a harsh and hectic open pvp FPS.  One has control over every skill element through the tutorial, then upon use, and continuous refinement and focus on a skill, you can progress in them.  After the initial tutorial you pretty much have your choice of how you want to pursue your career, build your character, from that point onward.

If you prefer running missions, they have an advanced mission generation system that ensures you'll always have missions to do. It creates these based on your characters skill set and reputation. These aren't all simple missions either, the generation system allows for some very advanced missions, there are some that have 15+ steps but generated elements, NPCs, items, etc.

If you aren't a combat person, you can make your living in trade skills; player-driven auctions and house. Advancing in trade skills is independent of combat and does not force you into a combat role. As with combat, they have a complex trade skill system which allows for a high degree of customization by mixing and matching components. It also has a high degree of inter-dependency on others, which is going to drive the economy.

There aren't have caps to the number or mastery of skills so you can invest in each skill line how you see fit. It does take awhile to master each, so it does make sense to focus in fewer areas or work with others who can help to fill in the holes.

For example, trade-skill progression is both vertical (gaining more skill unlocks more abilities, better results from recipes, etc) and horizontal (I am skilled in both rifles and first aid so I can switch those roles if needed). Their vertical progression isn't as polarizing like in WoW (you might not be able to take a more skilled player in a 1vs1, but a 2vs1 it is very possible).   In SWG terms, you could have a 14 point tailor who is ALSO a master bounty hunter!  The same is true for The Repopulation.

Guilds, I think, will enjoy their nation system which allows them to construct cities in the open world, and to besiege the cities of their enemies.

Fans of public quests like Rift, Warhammer or Guild Wars 2 style events will enjoy the engagement system. It is similar to what you saw in previous games, but can also mutate and spread based on how players interact. Many of the engagements have long-term effects allowing content to cater itself to the way players are performing.

Suffice to say players have a high degree of freedom and choice, as opposed to being leashed to a path in a closed instanced world. Be it through entertainment, diplomacy, raiding, upgrading, vehicles, pet types (robotic, engineered or tamed), and three faction PvP.

Ok so I've been play testing a few weeks. Overall I really like the game. Crafting is in depth, possibly too in depth in some cases. But overall I like the sandbox feel, I like how you get quests and the fact you can filter them so only the types of quests you like are offered.

The Devs are great about listening to feedback AND communicating what's coming on the patches. Is it buggy? Yes it is an alpha in the true sense of the word. Yes there will be at least one wipe before launch. But even with that I don't mind the play testing and losing progress because well it's fun and it isn't like I won't be able to skill up after release and will by then know the way everything works.

If you like not having your hand held, can stand a slightly steep learning curve, and don't mind truly play testing not just playing early" then I'd say give it a shot!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will start by saying I started playing mmos back in the days of Asheron's Call. I loved it and after a while I moved on to Guild Wars and then Star Wars Galaxies. If any of you remember SWG you know that the game had a tremendous cult following in the world of mmos. WoW came out and SOE decided that their games should be pulling as much revenue as Blizzard was doing. They ended up murdering alot of what I loved about SWG though I continued to play it for a while afterwards. In the end though I just ended up going to WoW because it was a more polished game that was sticking with the vision the devs had set out for. SWG died and I played WoW for years... buying expansions as they came out. If anyone keeps up with WoW you know that it has lost half of its player base with the recent expansion not delivering on the hype of the previous xpacs. I again stuck around and gave the game a chance hoping it would pick back the pace but it just did not happen for me. So I went on a binge of trying different mmos until my buddy told me about this gem. I have to say that the game has alot of potential. Giving that we are still in alpha and how fun the game is I am very excited to see what the game will play like when it goes live.

Pros:
Sandbox Gameplay... This is where the game shines. Many mmos that claim to be sandbox are usually all hype and not enough substance. This game delivers at being very open ended. Even the quests are randomised and tailored to your character and the skills and approach you take.

So many skills... Again I love this. There are no combat levels. Just your many skills you start off with and the choice is yours on what you want to level. If you want to be a melee then choose your weapon. The more you use it the more skill you will aquire with that weapon type. This is reflected in the crafting and non-combat skills too.

The Crafting... OMG! If you like crafting in mmos and love complex and in depth systems such as SWG or the higher end minecraft mods... you will love the crafting in this game. There is so much to it you have to check it out to believe it.

Other non-combat skills... Dancing, story telling, diplomacy... There are many things to do outside of combat. They claim that you can play the whole game without fighting. While I guess that is possible... I don't know if it is as feasable as they say but even still there are a slew of things to do outside of combat and crafting.

Nation Building... While many games have guilds or clans that you can join this game takes a different approach and lets you create your own faction outside the two set ones called Nations. Nations are similiar to guilds except in a nation everyone outside your nation can attack you. You can form alliance with other nations to counter this but this takes building relations with other people which I find to be intriguing. The town building is very nice too and throwback again to SWG and older mmos where you can have your own housing and utility buildings for various things like shops and guildhalls.

Pvp... While I haven't been able to explore alot into this yet I will say the vision of what is possible seems pretty cool. Being able to seige other player cities is the biggest addition and the devs are still implementing new systems to this. Again unlike WoW where you have just horde and alliance... this game allows you to build your own faction and thus making you a primary target for everyone. While there are ways around this it still brings alot of potential to pvp players who love open world type pvp.

Animal Taming and Robots... The pet system on this game is good. The more your robotics or animal handling skill is... the more pets you can control at the price of a debuff. There are many features as well not seen in many mmos such as having to care and feed for your pets among other things.

Graphical style... While alot of people shy away from the stylized graphics of this game I personally find them very suitable to the immersion. It does feel like mass effect and SWG met up and had a baby but that is perfectly fine with me since I loved both games.

Free to play: and the devs swear that it won't be pay to win. We appreciate this.

Cons:

Stability: This is the main issue with the game right now. There is lag and crashes and just overall weird glitches rampant as of 10/10/2015. The next patch is suppose to clean alot of this out so I won't be too harsh on this. That being said this is the worst experience of the game at this stage.

No instances: while this is a good thing too... I tend to find the lack of dungeon-crawling aside from the occasional cave or what-not. Just yea the pve could use a bit of a boost and not saying that instance dungeons are the way to go but in my experience this is where pve shines in mmos so the devs will just have to get creative on this aspect if they want the end game to keep those raiders hooked to this title.

Crafting and other systems can be a bit overwhelming at times: Again this is both a positive and negative. I personally love the deep systems but alot of players will look at it and be like yea !@$! this. If you are familiar with crafting systems in WoW and other mmos this is by far much more sophisticated. If the devs give this kind of love to the other systems... i.e. pvp and pve that will be needed to keep a strong and dedicated player base going then yes this will be a fabulous mold of a different approach to all things mmo.

So again this game is still in alpha so I am curious as to see what the devs have in store for future patches. If you are looking for a great mmo to get in on the early stages then look no further.

reviewerDisplayName: edzy I GOT MY PC BACK!
reviewText:
Early Access Review

Where do I begin?
At first, I was having trouble finding my way around and training center and getting used to the undeveloped parts of the movement and animations, which took some time. Once I popped out into the world, beginning my adventure in Freedom Town I almost instantly felt at home.
The community in The Repopulation is beautiful, I haven't had such a good time just talking in the General / Trade chat since Goldshire in Vanilla WoW.
The Repopulation is definitely not as casual as most MMORPG's out there and to this point I am still dying quite frequently in combat.
Nonetheless, I absolutely adore where this game is going and will be proudly supporting it as much as I can.
Considering I am currently studying Digital and Interactive Games, I am EXTREMELY impressed with the overall development progress and approach.

If you are just starting out in The Repopulation, please give it some time. It can be frustrating and you can easily get lost, but I'm sure other players will assist you in anyway possible! Allow yourself to adapt to the game and you will enjoy it as much as I am.

I can't wait to watch the progress, very big THUMBS UP.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Repopulation is a pioneering game.  One of the few MMORPGs to be kickstarted and community funded.  This is a special Indie project that has brought together a number of different individuals all united with a passion to develop The Repopulation and make it the best MMORPG it can be.  This is a game where the community is respected and respectful, where the Devs answer multiple posts on a daily basis. Where one person's idea or suggestion can find it's way into the next patch.

This is a game where volunteers are welcome to bring their enthusiasm and skills to making this game be the home so many people want to see. One of the advantages of being involved with an Indie development company is that you get a very honest and refreshing view of what is and is not possible and marketing speak is something more alien than the languages spoken by the sentient species in the game world.

This is a game that successfully appeals to a number of different gamer interests. There is indepth and complicated crafting that deeply appeals to those who want to sate their intellectual curiosity on working out what part of the web of interdependent crafters they want to craft in.

There are missions that cater to everything from a basic courier mission, to a heart melting story about love and loss in the Protests that helped shape the current political climate and war.

There is a contested area in the middle of the two main factions where anyone can be attacked. It is here that rogue nations can set their own diplomatic relations with all factions and nations and build cities to house their citizens and then defend those citizens against incursions from enemies.

This is a game about offering choices and letting people make and be known by those choices.

I backed this game in January 2014 and I do not regret a single penny. Joining this community and supporting this development is one of the best things I ever did. I've encountered a diverse and talented bunch of people since I got involved.

So please head to the main site http://www.therepopulation.com and read and absorb. This is a unique community and I look forward to seeing you join us.

It was 2012, and I was browsing Kickstarter for interesting games to back, when I first encountered The Repopulation - and my first impression was dominated by just two thoughts:
.) Holy , this might be exactly the game I always wanted
.) Holy , this done so unprofessionally and going to fail so hard
but I wanted to learn more.

Their website mostly was more bullet-point lists, just like the Kickstarter page and video, very fine-grained details, but I was utterly unable to get the big picture. Still, some of those bullet points were very intruiging - and I felt I'd rather have that game try and fail, than to never have it get a chance in the first place. So I backed.

Backing the game so early reserved me an early alpha spot, and so I was able to start playing (... well, testing" rather...) the game in June 2014 - long before it ever was released to Steam Early Access. I've spent several hundred hours with the standalone client since

Early Access Review

Okay, where to begin. Pro's Con's? Sure why not.

-PROS-

*In Depth Crafting Systems
*Not a quick progressing game, Meaning, you get what you put into it.
*PvP is not a must, but definately an option.
*Be yourself (Play and progress any way you desire)
*Massive World
*Always something to do
*Great community

-CONS-

*Still pretty buggy
*Not the most asthetically gratifying - Yet
*Huge learning curve
^^^^^^^Thats really all that ive noticed^^^^^^^^^

Okay, this is a review for its current pre-beta state. Graphics arent a huge priority for devs in this current stage, it WILL be polished by release. Ide much rather them get out content and fixes before worrying abt how it looks. If you dont like bugs, or occational crashes, or anything of that sort, dont play. If you enjoy learning the game as it progresses and molds over time, and knowing who is who from the beginning, BUY THIS GAME!!!

Ive been checking back in with this game quite often to see what has changed. Now that i have some friends playing it makes it alot more enjoyable. Things are easier, and the entire game seems to have more just by adding 1 or 2 people to play with. Servers are not dead, but the world is so big its hard to find people in the open world.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well... it's my first insight into the game. Please take a note that I didn't play any social-oriented MMOs before apart from Lord of the Rings: Online (2008-2015), which has a lot of it.

First impression - it's hell of a buggy and the graphics are outdated. Missing textures, low-poly models and such can be a pain, yes. And animations? While some are great (like moving with the weapon unholstered) some, well, are not. Clipping body parts, etc.

Then you notice there is no such thing as exp and levels. Yes, it's a MMORPG without levels and experience grind - it's about roleplaying. It's what RPGs once were.

*Some seasoned gamer sensitive emotions skipped*

Then you see social content - dancing, storytelling, pickpocketing, crafting... Crafting. It is even more complicated than the EVE Online crafting, which is sort of an achievement. But it's also entertaining as hell to the ones like me.

Then you see combat and cry over the outdated effects. Those need some hard work, but will certainly make a do for now. Bugged corpses can freak out some sensitive people though.

Then you see towards the end of the Tutorial... And OH IT'S  MORNING ALREADY!

Would rate 8/10 for everyone enjoyed KotOR.

Been play/testing this game from the main site for a while now, finally got it linked to Steam. I played SWG for several years and have been looking for another game with a meaningful crafting system ..well here it is. The game is still in Alpha and things are being tested and improved each day, but as it is the game is very playable.

The Devs listen and are willing to pull ideas from the player community, which is a refreshing change from oher games. They often can be seen on the servers working with the testers or trying out a new idea.

Some will say that crafting is complicated, well good, I was getting tired of item one, item two, and we all have the same old Uber Sword of Death as everyone else. With Repop the magic is in the fittings that are added to your weapons and armor, and even your abilities.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game immerses you into a realm of the unknown which only adds to the addiction factor. The tutorial gives you the very basics of gameplay and then you're left to explore and learn the depth of this beautiful game.

The developers really spent time developing the complex systems instead of story. They are working to provide a complete sandbox that will allow you to adventure the way you want to; logger, miner, fisherman, flower picker, looter, weaponsmith, droidsmith, vehicle engineer, armorsmith, creature tamer, rifleman, hangun enthusiast, unarmed combatant, blunt weapons expert, dance, storyteller, and many many more.

If you get lost, just ask someone around you (or in General chat) a few questions. This is a social game. Don't be afraid to be social. Some believe that games should be centered around the social and community aspects; these guys nailed. I can forsee a day when the cantina of a player city is filled up with individuals wanting to get buffed before a large PVP battle.

If you're looking for a complete and finished product, you may want to let this cook some more; but if you'd like to jump ahead of the rest and understand the complexity of the game before everyone else, BUY IT NOW!!!
