reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like Star Wars :Galaxies you would love this, its basicly the same thing just...well just more amazing! Great game so far, ran into very few bugs as an alpha game.

Now im updating this since i have the time,

There are lots of neat features that alot of players from SW:G would see.

Skills: This is the primary element of the game, Skills progress as you play. The more you shoot Automatic weaponry, The more it goes up. The more you harvest Plants the more your Flora skill goes up, The more you craft weaponry, ect. This makes the game more time consuming yes, but at the same time you do not have to put a full 12 hours of gameplay to progress, For instance if you only have 2 hours a day to game you can still get to do things others do, Granted it will take you longer than someone who spends 12-18 hours a-day but still you can do it too with no restrictions other than your time.

Gameplay: This element of the game can be played majority in two ways, RPG mode; Simple understanding, Movement keys work and you use your mouse and keyboard to play like you would in World of Warcraft.[ Not comparing just saying that you use number keys to use skills and what not]
So basicly your standard MMO controls almost with key differnces that are easily seen when you play.
Action Mode: This mode is my personal fav when it comes to combat. This mode turns the game into a Fake shooter, You aim with the mouse you get a crosshair and you attack with your left and right mouse buttons. There are ALOT of bonuses to this, If using guns you can AIM and hit Certain areas dealing more or less damage. making combat more fast pace you can still use # keys for skills, The only thing that changes ins the control scheme.

So i use RPG mode for everything else but combat mostly. If i feel lazy i will use RPG to attack. In RPG mode damage is mostly chest as spread is wider in RPG mode with guns. (This as if firing a gun from the hip its more inaccurate yeah?)

Sandbox Features: These features plays a major role later on, I have yet to buy one i am working on my offical character now but with these features you can do several things, so far what i can tell there are going to be Three memberships which are all going to be a ONETIME PAYMENT, Silver, Gold, Plat. Gold and Plat can both make towns/cities while plat will get access to Nation. Not sure as this is Early Access so i do not know the Release prices. Nations are part of the Sandbox features as this makes you a Rouge faction, This is a playermade faction. (Sorta like guilds) Now i know what everyone is thinking. OH GREAT I HAVE TO PAY REAL CASH TO HAVE A GUILD" You may have to MAKE ONE

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Repopulation is a Sandbox MMO, and not just by title. I've never felt more free in an MMORPG than I have with The Repopulation, you can do weapon crafting, armor crafting, fishing, mining, log gathering, plenty of combat skills, plenty of generated quests (and I didn't even scratch the surface with this).  Don't expect some half- cookie cutter A to B" quest t.

You don't even have to do quests as a matter of fact. You could just gain experience doing other things. You will get sent quests via ingame mail and you can choose whether or not to do them. They also give you quests based on what you like to do

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Long have I looked for a MMO which apply to me, in my opinion a game should be about doing what you want and while you do it you shall have a very fun time doing so.

In many ways The Repopulation seem to be spot on, the crafting is very comprehensive, thers no doubt that this game was made by gamers who are really into crafting, having to ensure quality for every piece in order to have the highest end product is just spot on if you ask me.

Skill system is very interresting, we have seen in done before and with great success, you don't have any char levels, instead you gain skills by using the respecive tools, weapons or crafting.. theres even skill gain on using a mount!

You can easily switch between RPG mode (WOW style) and FPS, personally i perfer combat pulling in RPG mode for then to switch to FPS mode, during crafting or gathering professions my choice is clearly RPG view.

Everything in this game is based on players themself supplying eachother, and they don't make days long enough for you to do everything on your own (ofc you can still try), but eventually you'll have to settle with what best suits your playstyle and what you want to do. Want to switch later on? Sure, just start doing it, thers no limit as to how many skills of professions you can learn. Personally a perfer mining along with some simple hunting.

You remember Project Entropia (later on Entropia Universe)? This game is much similar to it, crafting is way more advanced and challenging, but mining isn't and thats maybe something which has to change, there was many miners in PE and the way you mined there is something that beats WOW-mining style any day of the week. Who wants braindead mouse clicking on a pixelrock? Not me. Im crossing my fingers for devs to look at different opportunities.

I'll clearly recommend this game to anyone interested in getting involved in the development of a game and leaning the game early on. It's far from launchable and new content along with fixes are added all the time. The potential of this game is pretty much limitless and if done correctly this game has the potential to be a very good game for many years to come.

Keep in mind tho, game will be F2P, what this means for server cost vs income per player is to early to tell, but thers no doubt that as I predicted some years back, F2P game are here to stay. But they also bring with them new challenges and in my eyes there havent been that many successfull" F2P games

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game knowing it was in alpha, getting into the game took a few hours (it has a pretty steep learning curve) but the community really helped with all the questions i had. This game has a super complex and deep crafting system, open world with player housing. Basically a very satisfying SWG revival. There are bugs, but that is why you are looking at buying an early access game anyway right?! The bugs in general arent that bad and they jut need a bit of rounding off before this game really runs smooth. This game has a massive amount of potential and from what I've seen from the in-game devs and GMs, I am hopeful.

My bigget 3 pros/cons

+The most in-depth crafting system of any game...ever...
+Community and GM presence is fantastic
+Economy driven/crafting/foraging oriented game that is plesantly complex

-Bugs (obviously)
-Current build has a pretty crappy UI
-Graphics arent fantastic (if you care about that kind of thing)


I recommend buying/playing/loving this game now and helping the devs. Ill be back once this hits shelves, see you all there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted to log a few hours into this game before I gave a review.   Leaving a review of an alpha game is kind of tough so this will be more of a first impression than anything else.   Im a crafter, so this review will come from that standpoint.
There is definitely a resemblance to SWG and Ultima online when you play this.  Its a game where the crafting actually matters.  If you want to run dungeons to get uber gear this isnt the game for you.  If you want to be known on the server for being able to craft some of the most sought after items then you will have a home here.

The crafting is immense and can take some time to get into.   Most items need many components to craft.  The components come from several branches of crafting.  You can learn them all but it takes time to raise your skill.  Some of the items you can craft are:

Robots (pets)
Genetically Engineered Animals (pets)
Implants
Harvesters (mineral, wood, water and so on)
Housing Items
Weapon and Armor Fittings
Vehicles
And many, many more items.

The crafting can be difficult to understand at times but the community is great help.  After about a week I was able to make my first robots.  There is a work order system so if you need mats you can request them there.  There is also the ability to have your own shop merchant at your house or in the city if you belong to a player nation that has built a city.

There will be nation vs. nation pvp and city sieges (Mechs).  There will be hardcore and standard servers.
Abilities include pet taming and vet skills (You can raise a mount).  You can be an entertainer or diplomat.   There is no class system, you only limited by the skills you pick up (and you can get them all).

There is definitely a lot more to cover but I havent gotten into much more yet.  Ive got about 90 hours in and feel that I have barely scratched the surface.

If you enjoyed SWG and games like Dark Age of Camelot this game is probably for you...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm somewhere between neutral and dislike on this game. It has it's fun elements, but the devs don't appear to understand what a sandbox game actually represents. While the game nominally supports multiple play styles, in practice the devs design the systems to force players into a very limited set of choices. It's not really a sandbox, it's an open world game with a permanently broken crafting system and a lot of missions.

The more systems you have in a game, the more choices you should feel like you have. Instead, in Repop, so many of the systems they added are gated behind strict controls that it limits choice. The dev team has a few inflexible ideas on how the game should" be played and they don't seem trust their future player base
date:
so players end up with only a few inflexible options.

One of the biggest draws of the old-school sandbox games Repop is supposed to be emulating is that the players were allowed a lot of latitude in what they did. That latitude is not here.

A lot of fuss is made over the crafting system. Crafting has a lot of pieces and an obtuse interface
recommended: so it's easy to mistake it for a deep and interesting system. It's _confusing_
hoursPlayed: but it's not at all deep. After figuring it out
voteText: it becomes clear that it's messy and shallow and requires very little thought. Given the same pile of ingredients
helpfulPercent:
a "smart" player and a "stupid" player will make exactly the same items. I would much prefer a system that allowed for intelligent decision-making on the part of the players.

The materials chain has been designed so that all but one-fifth to two-fifths of the in-game production is useless. Most resources are useless. Most items you can create are useless. Despite designing the harvesting and crafting this way there's no system to constructively absorb all the useless cruft.

The economy is only partially player-driven. Having figured out fairly early in the process that they were too ambitious with the crafting system
votesHelpful: the devs integrated inexpensive vendors and common loot drops of key items that are too complex or too boring to be supplied entirely by players. Have fun slaving away clicking thousands of times to skill up making circuit boards or copper wires that can be looted off any NPC human opponent

You'll find creature handlers

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following TRP for a very long time and am probably one of the longest running testers outside of friends and family.

To start off, TRP certainly harkens back to the golden age of sandbox MMOs and heavily references titles from that era such as Star Wars Galaxies, Vanguard, Anarchy Online, and even Ultima Online.

If you cut your MMO teeth on World of Warcraft, and you liked it, bu and play TRP at your own risk.  TRP is sandbox, not a themepark.

***THE REPOPULATION IS A SANDBOX, NOT A THEMEPARK***

You set your goals and you achieve them. Simply leveling up skills for the sake of leveling is meaningless in this game.  It's what you can contribute that matters.

A lot of player's first mistake is assuming that the game revolves around your character; it doesn't. There's no hero's journey here. TRP revolves around real, tangible accomplishments.

Last night my nation, the 47th Legion, found a city plot and began construction of our base. That base means 1,000x more than my personal character achieving grand master in rifle skill. In a sandbox like TRP the character progression is completely ancillary to server accomplishments. This is a game about learning where materials are, how to refine or manufacture awesome stuff, finding a patch of dirt to call yours, taking said patch of dirt away from people you don't like, exploring, building your brand and/or businesses, building a community, et cetera.

In TRP you actually have to accomplish something that matters.  There's no race to max level, there's no instanced raid progression, there's no gear treadmill; you just go out into the world and make your way however you can.

If you want some real freedom in an MMO for once try out TRP.  If you need to be led by the nose and constantly handed feel-good-confirmations and gear trinkets hit the back button right now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh boy, where to start.

I freakin' love this game, let me get that out there first but I recognize it isn't for everyone.  If you like old school MMOs and have gotten tired or burned out on more recent MMOs where your existance in the game is largely running errands for NPCs, this one could interest you.

Fair warning, there be a learning curve ahead.

I've put 60 hours into the game at the time of writing and have so barely scratched the surface, it's laughable.  As I slowly learn more and more about the game, I start to like it more and more.  The crafting system is very complex and the different discilplines are tied together so one person cannot easily do everything, which forces cooperation within a group or buying materials from other players on the auction house.  It's not as simple as collect the resources, click a button, and poof I have my brown leggings of might!  The quality of the resource matters, how familiar your character is with the recipe matters, your character's skill in that profession matters.

There are no limits on what your character can do.  Mastering a profession" requires an enormous amount of time so it really just comes down to what do you want to spend your time doing.  Want to learn how to tame and control animals?  Do it.  Want to craft weapons or armors?  Do it.  The more you do it
date: the better you get.  Tons of areas to level your character
recommended: you'll never reach the end.\n\nI could go on but I'll put it bluntly: This is a complex game that requires some time but if you invest. it becomes extremely rewarding.  It may be comforting to know the community is very friendly and helpful and GMs are active in General and Newbie chat to help you figure out the game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, this game is still in development, so it is not finished and in a polished state. That said, it is still currently a very fun and amazing game already. There are constant updates and new content, and enough can't be said about the developers. They take the time to talk to the players on the forums, and you can tell how much this game means to them. You know that they will do the best job they are capable of.

As for the content, if you were a fan of UO or SWG you will absolutely love this. It is a skill-based open world. Even more than those games were. You don't have the hard skill caps they did, and so you have even more freedom. You can have as many different skills as you want to, so long as you put the work into them. Just pick up a weapon or tool and start using it. As you raise your skills you gain new abilities you can use, and you also are able to add more and better fittings to your weapons and armor. There is no ultra loot in this game. No magic sword of whoop-. Armor comes in three classes: light, medium, and heavy. Each has it's own advantages and disadvantages. But within each class the only difference between the types of armor are only cosmetic. They are all the same, just look different. To improve it you need to use the fittings. Weapons work the same. You can keep the same armor and weapons you get from character creation and be just as effective with your skills maxed. If you play with the mindset of the level-based WoW clone games of questing for the best loot gear and always chasing the level cap to have a chance to compete or have the advantage, you'll be lost. This game definitely has a huge learning curve, but once you get it you will have a blast.

There is also plenty to do in game, regardless of what your interests are. If you like to PvP there is that, with the game based around essentially a futuristic civil war, with an additional Rogue faction that is independent of the other two main factions. If you like to PvE there is plenty of things to hunt, and dungeons to go to. If you like to craft, the economy is very heavily player based with very few things able to be bought from NPCs. If you like to RP they are adding in plenty of features for that. They have entertainers that can provide buffs like in SWG. Diplomacy/intimidation skills that allow you to interact with NPCs. The player nations can build player cities. There are different types of player housing you can own. Or you can simply wander and explore the huge world. Basically any playstyle is represented. You can solo, join with a small group of friends, or be in a huge guild with lots of people. The community is great, very helpful and friendly. You aren't forced into anything. Some things may take longer, but just about anything is possible if you are willing to put in the effort.

Again, the game is not finished yet. There are still some problems and bugs, and a lot of content still to be added. I played Vanguard beta and launch, and this game feels much further along to me already. That doesn't mean it's done, though. I've been playing since December 2014, and just in that time it's amazing how much has been added and fixed. I can't wait to see the finished product. You can go on the forums and see everything that gets added for each update. Be prepared for a lot of reading, as it's a lot! And there are constant, regular updates.

If you are expecting to play a finished game, just hold on and wait. You will want to try this when it is released. If you are willing to play now and use the opportunity to play a fun game while helping the developers by finding bugs and learning how things will work so that you know what to do at release, then it is well worth the cost and I highly recommend this game.

I played UO for nearly five years, and SWG for three. This is the game I've been looking for since.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Recommended as long as you don't mind buggy alpha development phase. If you can't handle that, wait until beta. Animations and a lot of visual things are, quite frankly, -terrible-. However, the gameplay is solid. There is so much to do, the map is already huge, and it looks like it can expand easily when the developers decide to. There's a potential to really find yourself a niche in the game's community where you can excel, which I think it my favourite part. Nobody can do -everything-, so whatever you choose to do, someone's going to need what you make. Some people are saying that there's too much for skills and crafting, but I say there can't be too much. The more there is, the more you can specialize, and the more you can come together as a community [or a nation!] to get things done and done well. I think nation building is going to be huge, with that kind of a mechanic, with leaders bringing people together and organizing their members to do what needs to be done for the betterment of their group, unlike other games where you don't -really- need anyone else to get by.

Just got it a few days ago and I keep playing, but I'm still just poking around the main town and the couple maps out from it, just like someone else said. If you play, expect to start slow. I advise you ignore everything but the basics to start, get comfortable with the game mechanics, then slowly ease yourself into crafting something. I'm definitely going with Animal Handling for my main mastery! Still need to dive into the crafting a bit more. :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has huge potential.  I have not played a MMO like this in a long time.  A lot of players are saying it is like SWG and while I did not play that game I now wish I had.  Of course at this stage there are a few glitches and bugs, but nothing horrible.  I have enjoyed actually working towards a goal and the fact that I cant accomplish everything on my own.  It's not like WOW in that you can craft everything with a toon or two.  You need to specialize in this MMO and work within the community to accomplish your goals.

The people you see giving this game bad reviews either have a error preventing them from playing which is normal in alpha, or they prefer games like WOW where everything is just handed to them.  They are only concerned with getting their purple pixels, not with actually working towards something.  So if you are looking for a game that actually embraces what a MMO is supposed to be this is it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game (if it continues to develop on its current track and at its current speed) will be one of the best games made in the last 20 years. There is a huge market gap for games like this that only appeal to people with some intelligence and with a mature developed attention span. The heavily consequence driven and socially complex design theme makes the game play experience extremely intense. When I fight in PVP I get the same massive increase in heartrate i used to get on eve. Something that I cannot replicate on these nanny games made today. If i do not fear death, i do not care about it either, and in this game I FEAR DEATH!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a fantastic scifi sandbox mmorpg that really gave me a feeling I haven't felt since the pre-combat upgrade days of Star Wars Galaxies.  Literally one of the only things I see holding this game back is the lack of a community. There are maybe 50 people on the US server that are online at a time, so it's hard for new players to get the proper support from others that they need. Not only that, but a lot of the game depends on player to player interactions, especially when it comes to crafting and the auction house, so it can be difficult for players who may want to play a non-combat role in the game to get the materials that they need. That's why I want to encourage everyone who enjoys this genre of mmo to support the development and buy into the alpha now.  Anyway, here's why the game is awesome:

-Huge maps to explore, barely any instances at all! Nearly Seamless!!!
-amazingly indepth crafting system.
-leveling the right way! instead of your character having a base level, every single type of gear, weapon, armor, skill, you name it... has its own level that has to be leveled the good old fashioned way, by practicing it. Using a particular skill or item will level that specific thing, so if you shoot a lot of pistols you gain experience in pistol tactics, you use light armor you get light armor tactics, etc.
- (this one is a pro and a con) Community dependant. It thrives when there is a huge player base, which it does not have at the moment. There are building plots, which allow for entire player built cities to be placed. There is so many different crafting skills to choose from and sooooo many different components needed to craft these different things that it makes it difficult when there aren't many crafting components for sale on the auction house. Please support the game, the developers, and the community to make this game even better!

I mentioned this earlier but it really does bring me back to the Galaxies pre-CU days. It's not an exact clone of SWG, but it does follow in the footsteps as an amazing sandbox mmo.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Repopulation is a Sci-Fi Sandbox MMORPG that truly seems to remember what made the MMO genre great in the first place.

The game is still in alpha, so it isn't feature complete, completely balanced, or polished. It is, however, very fun and entirely playable in its current state. The game developers are professional, active in the community, and extremely hard working (the monthly patch notes are more extensive than any I've ever read). Most of the community (especially the players who've been there since the early days) is very friendly and helpful.

That being said, The Repopulation is not for everyone.
The systems are complex, making them difficult to learn but very rewarding.
This isn't a themepark MMO, so don't expect a carrot on a stick to keep you playing--you set your own goals.
Again, the game is still in alpha, so there are bugs and incomplete features.

So, if this sounds like your type of game, come join us on Rhyldan. You won't regret it.

(About my low play time--I've actually been playing the game for over a year, but only recently added it to my Steam library expressly for writing this review).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reviewing an EA MMO is very difficult.  Especially one as large a scale as TR is trying to be.  It's basically trying to be the next Star Wars Galaxies pre-NGE.

It's combat is clunky.  It's graphics are primitive.  The only thing it has going for it right now is the crafting system, which is very expansive.  I suppose the skill system is pretty nice as well, with skills going up to 6000.  It'll take you a LONG time to get every skill to that.  So the reward for grinding is there.

Right now the dev is unable to update the game due to the host of the Hero Cloud service going bankrupt.  I dont know the whole story.  But they need a new donor or sponsor before they can re-open the service.  Why the dev's picked the Hero Engine is beyond me.  I think it's terrible for optimization.  I realize it is expensive to make an MMO.  And for a company making their first game, I do no think an MMO is the first project they should undertake.  So for that reason, I guess the Hero Cloud is cheaper to host then their own servers.  But since that happened, the devs cannont update TR.  You'll notice not a single update since September.

At least the dev lead JC  removed the game for sale until they resolve this issue.  Just don't expect an update until early next year.  Hopefully the devs are still working on this in the mean time and will release 3-4 huge updates all at once.

I would say pass for now but you can't even buy the game so...sure, it's a thumbs up for now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game for people who love tons of complexity, crafting, and difficult griding.  No difficulty curve, there is a difficulty cliff.  However like most things, if you work at it, take the frustrations; and learn the system, it's relatively fun.  Only 15 hours in (as of writing this review).

Hours 0 - 5: Beating head against wall because skills and algorithms don't make sense
Hours 5 - 8: Beating head against wall because I have no clue where to find resources proper to grind crafting
Hours 8 - 10: Beating head against wall because it takes 100 lil pieces to make something decent.
Hours 10 - 13: Putting ice to forehead because of previous head beating-- finding resources and other things slowly
Hours 13 - 15: Finally started understanding system better and getting more familiar with the system.

Overall -- Game is fun if you're into grinding, graphics are nice, decent community ready to help at a moments notice, really well done character creation/customization.

I recommend this game only to the hardest core of gamers that are looking for a real challenge; if your casual action gamer I don't think this is the game for you even with the 1st person shooter elements; the RPG elements can slow down the action for someone looking for fast paced action.

Attention -- I am no where near end game, and have no participated in PvP as of this moment, I cannot speak for that; that maybe more fast paced than I anticipate.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to keep this short and sweet, as if i was writing what *i* would want to hear from an indie sandbox MMO review.

So here it is:
The game is solid. The combat feels solid. Movement feel solid. Mounts feel solid. Massive open world. Very minimal instancing. 3 Faction PVP. Deep crafting system. Lots of juicy skills to master. Dynamic / public quests. Rich loot system. Player housing and world building. Melee and ranged classes. Vehicle crafting and much more you'd expect from a modern sci-fi sandbox. The world actually feels alive and the lore is intriguing. Many Sandbox devs completely skimp on this area of development. In my opinion, a world without solid lore isn't a world i want to be in.

The game feels challenging with lots of paths worth investing in, as opposed to the multitude of games out there masquerading as MMORPG's when in reality they are nothing but a closed series of hoops to jump through while having your hand lead by the developers. Obviously it is in Early Access, it has some clunkiness to the interface and crafting in particular needs some refining, especially since it will play such an integral part to the game. You will need to work with other players in order to achieve big things as many of the craftable items require multiple components from multiple disciplines which would simply take too long to master alone. Good thing you can open up shop and sell your wares then huh?

It's been described as SWG meets UO (but i never played UO), to me its SWG meets Earthrise and i can't wait to get into the main release.

I have popped in now and again over the past year or so and I obviously stay current with the news of the game. I can once again state with confidence that this game is NOT going anywhere. Another poorly fleshed out MMO that will see it's demise likely before it even begins. Stay away.


This game is ugly, clunky, confusing, repetitive, bug riddled, and boring. I'm generally willing to overlook issues that others are not. But man, this game gives me a headache. Not because it's hard, because it isn't - but the graphics, UI, map, and minimap are just all so poorly implemented that it literally makes my head throb in pain.

The Audio is awful. I work in the audio industry and i'd be embarrassed if this were my sound design work. The quality of the sound effects are bad. The music flutters in the game and needs to be muted.

The graphics in this game are mixed. The 3D player art is really nice. Beyond that it's between bad and laughable. People argue that it's early access or alpha so graphics shouldn't be considered. I think those people are wrong as i've been a part of a ton of alpha's and early access games where the grahpics showed promise. What i'm looking at is certainly not representative of the final product but it is representative of the art teams talent. In this case i'd say the art team is not talented.

The UI consists of a ton of menu diving. Little boxes with tabs that extend out of site. I'm forced to open little windows and click a little arrow key to get to the tab I need which consumes quite a bit of
time. These information menu's are things that you need to access constantly. It becomes annoying and adds to the tediousness of this game. Keep in mind that i'm a 10 year Eve vet. People jokingly refer to Eve as world of spreadsheets"... so I can deal with data. I imagine that these things will be refined over time.

The minimap is a tiny little circle that shows little detail in the terrain. NPC's
hoursPlayed:
quest items are little tiny dots. They are everywhere and it needs a lot of improving. In all honesty it should be scrapped. Around the minimap you have little yellow arrows that tell you which directions to go for quests you have. Only problem is that they blend in with the terrain or with some of the icons around
the minimap so you can't even see them. Literally they disappear. I expect this is something that will be changed shortly cause right now it's just a clusterf**k of dots.

The map itself is a little more useful. By pressing M you get a little map window
voteText: that's notexpandable

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'm certainly not very far into it, but so far it looks promising. It's a skill based advancement system, where you obtain skill points through missions or by using the skills. New skills are available by buying the books from NPCs. The crafting system looks deep
date:
which means complicated; but, much like in SWG(you're going to see that a lot), this is not needlessly so. Most gear will be crafted by other players, and the key elements for modifying stats are fittings, which are modular modifications that you put into your armor or weapons. The tutorial is raw, and consists of popping up a database page describing what to do. Read these. Once you finisht the tutorial you will have several skills and pieces of equipment for your future endeavors.

I have not gotten into too much of the main story missions, and I think you may need to build up some reputation before you get access to the lore. You do get missions in your mailbox regularly, and it is made clear in the tutorial that you don't have to do them all. Once I entered Freedomtown I received 4 messages with missions very quickly.

Graphics are alright for this level of development, of course they will be expected to improve after what is an Alpha.5 build. My biggest problem is that the client keeps crashing to desktop, and apparently this is an issue for many other players. It is not totally unexpected, but I WANT TO PLAY. WAH.

All that aside, I am looking forward to getting into the gathering and crafting. Finding some materials was not as difficult as in SWG, and once you find a node you have the option to enhance the node or the area to improve the quality of the materials you take. Also, various quality materials stack, so you can have F0 all the way up to A10 quality of a commodity all in one stack. Oh yes, you can break them up later. So yes, I think this will be a good one, all the proper elements are in place. Sometimes you just have to sack up, roll a hard 6, show up and see what happens. This should be pretty good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before you buy this game read the posative AND negative reviews.  I would not say this game is for everyone, but if it is for you, you'll love it.

The way they go about skills is unique to modern MMO's. You can be a melee'r with a sheild who stealths gets some distance pull a gun out and blast on your enemys from afar if you so wish. Or maybe you want to be a healer who buffs has a sheild with 3 pets defending you and heck, why not throw in the stealth skill while you're at it. (I like stealth) Maybe you just want to dance and talk in chat, the choice is yours. Mix and match as you please. The map is big and they keep adding more areas and points of interest. There are 3 ways to sell or buy items involving other players. 1.) Player venders 2.) Work orders 3.) Auction House. These 3 ways leave an opening to become a master of the economy if you want to. Crafting is deep to say the least but I'm not much of a crafter so I won't get into that but every item you can use is made by other players, if it's high quality. The community is helpful most of the time, people want the community to learn the game and keep playing it.  The armors are shells meaning you can wear what you want and put fitting in them to increase your stats, same with the guns. If you find a look you like keep it as long as you like just change the fittings in and out. There's player citys and in later updates seige warfare (seigeing has been disabled for now) and remeber player citys have peices made by other players as well as the seige weapons. Mastering skills can take some time so don't expect to jump in and be the master of stealth, healing, entertaining, construction, harvesting, buffing, animal handling, robotics, combat and more. It's best to pick a few that complement each other and level them. Heck even vehicle handling is a skill.  There are 73 skills (give or take) listed on their website[therepopulation.com] and one that isn't (that I know of) spirital arts. All 73 skills are broken up into 6 categories. Like I said mix and match.

I play this game on a 4 year old laptop with an onboard graphics chipset. My CPU runs at 1.3ghz duel core. So when this game goes F2P expect alot of people to at the very least try it.  Although Be Warned! This game plans to do a server wipe once it is released. If you don't like the sound of that, just wait for it's release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has steadily (about once every 2 months there is a large patch.)  been making great progress ever sense initial alpha 1.   Alot of people call it vapor ware" but it is a smaller stuido making a very complex and interesting game.   Bottom line this is an alpha but its in great condition for an alpha.  It does have bugs yes but the core features are implemented and there is plenty to keep anyone busy.

Is this game for you? Maybe maybe not.  This is the true spiritual successor to SWG.  The crafting system is the most complex and challenging (in a good way) crafting system ive ever seen in an MMO.  It is also the most rewarding crafting system due to this.  When you actually accomplish producing something you feel as if you have accomplished a great task.

This is also a sandbox no hand holding here folks.  It does have a basic tutorial to get you introduced to the game but after that you better be able to tell your on tale and make goals on your own as to what you want to do.

Overall 8/10 right now due to alpha i will hold my 10/10 for release.  Would have paid more to play it and been perfectly happy."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Initial Review:

I will keep this brief, but add to it as I play. I have completed the initial tutorial for the game and am starting to progress through my chosen craft. Generally I prefer crafting, but do enjoy combat from time to time, so I went with Genetic Engineer. I supply my own Tissue and DNA samples which you get from harvesting animals, which need to be dead. I have dabbled into some of the other crafts and have quickly realized how intense the crafting in this game really is. It is very difficult to become your own supplier.

For instance, I can buy sterilizing agents(agent A), but I decide to craft them, so I determine which profession makes them. Turns out several, so I pick Chemistry, to make agent A, I need another item made with chemistry(agent B), as well as a raw resource, and an Acid(Agent C). So I go to make Agent B and find it requires another Raw resources and another agent from another skill(Agent D). For Agent C I need another craft skill, foraging, so I pick that up to find that I need a raw resource and more of Agent B. To make agent D I need A Raw resource, and who knows what else, so I just buy it. So to make a simple item, needed to make anything else in Genetic Engineering, I need 4 different raw materials, and 5 different crafting sessions, and that is with buying one refined item, which I need twice. I may still be missing a step, but to get those 4 different Raw materials, I need Foraging, Survival, Mining. I would also need a combat skill to be able to kill the creatures for some of those items. I guess if I wanted to keep it brief, I should not have mentioned the crafting system.

That said, it is a very well done system and it is exciting to see your work progress. I am ten hours in and have forgotten that there was no class selection, and the world feels very free and open, a much better feel for an mmo in my opinion. However, its not all sunshine and rainbows either. There are glitches, random crashes, graphical anomolies and everything else you would expect to find in a game. I have not knowingly joined a group(more on that later) or participated in PVP so I cannot speak on game balance. That said, it is definately worth the money, just remember you are basically buying a product that is still in Alpha. You are helping a startup to fund a brilliant idea and they almost always have a GM on to answer questions or help with bugs, which shows their commitment to making this game a success.

I am still listing it as a con because it is hard to find but here is some good information for new players. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=362788661

- Pros -
Amazing crafting system
Enjoyable combat
Good Tutorial
Great Trade System
Complex Skill Tree
GM Support

- Cons -
Learning Curve (A manual would be nice, especially for the UI)
Auto Group (realized I was in a group for the first time yesterday)
Glitches (expected but a con none the less)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really enjoy the hardcore aspect of this game. There really is no easy button for progression. Whether you decide to craft or skill up your combat, you will have to work at it. Crafting is super hardcore, so start off slow and work on making lower tier sub-sub items at a higher quality. Then focus on a more specific task.

Not exactly the same housing experience as in Star Wars Galaxies, but it's a great start in the right direction. Plenty of sandbox space to roam around and enjoy.

Overall, I love the game and would recommend it to anyone that remembers how to play a challenging MMO.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I never got the chance to play early SWG, but hearing about and seeing how detailed and in depth it used to be, I've been looking for something that might meet up to that standard. I've tried a few now, but have always been disappointed.

Where do I start with TR? Well, I am optimistic that this game could develop into something special. That said, I've been burned enough by games to avoid being just a blind fanboi, so here's a few good and bad aspects as of right now:

The Bad

1. Laggy and buggy, but not game breakingly so. It is an alpha, so that kind of comes with the territory.
2. Steep learning curve. And I mean steep. Did I say steep?
3. Tutorial was halfway helpful - probably just let chars learn all skills (particularly combat) without cost and then decide where they want to specialise. Aside from that, it was okay.
4. Landscapes are kind of same-ey. Perhaps it's the colour palate?That said, I've not yet had the time to explore all that much of the map, so I could just be talking out of my ar$e.
5. UI and pop ups all kind of blend into the same sapphiric miasma of eye-rapery. But since I still enjoy playing EVE Spreadsheets, this ain't too bad, I guess.
6. The AH is a little confusing. I'm the first to acknowledge that I may have some sort of mild mental retardation when it comes to numbers, but I also shouldn't need an economics degree just to sell a vial of D3 alien goo. I think my anu$ leaked the first time I tried to use the AH. Ana.l leakage is a thing. If you don't believe me, look it up...at work. Or just try to use the AH. Ladies' choice.

The Good

1. Steep learning curve. Yup, this is also a good thing, because learning and building a char through trial and error is what invests us in the game. Goals, people, goals. Just go watch some how-to-play vids, and stop whining about difficulty...it's noooot a tumor!
2. Skills. There's a lot of 'em. (In case you didn't pick up on it, I was understating. See what I did there?).
3. Teaming up is a good thing. From doing public missions to sharing mats and products, being social will be essential here; while there'll be plenty of loner content to keep us Unabomber types clicking away until the early hours. Brrrr, my shed feels drafty.
4. Devs have explicitly said this baby will never be P2W. Of course, that's what those f*cktards at Sony said about H1Z1 and see what happened there.....Smedleeeeeeeeeeey!!! Yet, I'm still hopeful with TR, because...
5. Devs are helpful and responsive and obviously care about their baby.
6. So much to do. If you're a blood thirsty, psychopathic monster, there's murderin' to do. If you're a carebare, hippy softc*ck, then maybe you can sit in the corner and be all crafty and sh*t.  I might even stroke your hair and coo gently.

The Ugly

1. Character creation, although in depth, more often than not results in an unflattering outcome. So I'm one of those creepy dudes who likes to make female characters. Something to look at, right? And I try pretty hard to make them at least look partway bone-able, yeah? You feelin' me, Dog? But here....dayum! The current TR character graphics really, completely take away all of my horny. Fix that sh*t.

Seriously, though, this one looks like it could be a good, even great, game. And if you're thinking about it, the advantage of getting in now is two-fold: you'll be an early part of, and co-conspirator to, a potentially great game (which you can then brag about in dulcet nerd-superior tones a few years from now), and you'll also to learn how it all works so you can dominate on release.

Happy gaming, sentient space beings.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite what a lot of people are saying the game is not dead, development is still on going! The devs are simply being cautious, they have to make sure that none of the funds they have go to waste.

They have already begun work on porting the game over to Unreal Engine, which is why we are getting Fragmented. They are going to use it as a bed to build the UE Repopulation off of, and are going to use the funds generated by Fragmented to keep development going. This does mean that it's going to be a while longer before the game finaly finished though. In the mean time we have another game which is FREE to those who have already purchased The Repopulation.

All in all the devs have been very open with the comunity about whats going on, and i feel that they are making the right decision going foward. The game is not dead at all, it's just going through a rough spot, but i feel porting over to Unreal Engine is going to be a positive for the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Did you like Vanguard's crafting system?  You'll find that here.

Did you like many of the abilities from SWG?  You'll find that here.

Do you like crafting to help others?  You'll find that here.

Nice and easy tutorial?  You'll find that here.

And overall, some fun quests and public ones everyone in  the area can join?  This game is for you!

The Repopulation blends a lot from other games that are now gone and fuses them together into a very interesting experience.  Definately worth spending 19.99$ to help the developers.

Or a diplomat.  Or a roboticist.  The sheer number of skills

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAlpha is Alpha is Alpha but I really like where they're going with this. Game's a bit clunky and the graphics leave a bit to be desired at the moment but overall pretty damned good for an alpha. That said the game's really pushing for the whole SWG / retro MMO / sandboxy feel and I like that a lot.... right down to entertainer buffs and so on. I'm doing my best to avoid playing the alpha test much (my best in that regard isn't very good) to save it for release but what I've seen so far impresses me. Glad I purchased, glad to support what looks like a wonderful game in the making.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

3 hours into the game and I'm absolutely loving the amount of detail put in the most simple tasks/jobs and just the depth and complexity of it all. There's a huge list of things you can level up, from swimming to thievery to stealth to more tanky focussed stuff to abilities which require concentration (it's literally too much to name, I have never seen such a vast list of usefull skills)

My first 3 hours in the game:
The first hour I spent just wandering around the tutorial area, trying to get the hangs of the controls and menu's, exploring the place.
Second hour was spent doing jobs and leveling up skills like hand gun handling and trap removing.

Then I went outside and killed a few robots but one almost killed me so I want back inside and coincidentially into a bar which replenishes your health. Appparently if you set up camp and there's 'entertainment' you heal faster (absolutely love this mechanic, no health potion or whatever but just rest and entertain oneself which actually makes sense too).
But so in this bar there was a dancer and I could talk to her, so of course that's what I did.

She asked me to dance but my guy said he couldn't, but don't worry folks, even this is handled in the greatest detail, because the dancer replied with 'don't worry! I've got a training card which will teach you some moves.' and before I knew it my guy was dancing his socks off!

Love this kind of detail in games. So far I've spent all my time in the tutorial area of the game. Honestly I've never spent so much time in the tutorial, but in this case I really needed it and I absolutely recommend you to stay there for a while too. At least until you've talked to every NPC or did every job/quest.

Loving the art style. It reminds me somewhat of the Deus Ex HD version. Controls could use a bit more smoothness or responsiveness imo, and the 1st person part could also use some work. In 1st person the camera just floats above your character's head and it's just not 'true' 1st person yet imo but it's more than good enough for an Alpha.

TL:DR: very detailed game, A LOT of DEPTH to nearly everything you can do in it, it's rough around the edges but hey what do you expect, it has it's own style and runs good enough imo (i5 4670 stock with gtx 670 2gb & 8 gb ram at around 40-50 fps). If the devs can keep the updates coming and put in the stuff on the roadmap, this game is gonna be  legendary,
voteText: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Repopulation is an open world, sci-fi sandbox game currently in early access that has continual updates and a helpful community. As of now the game is coming along nicely, the crafting is complicated and fullfilling and while in need of some UI streaming it hits the nail on the head for those who enjoy carving their mark on a player driven econony. Combat is fluid (as long as there is no lag) and feels smooth with practice, there will still be moments when you are killed outright by a mob and dont quite understand why your new weapon is not working as you expected untill you realise you didnt upgrade it or that mob type has resistances to your damage type.

While this game is easy to pickup, it is also quite complicated and has a medium/high learning curve. It can be daunting starting out with no real clear goal until you find your stride and decide what you want to be and achieve. As of now the population is low due to alpha character wipes that will occur in the not too distant future so it is a great time to jump in and learn how things work.

There are bugs and moments of lag that will be ironed out in the coming months no doubt by the dedicated developers, so just realise this when you jump in and something strange happens out of the ordinary. Players looking for an MMO that combines dedication to a server run economy who are looking for a deeper experience may enjoy this game very much but be aware, lots of reading on how things work is definately recommended before hand, check out some wikis and player made videos to brush up on the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So basically welcome to a game that has a far way to go but is quite enjoyible allready in its current state, lots of things are missing or not intended to be in the game but as you all know this is early access.

Ive once played a game we all loved SWG the god of making normal mmo feal like dead fish, this can become the new game like this.

Game has a solid noob area where you basically run around and learn the basics of the game like how to move,how to dance,roll hell even play with the pet options and have a pet for a few minutes, The bottom line here is its a great start but it lacks voice over's this to me is anoying cause the game can feal very alive at times and then all of a sudden turn into a turn pager of text after text but hey never been a huge fan of reading.

Game has a long way to go to be good or even ok for today's standards, the UI ingame is well uggly and feals i dont know welcome back to the year 2000 but its early access.

Good:
1. Good Ava maker in the beginning you can look like gollums cusin if you want.
2. Good start off with 2 excellent starting locations for old and and new players
3. Awsome looking droids (yepp they are awsome)
4. fun quest system talk to npc's or answer the mail and voila your questing
5. Story telling and dancing, yes rejoice the old swg buffing system is in the making
6. Even doh the game needs some huge grafical improvements i can see where the nature in this game is going looking great but hell need more life.
7. funny old aspects back ingame type in name of whom your looking for if this will include players with bounties later on it will be a winner.
8. No class or level system just epic grind of who is the best well anything, meaning you can learn and master all i guess (Or is this false? time will tell)
9. Mounts and taming yea baby!
10. Cycles yepp npc's work sleep and leave the shops closed, guess this will be excellent for a thief.

BAD:
1. Voices missing. sorry npc need voice i suggest looking for voice makers stat since if these npc dont get voices they will always feel dead, this is mainly the quest givers im talking about. I meet a talking droid doh good! thats what we want.
2. Jellyfish jump, make a male character and watch that jumping animation and laugh your  off (Again early access lol)
3. UI it has been some times since ive seen something so basic in a game, sorry you need to fix this menu's and all look like its the last survivor of the cold war.
4. Engine im worried that game is intended to look this way when its done, the visiuals needs a big update, lightning ect hell game look like its a shell at times.
5. combat.. ok love the fact with change weapons and go pew pew again animations from hell and lol when i fire a gun i expect it to do a little more then just spew balls of lights but hell again visuals.

Im ghonna add more points the longer i test this game and try to update as it it all comes together.
I strongly suggest you look at the streams,Screenshots and so found by players because some of the visuals in the trailer is not how it looks ingame.

Over all this is a great early access, alot to do ingame and its a good time to get in and answer a poll every quest or so to help the development, if its worth the current price tag even on sale, tbh im not certain should be lower its a hefty sum for a unfinished game.

6/10 Pro score.
With better visuals,voice overs,new ui and improvements (jesus kill the jellyfish please) the game will prolly be a 9/10
with hopes of continuesly updated content and not a Faceplant death SWG did damn you sony. it will be a 10/10

Hope this was helpful
Enjoy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Have spent 6+  months playing this game)

This game is a true revival of the sandbox MMORPG's we gamers knew and loved. I have spent extensive time testing this game out and I have to say that it is time not wasted. It provides a game style that allows you the player to decide what you want to do rather than some game dev saying you have to go down this specific line because you selected the warrior class (example... not real class).

This game allows you the player to decide what you want and what you dont want.

This game has everything. An in-depth crafting system that rivals SWG. It has PvP and city sieges. And of course it has PvE content that is ever growing and acts in a fluidly with the current environment that is in game.

Heavily recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only played this game for a few hours but almost immediately after creating my character, I was delighted to get an old but distinct vibe from it that I hadn't experienced since SWG, that same feeling of a world full of possibilities being completely open to me and while it is not from the Star Wars universe in this case, I can completely forgive that.

Since I know there is going to be one wipe before launch, I'm not really playing it balls to the wall, but just enough to get my bearings so that when it does launch, I'll be ready to know exactly what I have to do to get established.   From what I've seen so far, it has all the hallmarks of SWG with an incredibly robust crafting system that's ginormous with skills like genetic engineering, tailoring, fishing, culinary, robotics, cybernetics, animal handling, vehicles, etc  just to name a few. Supposedly you'll be able to play a fully enjoyable, noncombat character or you will also be able to experience the delights of a hardcore server gankathon that's never been seen before (the hardcore servers are not yet implemented but it's on the horizon, so I've heard).

Since I haven't ventured very far out of the training facility I can't really comment on player cities but such a thing is possible in contested and non-contested areas from what I've heard.   And for anyone who isn't as gungho about PVP for their gaming experience like me, the non-contested areas per your faction are supposedly very expansive so there will be no real need to venture out into contested areas unless you wish to.

All I know is that no other MMO has even come close to giving me the feeling that I once had when playing SWG  and even though I know I'll never be able to bring back my beloved Zabrak creature handler from SWG, it feels so damn good to play a game that gives me the same possibilities I once had back in the day.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After a very long time searching for a game I can play daily I do believe I have found it.

Combat is challenging but not overwhelming.
Instead of changing weapons every time you make a few levels you can refine what you have, same with armor.
Most styles of combat are supported from melee to long range sniping.

Crafting has a depth I have been missing in most MMO style games.
The shear number of items it is possible to craft is huge, best to specialize when starting out.
Materials can be selectively gathered, it's not the slot-machine randomness that seems popular of late, but you will have to work to get the quality you want.

Transportation is not difficult to acquire fairly early on as there are lots of generated missions to earn some money (and skills) from.

And finding those missions is not a problem, just check you mail, and don't worry about getting one you can't do yet, if it's in your mail you have the skills to do it now, super sweet system.

The game may be in Alpha right now but it's as stable and playable as a number of long running games I have been trying to play during my search. And as for content, it may be a bit light yet but it holds so much promises I can hardly wait to see what is added next.

With the great community large areas to challenge you it's a definite must check out game (but I may be a bit bias).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the time of writing this I have put in 266 hours into the game and still feel I've barely touched half of it.

This game is not for everyone! If you want your hand held and guided through your game, don't bother.

If youre looking for a in depth game that rewards those willing to put in effort and work at something, be it combat, crafting, exploring, dancing in a bar whatever floats your boat. This is it.

While the game is Alpha at this stage with plenty of bugs and unfinished features its still more fun than any MMO I've played in years.  The Development team is the best I've seen in forever, the type I never thought I'd see again in this age of Early Access and Pay to Test.  Devs are on the forums actively responding to feedback, asking for information and actually listening to the community.  There are GMs online in shifts to trouble shoot issues and help gather documentation for the development team.  Really its something else.

The game itself is complex. So complex one could get a panic attack just looking at the crafting of something as simple as a combat knife.  It takes some effort but all the tools are there and the community is excellent even for an Alpha group.  So its hard to go too in depth in a review about any feature without writing up a huge section so Ill leave it with general statements.  There is ton of information on the site and forums if youre interested in more details.

Everything they advertise about the game is there and then some. It may not be fully fleshed out but the bare bones are there and one can get a clear idea of what the finished product will be.  Its not like so many early access games, Ive tried my fair share, that boost all these things they want then when you get in they have two or three things kinda working sorta and tons of features nowhere even on the horizon.   Repopulation at this stage has at least a skeleton of every major feature in place that I have looked into.  It needs a lot of fleshing out but it gives you a good idea of what they plan and that they are actually working to produce what they promise.

Updates are common, It seems they have slowed down to about one a month.  Slowed down to what most people consider the normal rate and many times faster than what I have come to expect from Early Access games.  But dont let that make you think its just some tiny little fix a few bugs patch.  The notes are huge. Tons of changes, bug fixes, balancing and fleshing out content in amounts that are staggering.  Again, this isnt something we should be so shocked or awed about as it should be the norm.  But again we live in the early access era.  Final note on the patches, I dont remember the last game I was as excited about patches as I am with this one.  They put up patch notes as soon as they release the current patch and add finished features ready for the next patch as it goes along.  Really nice to have a Dev team that isnt Vague on what they are working on.

If you do buy in know its not all peaches and cream.  There are bugs a plenty, crashes happen but the game is more stable than many released ones Ive played recently.  Its not optimized so at times it can be laggy, I have a pretty good rig so dont notice it much.  Mostly when opening certain menus or entering a new zone.

Combat is better than I thought but still needs tons of balancing and is fairly simple.  There is a system in place for stuff like this attack causes this debuff so you use this one to trigger this debuff ect thats pretty decent but the fights are either really easy or really hard.  There are some open world dungeons in place to give you a feel for what they plan and it works rather well.  But it still has a long way to go.  It is kind of complex in the mixing of different armors and weapons combined with the flexibility of the fitting system to the point there is no best build as all will work well used right.

Crafting is amazing. Its why I first came here and I am not disappointed. It still needs some tweaks but its the first game in a long while where crafting wasnt just important but the back bone of the game.

If youre like me youve been burned by the Early Access so many times youd rather walk into traffic than try it again.
This is the first one Ive ever been truly happy with making my purchase and I wish I had started up sooner than later.

The last thing I can say is out of all the games Ive played on Steam over the years, this is the only one I was willing to take my precious game time to sit down and write a review for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the moment, The Repopulation is still young, but already displays great potential. This is an sandbox MMORPG, which means that you are in control of what you do, you choose what you want to do and when to do it, this type of game wont hold your hand and guide you through each area it has so you experience everything it has to offer.

The Repopulation teaches you the basics and then drops you into a world of countless possibilities, free to do as you wish. Quests, NPCs, PVP, PVE, etc. its all there but you choose to follow them if you so desire.

What struck me as the most unique however were the skill system and the crafting system. Skills increase as you use them, and the crafting is incredibly complex but never frustrating.

The game will be F2P on release, the early access only gives you immediate access to the game, but progress will be erased before release in order to prevent early access players from dominating the game, and a lot of perks that will carry over.



TL;DR: Its a good game with no specifically defined goals, you can do whatever you want. Itll be F2P, but buying early access will grant perks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best alpha I have ever tested. It is a true sandbox MMORPG that doesn't hold your hand and allows me to do whatever I want whenever I want. The crafting is very complex to learn at first but vry rewarding once you do and work to become a grandmaster in on specific area to make better quality than someone who tries to do it all by themself.

I can go from gathering a resource and obtaining knowledge of that species to make it better with enhancing or I can turn right around and kill npc creatures to become more effective with my weapon type I chose as well as become more efficient at killing that specific species as I gain knowledge of it.

The game community as a whole is awesome and the fact that the developers and founders of the game have a passion as it shows on their massive dedication to fixing bugs and keeping us informed of theior progress. Each patch adds more balance and features and the bug fix list is usually large and not vague info.  Support for such a small team is fast. They also love hearing our feedback and will respond as well. If you give a valid enough reason as to why something should be altered or added, wou might just change the game as they are open to us, the players, on the forums and in game.

The upcoming improvements on building Nation cities is going to be astounding! Underground levels!!

The world so far is vast and looking at the overall map you can see where they will be able to expand on it just within this planet setting....It takes 4+ hours to traverse from point A to point B on the fastest vehicle available.

I find myself mesmerized in the game even with the current graphics knowing it is still in Alpha and reminds me of the countless hours I would spend playing Star Wars Galaxies back in the day knowing that there is so much more planned for this game from a team that cares.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: i am still early in the game.
the repopulation is a game that mixes a traditional mmo with a survival game. but free by the bonds of hunger and thirst.
in the game you will choose a nation, OWON (red uniforms, with a slightly socially darwinist ideology) and FPR (insurgents with kaki armor and a present-day ideology and ethics) and you will be in a subnation (guild) wich has cities and strongholds. the good thing about this game is that there is no forced grinding. want to ice some bandits while you should be mining? why not! want to spend 2 hours chatting? no problema amigo! the game also features one time pets (robots) or permanent pets (creatures) that die if not fed, mounts and vehicles (bikes, 2 seat cars and siege mechs)
that said, the game doesnt hold your hand a lot. you can bang against the same wall (intended as a methaphorical problem) and then realize it. it is alpha, there are bugs. PvP is completely facultative.
the gampelay is focused on crafting, and everyone has a place in the community. i am, for example, a dyemaker. i get chemicals for refining form chemists and sell my items to poeple who want dyes and structure builders.
rating:
graphics: 7/10
gameplay: 8/10
variety of content: 9/10
longevity: 9/10
total: 8.25

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A wonderful sandbox. Free to skill, to do, to craft, to go, to farm, to steal, to build anything and everything you want. Belong to either of two opposing nations or found/join a rogue nation that battles both. Build player cities, build your own house (either instanced or in the open world). Ride hover-bikes. Build hover-bikes. Drop your harvesters somewhere and have them farm mats for you, while you log for the night.

The edges are still rough. It's pre-beta. But it's very playable and the bugs are actually more funny than disturbing.
A diamond in the making.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Get this game!!

Well if you don't mind dealing with a few bugs and other issues whilst it is still under construction. Otherwise once it is completed and live be sure to play it!!

It is well worth the $40 and then some for anyone who is a fan of sand box MMO's.

For starters when you get in there you feel like a complete noob again who has to learn everything to play it. This was the first appeal to me as it has been a very long time since I felt like a noob in any game!

There are hiccups, features not implimented yet ( Aesthitics for one as character animations aren't fully implimented yet ).
There are area's that are incomplete at this stage. It is a work in progress.

The devs are extremly pasionate about this game. They are very active both in game and out answering questions left right and centre! They are right there to help you with any problems you are having. I have never ever seen a game before with Devs this active.

The crafting game is so extensive that I still haven't really got my head around it but I'm working on it!

You can be whatever you want to be, run errand missions for cash instead of combat if you wish.

It is not quest driven in the usual sense ( you are given jobs  you can choose to do or not to do ). Your hand is not held, you have to figure out what  you want to do next.

Amazing game so far with so much potential.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLet me start out by saying this game was DEEP. I won't go into incredible detail because if you've made it this far you know how to read and if you've found this game interesting enough to look at the reviews you probably already have an idea what this game was like. The developers tried really hard to revive an old dead game that already had a few years behind it but they made the fatal flaw of using a bad engine to build their game on and it caused some things to fall apart. Sadly that is a sad occurrence that happens to a lot of indie developers. Luckily the devs realized what the problem was and have since decided to drop the whole make sandbox MMO's great again" campaign and have gone for something more attainable. They are now switching to the Unreal Engine and from there
date: who knows? Maybe we will get a great game out of it. If you read the other reviews on here you will see that this game had a dedicated player base and the devs really tried hard to make the community happy. I want to see this game succeed because we just don't have very many good sandbox games out there anymore. You may want to wait for the devs to release some version of their new game before buying this game but I definitely recommend getting it at some point. Let's keep the dream alive!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review will not be unique from most that have been recently added.  But since I'm reinstalling the client, and waiting for resolution of a technical support ticket which has rendered my 33hr.-old character a scripting casualty, it seems I have time to write a review.
Having said that, in spite of all the alpha glitches, I like this game and think it has a lot of potential.  I like things that challenge my mind.  I become easily bored with the run-of-the-mill mindless stim and click garden variety mmorpgs that your average sheeple might be satisfied with.  I'll tolerate this being rough around the edges, because I can get a real sense of accomplishment from not getting a trip back to the cloning vat after vanquishing a relatively low level hostile.   In other words, the game is difficult; and therein lies the reward.  In the same 33hrs, I had a GW2 character 2/3 of the way to max level.  Here, I'm just happy to be getting better purified water at the crafting table.
One big thing that this game needs and will need if it is to survive in its current vision, is plenty of players and participation.  So, to that end, I'm encouraging folks to give it a try.  I have great hope for this product's end-game RvR potential, and I don't think I am going to run out of things to discover or do in this game envirenment anytime soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This MMO isn't like WoW at all. If you've never played Star Wars Galaxies then be ready for a grindfest. If you find that you'd like an MMO that's (a lot more) in depth then this game will eat your time like when you take your cell phone into the bathroom when you take a dump.
So far I've found the community, in game, to be more than helpful to where you ask a question and you won't get -ish answers. Very few people spamming their wares in general chat (will change over time) makes it nice to see when I skill-up in a trade.
The mission system can be a little annoying at times. You get missions randomly over time or when you're out killing mobs and one will appear giving you the option to be rewarded off further kills of said mob.
The only real annoyances I have with the game right now interface screens. If you have your mouse buttons held down (while you're moving) and go into an interface screen, when you exit out of it your camera and/or movement will suddenly change.
Also a small tidbit: The game has map rotation with no North indicator. Though you may find this to be silly at first but when you're trying to find your way in a city and bring up your map then close it unless you use a building as a temp heading you will find yourself getting lost very easily.

Overall I find this game to be real enjoyable even in its early dev stages!

6/10 - Unfinished games never get a rating over 6 due to the fact that it's still unfinished, but from what's playable right now I'd give that a 9/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overall a great game. Remember that at the time of this review, it is still in alpha. They are starting to impliment the changes to the system designed for launch. Some of these changes are frustrating as the current population is not very high. You must look long term. Think about how the game will change when there are enough people to fill the auction house, place good solid work orders, and fight over resources. So before you slam a change made because it complicates things, think about how this will feel with 4-5X as many players per server.  Aslo keep in mind that a server whipe, merger, or refit could come without notice, so dont get attached to your toon.

If you are thinking about playing this game at launch, you will want to jump in now and take a look around. The crafting system is super detailed and intense. The combat system is unique, and play style is completely different for each weapon and armor mix. Healers are still being give some polish, so if that is your thing come in now and help give some feedback.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes there are a few bugs here and there, but they're by no means, game breakers. But it is an early access game, so it's to be expected. The fps mode could do with some tweaking too, but is fun to use, if like me, you don't like toolbar button spamming mmorpg's.

A very fun and unrestricted mmorpg, with 1 hell of a crazy indepth crafting system. You're not limited by a leveling system where you have to place points in certain stats. You level what you want to level up, by doing what you want to do. The crafting sytems is by far the most indepth and complex of any game I have played, so crafters should be in their element with this 1. The comunity is very helpful too, so it's easy to get assistance.

Overall a good game.

EDIT : This game is no longer being made.....for now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all just like the old SWG days, I am finding myself becoming addicted. Having said that, this is Alpha and as expected it is rough, clunky and buggy. However the foundation is set and the game mechanics have huge potential for solid old school sandbox goodness.
I played SWG -Pre-CU through the NGE and have to say this game is giving me that old school sandbox feeling. I feel like there is so much to learn and skills to improve upon. I have that feeling of a lost person waking up in a new world just like when I first logged into SWG, not a hero, not the center of the universe, it's just a day in the life of...whatever and whoever I decide to be.
Please remember the game is in Alpha and it can be a rough experience. If you can except that and want to contribute to the games direction, its a fun game and has great potential. It may always be a niche game just as SWG was always somewhat a niche game
The graphics are not spectacular, the UI is buggy, and it is easy to get lost and not know what to do which is a good thing. Pro Tip: patience pays off in sandbox MMOs. The overall game play is headed in the right direction; it just is lacking the polish that comes later on in development. I am hoping this game succeeds in what so many post SWG MMOs failed to do.provide a new long term home.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Been waiting for this game ever since I heard it could potentially be a replacement for Star Wars Galaxies when it shut down. Seeing as how it's inspired by and borrows features from SWG, I would say that's true. The tutorial throws a ton of information at you at once, so if you think you can just fly through it your first time, you're going to be clueless once you're in the actual game world. I actually scraped my first character (which I completely rushed) and took my time with creation and the tutorial the second time around. The result was a much more stable and enjoyable experience, even though the game is in Early Access. I'm definitely going to be sticking around on this game.

Gameplay: 8 ~ The Repopulation is an incredibly vast and detailed game, but with detail comes complexity. If you have enough self-control to take the time necessary to learn all of the game's mechanics in the tutorial, you'll have an enjoyable experience. It does feel a little stale in terms of combat, but that's an easy thing to overlook if you're having fun.

Graphics: 8 ~ Lighting effects is where this game really shines (literally.) Though everything does have a sort of stylized-realism, (that is to say, mildly cartoony instead of Battlefield/CoD lifelike) it fits the overall feel of the game well, and I have no personal complaints.

Sound: 8 ~ Continuing with my theme of It's quite good
