reviewText:
Early Access Review

Though I haven't played very long at the time of typing up this review and still have yet to try the PvP system not to mention that it is an early access game which is in alpha too so theres still yet to be more content I still think the core game is brilliant and theres plenty of stuff to keep you busy for hours on end.

The game is a throwback to the golden days of MMOs such as Ultima Online and Starwars Galaxies before EA got their hands on them and tried to make them a quick cash in on WoWs success and alienating their fans which drove away the communities basically killing the game but I digress. If youre familiar with the games I am referring to you will know that this game isnt easy to get into but once you do it is a very rewarding game.
To the people who arent familiar with Ultima Online or Starwars Galaxies the best way to sum this game up is a Sandbox Social MMO. There are social skills such as dancing and storytelling which arent just useless emotes as these offer buffs to people around them as if youve raised their moral. There is a huge amount of crafting skills which you learn from NPCs or other players via these cards which can be obtained. There is a huge amount of weapons and armours which you can swap out, mix and match depending on your play style and how you want to be known. Those are just a few elements of the game to scrape the surface and a lot more that I cant list because I would be here forever e.g. taming/pets, genetic engineering, vehicle customisation etc. Highly recommended if you want a classic MMO that isnt just a generic WoW rip like 90% of the current MMO market.

Also no subscription so once you pay for the game you're good to go.  If I am to critique aspects of it then they would have to be the graphics as its not the best game to look at and the fact its very grindy if youre wanting to raise one specific skill but Ive never been too bothered by graphics and the grind is to be expected with this genre of game. It's also extremly glitchy but that's to be expected with Alpha. Honestly if you're looking into getting this game i highly suggest waiting for Beta release.

The developers are really passionate and work really hard.  It's amazing to see what they can get done in two weeks.  They regularly change their patch cycle and always make great additions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I took a chance by buying an Early Access game, but I didn't get burned. I would say it was more like going to sleep in a cool room with a heavy blanket on, only the room tempature increased during the night making me wake up in hot sweats, although I am too half asleep to have the cognition to take the damn blanket off.

It has some great features, and I see a lot of potential in the game seeing as there aren't a lot of sci fi MMO's aside from SWTOR, and let's just be honest, that was just a bag of angry bagders.

I felt uncomfortable whilst playing this title, because I enjoying the theme, but the gameplay was a little generic. I suppose even if it comes to fruition that this game releases, that won't change. Although it is refreshing to not have a leveling or class system.

The crafting system is by far the most intriguing thing about this game, so if you are expecting this game to bring you flashy pew pew lasers to the face until you are in your computer chair blind and having seizues, you are not going to like this title in my opinion. I have played games of its ilk, and the battle just doesn't cut it, but the rest of the game is quite in depth. The skill system is innovative, and the design and theme are pretty solid. I can't say that the graphics impressed me, and it surprised me that I had a low FPS. The graphics aren't bad, but I think because of the early access, a lot of the textures aren't quite rendered correctly.

There were bugs, and the game crashed on me, but it is still early access, so I am not surprised at that, however with the amount of flaws that I did see in the design, I have a premonition that the errors won't be so easily fixed, and they will continue to be a nuisance far beyond the launch date, and with a small team of entrepeneurs at the helm, I am not so sure that the repairs will be quick.

As a gamer I say to this company... GREAT JOB guys trying to innovate!!! Great idea, but lacking in application. Don't be too discouraged, because that is just the norm for developers who create MMO's in today's market. Usually the budget is too low in most cases, and the teams are quite small. I am quite sure that this game is on kickstarter, and I am all about supporting the independent gaming community. So, I would recommend this title, but I would wait until launch day if you aren't in favor of supporting the company. I assume the majority of my beefs with the game will be squashed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing MMOs since sometime around 2000 when my brother got me into Ever Quest. Since then I have been playing every MMO I can get my hands on from City of Heroes and World of Warcraft to EvE Online you name it I have probably played it. The best one I ever played was a little game called Star Wars: Galaxies. It was a massive open world game that allowed you to play how you wanted, as a Dancer who heals and buffs people before battle to a lonely crafter who makes the galaxies best weapons all in the iconic setting of Star Wars. It was not to long however that Sony Online Entertainment and Lucas Arts ruined the game. After its down fall I jumped from game to game looking for the what was lost.

I have found that lost greatness in a little company called Above and Beyond Technology the creators of The Repopulation, a Sci-Fi sandbox MMO taking place on a distant planet called Rhyldan that Humans landed on to rebuild their civilization.

In The Repopulation you can play as anyone or anything you can think of. Do you want to be the biggest meanest sword fighter on Rhyldan, or maybe you want to be a performer and help buff others before they leave for battle. You can open your own shop and craft items that are needed by others. How about a medic so you can join your friends in battle to keep them alive and well and maybe you can tame a few animals to accompany you in battle. This and so much more are possible in The Repopulation.

I would encourage everyone to try the game and give it a chance even when there is a lot to learn at first, once you do it will be well worth it.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This game is interesting.

The game has no generic leveling up system, Other than skills and crafting.
Gear means everything, which isn't that different to conventional MMOs.
Each thing you learn will have skills that are assigned to it.

I've been playing it for a couple of days.
Questing is randomised so you might get repetitive quests or new quests. They are optional and will give you money or skills.

The game is currently in Alpha which means there might be a reset soon so you might want to learn everything first.
Trust me you would want to play it. If you enjoyed Ultima or Starwars Galaxies.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lots of potential but not enough to make it worth buying into the earlier access yet if the cost is something you're worried about.  If you've got a few spare bucks, totally worth sinking some time into.

I'll be checking back if the game ever makes to to final release. At the moment the video/camera can bestuttery even on lower settings with a high end machine. You'll need to be able to support max settings for monster draw distance or else you'll often load in the middle of a camp only to be chain stunned to death.

Crafting currently, feels like it took the best of Vanguard's & SWG's perfectly complex crafting and enhanced it by adding even more item grades and levels within grades to the point it's just too much. It's like they were close to a great system but overdid it. There is a great in game database that links where every item is and where to get it, but unless you are the most hardcore crafter type, I feel this will be too much for you. You may also run into issues with space due to so many items and so many parts for crafting. This might work itself out as there are more players / crafters to take some of the burden off of making every part for yourself at this point.

Graphics and combat make the game almost feel like Anarchy Online 2 but 5 years too late. You'll find that you get hung up on the smallest blade of grass and get annoyed at landing your speeder (fast ground transport) in trees 1 in 5 trips.

Overall game play makes you come back for more but leaves you wondering why you are logged back in after an hour.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I used to be a Star Wars Galaxies veteran, I played it for years and I loved it.  So I heard of this new game coming out that was going to market to that mature, proud community of sandbox mmorpg gamers:  The Repopulation.  Immediately as I logged in I could feel that once again, I was in a living universe where I could become anything, and do anything I wanted to do.  It felt great and it's something I hadn't seen in a game in many years.

Course the game is currently in early access alpha, it has some issues with the UI and the sale tab of the AH is useable but it is kinda clunky at the moment, don't fear though this will all be fixed in due time.  Other than that, I am surprised to find that I have not seen many real bugs.  The UI of the sale tab is not even bugged it's just clunky lol it's surprisingly well polished for an early access game, even so even if it were really buggy, Star Wars Galaxies had some issues with bugs as all we SWG fans know but it didn't matter because the game was amazing.

All in all, if you're one of those people looking for that old sandbox freedom feeling of being able to do and become anything that you want.. I would highly recommend you try this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, after spending 6 hours in this game i could probably give my first impression of it.
When i was a kid and started getting more into computer games WoW had just come out and it was for sure the biggest thing around. I hopped on the hype train and had a blast, i still today play WoW and enjoy some aspects of it, but i never got to play games like Everquest, SWG, DAOC or Ultima Online during their prime years. But if they were anything like The Repopulation is, or at least hopefully will become when it's officialy realesed, then i can see why people miss those days.

Gone are the in depth tutorials telling you everything you need to know to speed rush through the game.
Gone are the classes that defines what you do.
Instead i have for the first time since i started playing WoW all those years ago felt lost in a new world, with new things to explore around every corner.

Sure, the game is very badly optimized right now and there are quiet a few things that needs to be fixed, so if you never ever would play an unfinished game, don't freaking buy this. But if you want to have a new adventure you only heard about from your older brother growing up, or if you wanna go back to those adventures you told your little brother about and don't care about a few bugs or lagspikes here and there. Buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Repopulation... Where to start?

This game I heared about before it went into a playable Alpha state. And, it intrigued me. It's an MMOSBRPG, or Massively Multiplayer Online Sandbox Role Playing Game (Long Abbreviations FTW!). And, here's my review of this.

Graphics: Current: 7.5/10 Future: ?/10: So, since this game is an alpha, I have to review what is given to me. And, it's pretty good, but I can't push the high quality, due to my machine not quite being able to play at max with a good framerate, though with the upgrades that I want to purchase, maybe then i'll be able to play at 144 FPS on Ultra for this game. The game looks nice, but the character animations are a bit lazy, but they will change with time. Oh, and Dual Wielding Pistols is really funky... You hold both pistols in the same physical location, leading to some funny clipping stuff.

Overall Gameplay: 9/10

Combat: 10/10: This game has such a unique combat system. It has one main governing system, the Openings System. If you shoot someone in the Leg, they are the suceptible to other things like maybe Bleeding, or if someone is Startled because of how close you got to them from a shot or slash, then maybe you can Dishearten them and make them deal less damage. Any way you slice it, this game does not have Basic" attacks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am posting this review on my very limited first impressions, so this may change in the future.

After one hour in the game I did not want to tear myself away.  It is very rare for an MMO to do that to me, but this has accomplished it.  I do not feel the need to try and gain levels to get to the end so I can either start working on the endgame or starting a new character to experience a different class.  This game hooked me by simply letting me out of the city gates and doing what I wanted.  I absorbed the scenery and killed some animals.  That is all I did, yet I want to go back for more.  Excuse me when I say, but I have not had that feeling since Star Wars Galaxies back in June 2003.

Everything about this game conures up those memories so far (thinking of first impressions for both games).  The color scheme to the animations all bring back that nostalgiac feeling.  The crafting and crafting stations remind me of city in a city and making my next project.  Using my fist weapons definitely makes me miss my Teras Kasi master as the weapon and animations seem like something ripped from the past.  The wealth of jobs" in the game is something we are not used to seeing anymore and I welcome it.

Since this was a first impressions piece

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes, it is an alpha (or beta, or early access or whatever) but there's already a lot of content to fiddle with. As an elder's day SWG fundamentalist I'm pretty surprised about how much inspiration was taken from that original title and I'm pleased every time I see it reflected in the new shiny graphics. It's too early to predict the final outcome or give a verdict, yet, but as far as I can tell it promises and delivers the true sandbox game-style many gamers like me have waited for since SWG (and even earlier, UO).

To the AD kids accustomed with FPS and action-RPG: stay away, this is probably not your cup of tea.
To those enjoying deep deep deep crafting in EverQuest: fasten your seatbelts, crafting is gonna be a bumpy road even for you! And I say so with satisfaction.

Skills require time, patience and practice to be learnt. Exactly as I like it! And there's no one-man army (single player games and modern pseudo-MMOs) nor full loot free for all PVP. It is very much possible to be the famous fisher all over again, fishing and selling his catch without fighting. And still be on the top of the foodchain in this virtual society.

Chase those hunters, set up a camp for them to rest and entertain them while a medic heals their wounds and get tons of credits for doing so. Without a weapon be their champion and lifesaver. Ahhh... just like many did in the ole' days!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

there's alot of potential here for the long pined for and in recent years much touted and vocalized demand for sandboxy mmo play that earmarked the early years of the mmo genre but has long since been forelorn in favour of an extreme dichotomy between hardcore corpse loot ffa pvp games like eve and DFO and others, and the increasingly on rails and narrow avenues of gameplay of themepark games ranging from wow to gw2.

instead here we have a a middle ground answer to the ever widening gap that takes another look at the mmo as a virtual world. while there will be a hardcore corpse loot server option eventually, currently the game's economy and avenues rely on swg like decay system rather than corpse loot or bind on equip durability systems of the two polar extremes that inundate the genre over the past 10 years.

there's a wide degree of freedom and options on both avenues of progression and gameplay roles. want to be a dedicated crafter? you can do that, and rely on combat oriented players or trade to feed your manufactury efforts. want to be a non combat entertainer? you can progress dancing and story telling and help road weary combat players both at clubs and in the field at campsites. want to be a combat player? there's a wide variety of weapon and combat styles to choose from, ranging from mobile ranged options to longer range but less mobile options. to a wide variety of setting appropriate melee options each with their own tasty nuances.

the freedom to dedicate yourself to one of these avenues, or mix as you please, is also refreshing. want to be a dancer who also farms wildlife with an automatic? well hell that's what i do in game already right now.

and pvp vs pve? on the normal mode servers, pvp is always an option, but not a required one. each faction gets a full third of the game world to themselves each. while the final third is open pvp for the less faint of heart. and factions themselves are not set in stone - if you wish to break away and make your own decisions as to whom you ally with and fight against, you can do so via the rogue nation systems.

i have watched in and out of game the amazing pace of progress by these developers over the past year, while engaging with them on their forums and getting personal and well reasoned replies from them. maybe i have an idea to suggest for the game that doesn't work or has been tried already? the devs have let me know that, or why that thing i suggest doesn't work or they might like it but plan not to use it. and at other times for feedback that they do plan to take, they ask for more information to get a better picture of what i'm asking for or suggesting.

the downsides of the game currently are, however, quite obvious: character creation is very light with not a lot of options beyond tethered together sliders that change the shapes of body parts. the UI in general needs a lot of work, as it's heavilyinundated by drop down menu paradigms. this affects everything from AH shopping and selling to crafting to character creation - they have told me they are aware of this though and asked for examples for inspiration of what we desire and expect in these places. and ofc the art assets quality is also lacking at this time.

i also want to note, that if you like mmoRPG combat, ie tab/click targetting stuff, the combat is solid, responsive and punchy. this game feels just plain nice to farm mobs in so far, and i can't wait to get the opportunity to try the combat in pvp in the future.

my verdict is that if you're looking for something that scratches that pre wow/eve dichotomy sandy mmo itch, then repop is the game to watch. if you aren't ready for wipes and bugs and all around roughness, keep this game on the backburner for now, but keep an on it and this is the middle ground sandbox mmo to watch in the coming year above all other big studio hype machine offerings being bandied about.

Not bad!

Pros --

Crafter Heaven or Hell
Purely Open World
No End Game!
You can use pretty much anything you can make
Combat is not bad, but could be better with there action system

Cons--

Crafter Hell! Too many steps to get something done, but its still fun!
There are afew npc bugs where you may be able to attack a npc with out firing purposly
NPC vendors such as shop keepers have a long aggro cool down and will kill you if you are in sight
Lag switching from region to region and fps drops when traveling fast speeds
At this time most of the ownable lots are taken up.
They need more weapons and armor to keep crafting interesting
They need to ballance the item prices a little better to encourage trading on auction house


Out side of those little bugs its a solid game! I put over 100 hours into the thing! It's defenently a good investment of time. Communitys great, and its refreshing to see a open world game like this where you can kill anyone or anything, and  do what you wanna do with no forced quest line, or stupid gear that gets nurfed and crap.

Initial review: (only a few hours in the game)

So far the game seems very complicated but still strangely entertaining.  If you are easily confused don't play this game it's not very noob friendly.  The skill trees are huge, I've played 3 hours and barely out of the tutorial zone :)  So far I'm enjoying the game, it is a huge time sync I can tell because just getting a few points for harvesting took a huge amount of time.  If you like crafting, questing and lots of options on what you can do and what you are this might be the game for you.

EDIT 5/11/2005: I'm told you get to build and stuff in this game so far I've played 8 hours and all I've managed to get done was kill a few monsters, die 40+ times, and gained a ton of recipes for things I can't hope to create anytime soon :( The game seems to be a serious time sink.  After 8 hours I still have all my starter gear and weapons only thing that has changed is I have a few 2% damage mods on my starter weapons.  The crafting system could seriously use a (have mats filter) so I can work on skills when I have the mats instead of hunting through everything just to find the 1 thing I have materials to make

EDIT 5/13/2015: Ok this is it for me, I can't take it anymore... let me see how to best explain this.. lets say you want a Cloned pet... first you have to kill 2 to 5 of a creature (not bad right?) then if they drop what you need DNA and tissue .. then you have to go to the store and buy a sterilizing agent .. then go to the crafting station and sterilize the tissue to make orgainic material ... then have to take that and mix it with dna to make the pet.. and this is the easiest fastest thing you can make.. never mind the 200+ deaths before you can kill those 2 to 5 things... forget the hours and hours you'll waste to get nothing in return.. if you want to make something useful like a car or house? you better be ready to spend days/weeks just to make 1.. this game is the biggest grind fest I've ever seen.  Your not grinding levels per say, your grinding skill points 1000's and 1000's of skill points just to do what? who knows I gave up at 100, yep almost 18 hours of play and died more times than I care to think about .. my highest skill is 100 (rifle) and my armor skills are in the 20's.  anyway not going to keep going but this game is just all about grinding grinding grinding and when you get done grinding.. well you stopped playing that's the only way it ends

Still going to recommend it because if you like this crazy stuff it's really well made.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Havent  been able to play much but here are some first impressions. I would not recomend this game to 90% of people. Right  now its ugly, janky, buggy, crashes a lot , and  a bit  like  trying to learn quantum physics  in kindergarten.  but those 10% of  people who enjoy that kind  of stuff, this is the game  for you.

Pros
Crafting- Oh my god crafting feels  good (although probably a bit to over complicated) You can craft pretty much everything you will ever need.

The world- Its massive with lots of  places to explore.

The community- So long as you are  asking  simple questions you will get fairly reasonable answers.

Pets! - Want to create a better  Monster? try genetic engeneering. More  of a nature  loving sort? Tame a wild beast. Killer robots  more your  speed? yup got those too! ( though for  robots I hope you are  ready to dive  into a crafting system that will make your  brain bleed  just looking at the  stuff required to build the basic  parts for the  durn thing.) Plus side is you can probably buy them from someone who has already figured it  out.

Cons
Combat- is abysmal and  boring. Its tab combat. boring. Even the action" mode  is just tab combat with clicking instead  of button presses ( IE you click your mouse to use your  auto attack on whatever  monster you have tab targeted.)

Overly Complicated- So depth is a great thing
date: complexity can be  a great thing
recommended: But having a graduation from simple to learn grating up to hard to master  would be  a better  way to do some  of the stuff in this game. As it is
hoursPlayed: not very new player friendly.\n\nThe community- While most of  my (somewhat) limited interaction with the community in game  has been pleasent
voteText: asking questions about  crafting
helpfulPercent: or  making a comment about  maybe things are a bit to complicated
votesHelpful: will be  met with a level of arrogance normally reserved for  the likes  of Kanye West.\n\nKeep in mind this is just my limited experience with the game
votesTotal: my opinion may change but as  of now if you are  looking for a game  that reminds you of SWG
votesFunny:
you might be better served to keep looking. Some of the  things are  the same but the game still has a long long way to go. That said the dev team seems to be active and responsive and  hopefully they can bring their  dream to life.

right  now 5/10
"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOy vey. If the developers play their cards right, The Repopulation will cause an earthquake in the MMO market of epic proportions. A word of warning -- this game, and many others like it, will not appeal to a certain faction of mers. I would argue that this is largely due to many MMO players wanting to have everything spoon fed to them, whereas in TR you'll have to do a lot of brainstorming and theory crafting if you want to succeed. However, once you GET IT"
date: it'll be one of the most realistic and enjoyable gaming experiences that you'll ever partake in.  The Repopulation is in every sense of the phrase -- the ultimate successor to Star Wars Galaxies
recommended: and perhaps even has the potential to be greater. The game is overall very steady

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Remember... it's an Alpha with quite some development time done.

Wat do i think of the gameplay:
I have played the game now for a few hours, and done the training set a few times with different characters. So far i am enjoying it. My videocard 290X runs the game good, but not as smooth as SW-TOR. It has more detail then SW-TOR, but it comes (logically) at a price. Different settings make huge differences in speed vs quality (as i would expect).
On higher settings the game looks very nice and plays not too bad but not good enough. I guess that certain optimisations will make things go smoother/better. Personally i think that for an alpha release it looks and plays ok.  Just take it down a notch and it still looks good and plays very well.

Alpha? glitches?
i have not had any lag or big glitches, the only thing i kill instantly is the music. (its not my kind of sound and after a while it  is ... well lets say i killed it. probably great music for hardrock screaming fans)

Quests and gaining experience
The quests are easy to pick up (open email and accept missions) but difficult to find once picked up. You gain experience  by doing things. In the early stages it feels overwhelming and there are quite some areas to improve. just watch and learn in the tutorial part. You end up with a robot pet and a lizard kind of pet. very nice.

Overall
I think the game is good with a lot of possibilities. It takes time to get things right but i think that it only will get better. When my experiences change i'll update. Now i would say... if you like firefall in a bigger scale and more detail, you should certainly give it a try. (be sure to check out some gameplay vids on youtube.
If it is worth the money... well thats difficult. i think it is. but if you are more into SW-TOR style or Firefall fast style this one is maybe going too slow. (but i have not yet had the opportunity to race around in one of the vehicles.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is a purely sandbox adventure in every sense of the world. The mission system tailors itself to your playstyle, so you can do things that are purely crafting, purely combat, delivery missions, etc, or a blend of them. You can further tailor missions for specific factions. The game does not really lead you from one place to another. You move from one place to another and the missions presented to you will reflect that change.

You raise your skills by doing, not by level, as there aren't any levels. You want to raise your pistol skills, then equip a pistol and use it. A specific armor? Equip it and use it. It goes on and on. It also has viable entertainment and cooking skills, so it is conceivable to just be an entertainer.

The crafting system is fairly complex. If you want to craft, prepare to have a second job. It's an exaggeration, of course, but not by much.

Player cities. Rogue nations. PvP, either on the hardcore server, or if you go beyond the starting areas. You can concievably play the game without PvP, such as a crafter character, or by staying around the core areas.

It's an entertaining game with a lot of depth and complexity and will hopefully do well. Release looks to be later this year and it will be F2P.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I see a great potential for this game. The content offers exactly what a sandbox MMO/RPG should have and there is still more to come! I would recommend this game to others IF they enjoy crafting and sandbox based games BUT, if you are not fond of loosing your progress for launch (as usual for a game coming out of Alpha) or can't stand game crashes, occasional glitches or any other expected problem from Alpha games PLEASE WAIT on getting this game. The only other thing I can say is you need patience for this game has a HUGE learning curve, it will take some time to learn to play this game.

Here is my score for this game 1-10:
Content: 8
Story: 10
Playability: 6 (Crashes are common and region Transition Lag, Reminder IN ALPHA)
Market: 8 ( Needs a little work for the AH BUT still great marketing features like Work Orders")
Social: 9
Developers: 10 (They care
recommended: and they are on a lot! Solid 10)\nCrafting: 10 (Crafting is challenging and Sooo in depth that it is overwhelming. I like a challenge!)\nTime: 10 (For the short amount of time I have had this game
hoursPlayed: I have 100+ hrs and I find it hard to pull myself away)\n\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having backed this game via kickstarter.  I have very high hopes for this.  Being a veteran of SWG this game appeals to my nostalgia feels.

Pro's

Scope,  style and sandbox classless system are major selling points. 3 way pvp.  player run and owned cities.  immense crafting.  playing the entire game as a non combat character.

Con's

And these should be taken as it being early days and by no means final judgement on the games finished product.

Animations do seem slightly clunky.

Aesthetics.  Character creation is a tad rubbish.  Hairstyles are shockingly bad.  and the slider system makes it very hard to get a distinct look everyone seems to be the same person.   Some of the early release armors are ugly.

the Faux action shooter option while a nice touch needs some work on it.


Conclusion:  Support this game.  with your help these guys can make a game worthy of us veteran SWG players.

Despite the negatives I have found so far it by far has alot more promise going for it to just forget it.

Keep an eye on this

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not that far into the game yet, but from what I have experienced so far this game has a huge thumbs up from me.

The game systems - skill systems - crafting and all that stuff feels really solid and I am truly enjoying myself in here.



EDIT 45 hours in:
This game is truly growing on me. The game systems are really solid and the potential is enormous.

What you do have to realise when thinking about trying the game is that it is an Alpha. I repeat: Alpha. Not a lot of people have ever been in an Alpha and are comparing it to Beta testing which is a whole different ball game. Public betas are usually very polished and not so much about actually testing as it is about showing up a near finished product and more about PR than anything else.

So I repeat, again: Alpha



Also, almost every question and issue with the game I have seen are things that have been answered on the forums, by Devs or even on the website. So if you are the type of person that has a hard time finding and understanding written information you will probably be quite frustrated at times. It might not  be the game for you and personally, I'm fine with that.

I come from a background of playing EVE, starting in last phase of BETA and then playing extensively for 8 years and on and off after that. EVE is similar in the way that it has a quite steep learning curve, a very dedicated community and a mentality of If this is not the game for you
date: we have no problem with that". I think this game might develop into a similar kind of community
recommended: and again: I'm fine with that :)"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo I've sunk a good little chunk of time into The Repopulation and after 2 days I have too say, this game is just great! I'm a huge fan of games like Eve Online and SWG where things are player run and people are completely free to do as they choose and this game is right up that alley. Keep in mind that it is an me in Alpha! It's got its problems right now and i've had a few crashes here and there but its definetly not game breaking. Also I don't really understand why people have been saying that there's no tutorial or it's too hard to understand. All you have to do is read the dialogue at the beginning in the tutorial zone when you talk to npcs. And if that doesn't cover it for you, the community is always happy to help. I learned a lot from just asking people about stuff. If you know you don't like MMOs then don't buy this game because it's most likely not for you. But if you do than it's definitely worth checking out :D

Great game that has replay" value by the same character you already play - almost like FFXIV (in that you can use the same character to play all roles).

So the game is still a bit buggy. And at first I thought it was my graphics card
date: maybe even the brand since it's ATI/AMD or maybe even the connection...but others are experiencing similar issues and many others (which is expected).\n\nYou might occasionally d/c or encounter a glitch or 2 - but just work with it
recommended: review the forums or ask the "newbie" channel even...you'll most likely find some answers or tips to help (while fixes and updates are in the works). The foliage setting was an issue for me - and while I have to set it on "very low" to where I see virtually no grass it helps for now.\n\nThe crafting is a bit complex - but it will be great for inter-dependency on other players and preventing people from thinking they can do it all. This is an MMO after all - join a Nation (guild) and team up! I've done a cave so far

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My first MMORPG was SWG Pre-CU. It was an incredible experience, had an amazing community, and left you with the feeling that you were really in a living and breathing player driven world. Combat professions were dependant on non-combat professions and vice versa, the economy was completely player driven, and you had the freedom to do and be what you wanted to be. The how and why were completely up to you. With the changes that SOE made to SWG, the player base began to dwindle, and heartbreakingly, the game was eventually shut down.

Enter The Repopulation.

I've only had a chance to play for a short while, however, it can be safely said that this game is a true successor to the mechanics and concepts that made SWG such an amazing and immersize experience. The Repopulation is currently in Alpha, and with that said, there will be bugs, and the development team is still in the process of creating and refining the game systems that will make to to the final release. With that said, what I have seen so far is nothing short of amazing.

To the development team, thank you SO MUCH for not only creating a game that is incredibly nostalgic for me and other players, but also for creating a game that does not follow the typical WoW/themepark/level based progression trend that is so commonplace in MMORPGs. That alone will make The Repopulation worth checking out for many gamers who want something different, and will set it apart from the current trends and gain a foothold in the niche of players who want a true sandbox experience.

For everyone who considers themselves a SWG refugee" like myself
date: do yourselves a favour and make a pledge to help the development of this game. Support it and the development team
hoursPlayed: and welcome home."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impression review:
The gameplay itself looks promising and is probably the closest to SWG we will ever get. But the visuals are ugly.


While it does have minor crashes and bugs, its alpha so the performance hiccups are also to be suspected. But no serious/game-breaking bugs so far.
No monthly fee, it will be F2P but not pay2win from what I read.

The animations, graphics and music are extremely boring and outdated while still requiring an endgame computer. The absense of colors.. It's usually much grayer than in the storepage screenshots. When I played this game I thought I got colorblind. Don't get me wrong I dislike cartoony games. But this game is too far to the other extreme.

Combat feels a bit static as well, boring SFX, boring visuals, same story.

I only played for a few hours so I should update this review later.

If they would improve the visuals, add some more colors and make the world more lively and less 'static' then this game will be the first worthy alternative/sequel to SWG (before NGE).

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo I've sunk a good little chunk of time into The Repopulation and after 2 days I have too say, this game is just great! I'm a huge fan of games like Eve Online and SWG where things are player run and people are completely free to do as they choose and this game is right up that alley. Keep in mind that it is an me in Alpha! It's got its problems right now and i've had a few crashes here and there but its definetly not game breaking. Also I don't really understand why people have been saying that there's no tutorial or it's too hard to understand. All you have to do is read the dialogue at the beginning in the tutorial zone when you talk to npcs. And if that doesn't cover it for you, the community is always happy to help. I learned a lot from just asking people about stuff. If you know you don't like MMOs then don't buy this game because it's most likely not for you. But if you do than it's definitely worth checking out :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game does bring me back to the days of SWG. It's sandbox in every sense of the word. You can do what you want and play how you want.

THIS GAME IS IN ALPHA!

This means its still under heavy development. There are bugs, graphic glitches and annying little quirks. However, they are working on them all. Since my start in this game December of 2014 I have seen lots of changes and improvements. The Devs care about this game and want it to succed. They listen to the player base and intereact on the forums.

I am excited for the future of this game. If you don't want to play something in development then DO NOT purchase this. It will be far more polished at launch (Dec 2015 or 1Q 2016) and free.

The only con on this game right now is they are not planning to impliment a subscription model for those that would like to support the game with a monthly sub. If they did that at launch I would subscribe in a minute.

If you want a game that is not on training wheels, encourages social interaction and group play, then the Repopulation is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a lot of potential. Many nice features including email mission system, and lots of skills to work on.

The skill system makes a nice change from the level grind found in most mes, players are not limited to linear progression, providing they have the right skill and gear players can go anywhere to advance. The skill system also has the advantage of allowing players to tailor gameplay to their particular taste, no need to make alternate characters.

However It's very unpolished at present and badly needs optimized to produce smoother movement and performance, opening the map makes the game lag like crazy, especially so in the already laggy city areas.

The graphics are not the most pleasing to the eye, could do with more textures, art work and better lighting, and greater diversity of environment.

The combat doesn't quite work, currently combat feels like you are fumbling around while trying to target mobs and activate abilities, even the fps mode combat feels stiff and awkward.

While fighting mobs they get so close to your character that you are practicaly shooting at your feet while trying to keep them in target, some bad AI combined with the weird combat system makes for poor gameplay.

Frankly they need to choose one combat mode or the other, trying to combine hotbar click combat and FPS combat through the same basic combat system is poor game design.

Exploration of the game is made difficult because of the death respawn system, the zones are quite large, upon death you are forced to respawn from the nearest city spawn point, this means you have to travel a fair distance back to where you were exploring, an ability to bind in the world or a simple time out mechanism would significantly reduce the demoralizing effect that death currently has for players.

Maps and waypoints ingame could use some refinement, making it clearer for players to find where their mission objectives are. Too much time is wasted trying to find mission objectives at present making some missions just not worth the trouble.

The game features an elaborate crafting system which many crafters will love, however at the same time this is likely to put many others off, alternatives for gear and upgrades for the more casual player may be advisable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is exactly what i have been waiting for since swg was taken away. The exploration, crafting, community, sensible PVP-PVE balance, Player Cities and housing all makes this a home from home... thank you A&BT. I do not use Steam that much to be honest but have some games off Steam - I am however a long term backer of this game and have been testing it since the begining of Alpha 3 which is about 6 months or more now. It is an old fashioned game only in the sense that it is PURE SANDBOX. It leaves you to explore and decide what you want to do in the game-world, everything is optional. I think this game is for more mature players and commited gamers as it takes work.


No 'themepark' leveling or story-lines or easy to do without thinking missions [ ie go here do that and there is the npc you talk to]. You have to find these things for yourself a lot. So this is a game that makes you think and work to achive results. I like that there are no toon levels but rather skills to increase proficiency in. There are over 1000 repeatable missions accross the world if missions is your thing. The Crafting is complex, it will appeal to those who drool over real crafting requiring thought and graft. The world is beautiful and well thought out... with so much to do and so many options and paths...


Oh boy so much to try remember to say - hey I'm in love with this game" just about sums it up and this is said by a guy in a grey beard lol so a mature well thought out comment.

Important to remember it is still a game in development and you are not buying a finished product
date: rather buying into the opportunity to test and help this indie project become the game we have been wating for since SWG and UO days."

This game has been DELAYED, but it is NOT DEAD. Do not dismiss this game! It is overflowing with potential! If this game gets a decent community it will be superb.

The issue this game is currently dealing with (and overcoming) is their game engine Hero Engine" is owned by a seperate company. That company is going through issues and it is affecting The Repopulation. The devs have decided to switch to Unreal Engine (a good choice in my opinion) and are working on porting everything over.

Due to all of this. They have shutdown the servers and disabled the ability to purchase the game until it is all resolved.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Did you enjoy Star Wars Galaxies, Shadowbane, Anarchy Online, Everquest or Dark Age of Camelot back in the day? Did you enjoy the era where MMO's had more complexity to them? Well, chances are you will enjoy this title. It has everything that made old school MMO's great but with a modern touch.

The problem with MMO's nowadays is that they all follow the same formula: quest, level up, get gear and loot. While this is an OK formula, I missed the more open-ended MMO's where you could go out and do what you wanted without having to follow a linear progressional path. The Repopulation does this right. Similar to SWG (Star Wars Galaxies), the developers made the game so that you could start off and get right into crafting without having to force yourself to do combat. You could do quests if you want, but you can also head right out and follow your destiny.

Want to be a tradesman who earns an honest living building vehicles and houses? You can do that. Want to be one of hundreds of soldiers fighting a war on the battlefield? You can do that. Thing is with this game; there are so many features to it that it really feels like a living, breathing world. Although still in 'Early Access' it feels like a polished Alpha. Granted, there are still MANY bugs and quirks that need fixing. The game would not be acceptable to the average gamer. However, if you have that itch for an old-school MMO like I did, then pick this up. It'll scratch that itch.

I can't speak for the future of this game, but there is a LOT of potential here. The world is quite large as-is and I have a feeling they're planning to expand it. What makes this game feel like an actual world is the complexity of it. It could well be a life simulator once it's released. Only time will tell.

Based on what I've experienced so far and the promise this game shows, I have no choice but to rate it a solid 8/10. However, if they fix the bugs, clunky UI & map glitches and add a little more pizazz to the game, I'd give it a 10/10. This is THE MMO to play for any mer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you miss SWG, this is the game for you.  If you love open-world sandbox games, this is the game for you.

Its Alpha.  Things are amiss.  Because its Alpha.  But there is still an incredibly rich experience to be had even at this early phase.  The Alpha community is generous, helpful and knowledgable.    Are there glitches, bugs, random CTDs and errors than require you to wait for a midnight server reset to unstick your character?  Yep.  It's Alpha.  These things happen.

There isn't a lot of hand-holding.  In fact, a lot of critical documentation has yet to be implemented, but give the game a day or so to grow on you.  I'm a SWG day one vet and have quite a bit of exposure to sandbox games.  I was still mystified by many of the game's aspects.  Three days in, I had figured most of it out.

Fair warning: the crafting system is incredibly deep and complex.  This isn't going to be like Galaxies where you can be self-sufficient after leveling a couple of Alts to Master.

I have a couple of beginners 'tips:  There's an NPC doctor in the hospital who wants parasites that can be looted while mining or logging.  Grab the 10cr used logging saw and used mining drill and have at it.  Rise and repeat all the way to your fist vehicle.  Price are about 2K for a decent cycle.  Or buy a Light Assault Mech and get killed by a vulture.  I take that back, don't by the Light Mech.  Just buy a cycle.

Anytime you get an Engagement Mission....head out and do it.  The rewards will be worthwhile.

Don't start fights you can't finish....specifically with any NPC mob that has Medic" in their name.  Serioulsy OP atm.

8/10 currently.  I can't give it 10/10 because it's not quite finished and polished (because Alpha).  Entirely worth the 20 bucks for the basic level backer's pack and Alpha access.

Do it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start off by saying that if you're looking for a game to replace the hole left after SWG went down, then this may not be the game you expect it to be.

The general lay out of the game and the overlays are effectively a carbon copy of SWG so you may start to feel like you're back in that world... until you begin to explore and play the game. I got this game because people get referring to it as a spiritual successor to SWG and I haven't played a really GREAT MMO since SWG (I don't think there are any MMO's out there that can match SWG for being a true MMORPG Sandbox game)

However I found myself comparing every tiny detail to how SWG did things, and The Repopulation came up short on absolutely everything. Ofcourse this game is still being made, and you can really see what they are trying to achieve with it. I'm probably jumping the gun with my judgements and I should come back in 6months to a year to see the progress.

Having said that I don't think it can compare to SWG, i'd still recommend picking up this game, or atleast watching it's progress. It has the potential to be the only true Sandbox MMO out there that doesn't send you on linear quests from level 1-90 killing boars and running from point a-b until you max your characters level out. You can see that they want this game to be for the players and run by the players, in game economy driven by player crafting, player cities, completely explorable landscapes etc...

Just be warned if you're missing SWG then this isn't the game for you (currently)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are looking for a craft focused mmo with lots of depth as well as fun to play I would recommend this game without reservation! Its different, fun to play at this alpha stage and the potential is huge in this game. It is alpha so its by no way perfectly running, but not a problem in my opinion. I've been hooked like I haven't been hooked on a game in years ...

Crafting is vast, looks huge to begin with but is not as bad as it looks when you get into it. There are vast number of components to make. Fighting is good but plenty of improvements to come I think. Player cities are good fun when you get into making your own home. Lots to make and Im sure lots more to come. Mechanoids, siege warfare, pvp are all areas with great potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Old review ( Not Recommened )
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Buyers beware!

This game has a lot of potential and I can see it become a very interesting product in the future but as it stands right now I just cannot recommand it. I am aware that the game is in Alpha phase and that it's far from reflecting the actual finished product but right now paying 40 $ for a game like this seems kind of a ripoff to me. (It's really not fun at all.)

-It's crippled with numerous bugs of all sorts and very poorly optimized (to the point that it sometimes becomes unplayable (my framerate as dropped several times below 10 fps and all the graphics settings we're tuned down, plus I'm running this game on a pretty beefy computer.)

-The screenshots in the preview area of the game store page does not reflect in any way what you get when you play the game (as in the actual game looks much uglier)

-I literally spent around an hour in the main town just to find a NPC to complete the most basic quest. (Couldn't get the proper indication from the other NPCS or other players for that matter.)

-The game has an extremely steep learning curve that may not appeal to all players (I was prepared for that.)

-The training area where you begin could use a lot of work to help new players.

-Almost every annimations in the game looks sluggish and unpleasant to the eye (Even basic attack annimations from mobs, To the point that you sometimes ask yourself if the monster is attacking you or not.)

-Servers get super lag spikes from times to times.

-Audio tracks sometimes cut right in the middle of the song or start at improper moments.

In short, if you buy this game just understand that the money you are investing is really to support the developers more than for the actual game itself.

Update since last release: (14.12.1)
---------------------------------------------------------

-> The overall look and feel of the game has improved.
-> The is still a lot of work to be done on the texture side but considering the state of the game this is not a major issue.

-> Character and Monsters annimations have been improved. (Thanks god.)

-> The game is now much more playable than it used to be. (At least for the time I've spent trying the new version around 2-3 hours)

-> The sound track still cuts out of the blue like it used to. There has been no improvement about this issue. It's rather sad because it seems like some of the songs in the game are really worth listening to. (Adding a fade-in/fade-out effect would really help to keep the player immersion into the game)

-> Switching my review from not recommended" to "recommended"  you can walk around and have fun exploring the map fighting a couple monsters along the way. This game is still very far from perfect but at least now it's playable.

Side note: Those who think about playing this game like an "action game" (Because of the 3rd/1rst person view mode) don't make the same mistake that I made. This game is really meant to be played like your standard me. Switching into 3rd/1rst person doesn't really bring anything new to the table nor does it make the combat more "dynamic" in any way."

I spent countless hours and sleepless nights playing this game alone. Despite the bugs that are present, this game is really fun, addicting and has great potential for an early access game.  The game *IS* challenging, but you will feel great satisfaction when you build up your character the way you want to.  Not for the faint of heart, as you'll need a lot of patience to learn the basics (Mainly crafting), and to learn how to get through the game. Food for thought.

This game offers great freedom on how you want to build up your character. You can become a crafter in many different types of trade skills available in the game, a melee/rifle/flamthrower weapon wielding soldier (just as an example), or both if you want to pursue that path.

I'm glad to be able to support this game.

On the other hand, being early access, it is present with some horrifying bugs that render this game almost unplayable at times (Random CTD's, Lag spikes at random intervals of time, combat hiccups and farts), causing you to rage quit in the end.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game tries to re-invent too many wheels without having the development staff for it.  Combat, crafting, skills, abilities, gear, the mission system... all at various stages of conceptual" implementation without being complete or interwoven with the other systems in the game - combat being the most lacking.  Most systems are designed to be overly complicated for no reason
date: tooltips are vague and inconsistent leaving the player to question pretty much everything they look at in-game.  Poor english and grammar skills from the development teams leaves many tooltips incomprehensible.  GM staff is malevolent and vindictive often speaking up in general chat about their pleasure in disciplining alpha testers for testing things innapropriately without an obvious communication to testers of what is and is not appropriate.  If this game ever does go live it will be a major bot-fest as pretty much everything is levelled up runescape style.  For example: you can level vehicle manuevering by auto running into a wall afk which you guessed it
recommended: will get you banned.  Hope you don't walk away from the keyboard momentarily while driving to that grind spot and forget to come back!  In its current implementation the game seems to simply be a crafting simulator where combat is just a "pick your weapon skin" gathering profession.  Like most games out there nowadays the community is fairly toxic though even more-so than normal.  What do you expect from a game advertised to have hard-core gank (and grief) and loot your corpse pvp."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**This review is now out of date due to changes in the games direction.**

Precise in delivering the experience it advertises. It's steeped in the best parts of SWG, while shaking loose a lot of what I dislike about the MMO formula. One example is how missions are emailed to you, and delivered upon completion. I am not a mission oriented player, so I can now pick and choose what is convenient so as not to disrupt my current agenda.

Combat is very tight, and feels like it should. The crafting is extreme enough that it will easily be a full time job, which it should be given the economy will be player driven.  The map design is shrugged off as a necessary evil, filled with pockets of the same enemies and resource spawn areas. I am somewhat confused by this, since these resources that need to be harvested appear in the same areas, grinding these with many players will be a mess. Unfortunately not the kind you'd see in a survival game, where brutality breeds success. I picture more of a drawn out wack-a-mole. This could be wrong, we won't know until closer to release.

There's exactly and only one problem I have with this game. Not enough of you are buying it. It will need master shotgun medics, and racist vehicle merchants. It needs entertainers and people who need entertaining.

Just purchase and forget. One day you'll log on steam to see it has released, and just like that you have a new experience to embark on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

How do you know if a game is a good one? Look into its keymappings. Usually games which have very complicated keymappings, and will take you about 5 to 10 minutes for just learning and remembering keybindings are good games.
(And I mean those games that recognize mouse thumb buttons. It is ridiculous for games nowadays not recognizing thumb buttons.)

And this game had very complicated keybindings which scared me away. I now regret for dodging this game, because after asked my friends about this game, I knew I could have an enormous world to explore. But I gave it up too early.

And now, the server has been taken down, and I don't know when will it be openned again.

My experience has taught me that, if a game had very hard learning curve, just stick to it and get used to it. It always needs some hardwork before you can succeed and achieve something. And that works for both the real life and games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

On the face of it, this game could offer everything a fan of sandbox games wants. Yes the crafting is complicated and has huge depth and the game doesnt hold your hand.

But deep down, in an attempt to add deep crafting, they have forgot to add any ease of use. For example, to craft a gun, you need to craft X amount of components, and those components need Y amount of items. And to figure out where to get these items from, you have to navigate an over complicated badly written in-game database, which tells you what node is needed to harvest. Once you know the node, you then have to scan while in the respective zone in order to find their location.

The animation of characters and monsters is something from early 2005, the movements are sharp and at times 'spikey'. Ability visuals are uninspiring currently and its impossible to tell any visual difference. The graphics as a whole are nothing special either and yet they use a lot of system power. This all may change as there was talk of them using a newer more up to date engine in a future patch.

The audio is almost pointless, and the sound effects are uninspiring and just a general laser pewpew for almost every gun..

There is little community (at least on EU servers) and the ones i have come across have been verbally hostile/rude, which impacts a sandbox game much more than a theme park, as you require other players assistance to progress (crafting, farming, forming pvp groups etc).

The blog states the release is Q4 2015 which concerns me as i see this game still as a very early alpha test.

Deep down, the ambition is amazing, SWG + UO is the inspiration behind the game, but they have bitten off way more they can chew.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI was recommended this game from some fellow SWG fans several years ago. I subscribed to the newsletter and have been following the development for the past few years.  Early Access
date:
is not something I normally like to participate in due to several games having been pulled before release, the cancelation of the Star Gate MMO before beta, and decline of the subscription based MMO genra as a whole.

A few months ago I decided that it was worth the risk, the game looked more finished than most MMO's Ive participated in Beta with.  I played several hours of the game enjoying it for the most part.  I never liked the walled in feeling of the land, the lack of information around the crafting system, and the dialogue system with the NPCs but none of that is enough to warrent a bad review.

Contractual issues aside with Hero Engine and the game developer I understand the hold in the development cycle while they plan an alternative route.  I support a switch to another engine like UE, i think it will be a great step for this game as long as they are happy with the contractual and royalty terms of that engine as well.

What I am unhappy about is the development of the Single Player / LAN game based on this concept which has caused them to shelve the MMO for a year and possibly longer before working on the game that they have been advertising and collecting capital for.  There is a word for the wrongful  deception intended to result in financial gain, its call FRAUD.  Now whether this is intentional, accidental, or coencidental is not clear, regardless the possibility exists.

The only advantages I can see with Fragmented is the release of game sooner so they can continue bankrolling Repopulation.  The disadvantage is in the simultanius development, while there is some advantage to this on a whole it will mean more delays as support will have to be given over two products at the same time unless they hire even more staff than they had previously id expect slow downs in the development process.

I'd give the game an 8/10, the company id give a C rating.  I cannot recommend this game until it is out of Early Access."  The game that I previously recommended before december 2015 no longer "exisits" and I feel that the future of the game is in jeopordy
recommended: I hope im wrong.\n\n[I'll consider revising this review later this year or beyond depending the release of any additional information on Repop
hoursPlayed: or an explination on the necessity of Fragmented beyond
voteText: give the fans something now]"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has some serious potential.  It already has things I find as glaring deficits in most modern RPGs/MMORPGs: the basis for a robust economy,  a complex crafting system that requires specialization, cooperation, and market use (and abuse!). It has player housing, both instanced and open world. I thinik it will be interesting to see how these pan out in the long term.
All this game needs now is a driver for demand:  A population that has a reason to need or want the large myriad of items that can be crafted.  How to draw a population? This is a no brainer.  Incorporate some features that other games have already done well: A good combat system, good end-game content, and good aesthetics options, both in character and the characters' possesions.  Character development is key in keeping players. The Repopulation still seems to be (understandably, given its developmental stage) lacking in these areas.  However, it is definitely one to keep an eye on in the coming months!

For now, I don't recommend picking up this game.  While it is promising so far, it does have a long way to go in order to become viable.  If it ever gets to the point that I think it's worthwhile, I will update this review and change my recommendation!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very good intentions in the first place at trying to match up with SWG and other similar sandbox games but the interface is too confusing and over complicated for no good reason: very simple things such as grouping doesn't make sense at all, there are too many key bindings and to cover them all without dropping the mouse would require a pair of extra hands, there are too many menus and options are all over the place, banking system is really poor and trading menu is heavily discouraging.

There are too many abilities and skills which end up clogging up the skill bars, crafting has also been made too complicated and divided in a dizzying amount of sub skills and recipes that just add to the whole confusion and complexity, maybe in an attempt to rival with other games such as EvE Online, but without the same success in making it interesting enough.

Fighting system is nowhere near as fluid and captivating as other games available around, and ends up with just clicking on series of aptitudes that would remind DAOC and its combos. Besides that the quest system is broken and some missions require too much time running around to cover long distances to collect very little and have even less in return. The game is not rewarding.

This said it will certainly please its own crowd but feels very frustrating and disappointing from my point of view. I will probably not pursue it past the alpha/beta phase unless a lot of things get square out and fixed to make it more attractive.

And yes one last but very important thing: grinding has stopped being fun a hell of a time ago. If I wanted to aim for a grindfest kind of game I'd know exactly where to go and that also precisely places where I'm keeping away from. There is a huge difference between making things difficult or challenging and just making them horribly frustrating just because they have to be repeated a thousand times for very little progress or reward (again). Please check TESO for that matter. Greatest PvE system seen in a while. I haven't been as far as trying the PvP system but there are just too many obstacles for me to even consider pushing that far into the game.
voteText: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to give this game a thumbs down for now, but if you like old school MMO's and supporting inde devs, then you should by all means pick up a copy.  At this point the core systems of combat and crafting need complete overhauls.

Combat is wonky, especially with melee combat.  They attempted a hybrid tab target with crosshairs and they didn't succeed at either one.  For an old school mmo they really need to stick with an old school tab-targeting system.  They tried to add a self aiming mechanism and it simply doesn't work well.

They attempted to do a 'deep' crafting system, but they ended up with a convoluted mess of a system with tons of materials with various qualities that simply don't make sense.  I appreciate them trying to do an intricate system but they completely forgot to include intuitive, logical systems.  It needs to be overhauled.

Other than that the PvE and PvP are nothing special.  There's potential with this title, but they need to lock down the core systems before I can recommend this title.  I hope they do better in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted to like this game.  I did.  The thought of it being SWG 2.0 was appealing enough.  I thought the game had potential, but it needed polish a lot of it, the game was stuck in the same stage of development for far too long.

Now I read about the game being shutdown on an article on Rock Paper Shotgun that said that The Repopulation was officially on hold and that a new game, named Fragmented was going to be taking the forefront. https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2016/02/01/the-repopulation-mmo-fragmented/

What bothers me the most is that the developers have not taken a stand to announce this to anyone much less on Steam that this change and swap was going on.  The article above states that anyone who bought The Repopulation would be entitled to a key for Fragmented, their new game.

At this point I don't trust any thing this company will do in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a 20yr old MMO with all of the problems of a 20yr old mmo. If you've played EQ1... yea, like that.
Open world chat... everyone talks on the same channel at once.
Some of the community are helpful, some are jerks. You get to hear it all.
You get stuck in walls. Use the /stuck command, like a 20yr old mmo.
Your pet runs all over uncontrollably... use the /pet command
The mobs you kill get stuck in walls... unfortunately there's no /drag yet

Want a quest? Go find one... good luck. They're all over, and text based. Get 10 of this, 20 of that, whatever.
Want to skill up? There's a skill window with more skills than members of congress.. Greeces congress. What any of them do or how the over complicated skill system works? I've no idea and don't have the patients to figure it out.


It's unoptimised, poorly rendered, the animations are sureal, and the chat is a mess of everyone talking over each other to the point that arguments erupt left and right, so GM's have to get involved.

Basically the games a mess. I like the premise, I really wish there was a decent SciFi mmo out, but there's not. This game needs a LOT of work before it's really playable, and I don't see that happening. Why do I keep getting suckered into paying for pre-release games?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would love to be able to reveiw this game but as I have never been able to get it to successfully launch, I'll have to content myself with reviewing the support I have received.
Initial response to my inability to launch the game was swift, and I dare say that if the issue had been caused by something as simple needing to update my drivers, reinstall the game cache, or reinstall Visual C++ then it it very well would have been resolved.
Unfortunately, once the issue moved past the obvious things to check I received no further help. Understanding the game is still in early stages, I waited nearly two months before following up to see if some resolution had been discovered -at which time I received, basically, a 'we don't know or care' response.
To everyone that is enjoying the game, I guess the money I threw at the Kickstarter was worth it. As for me, if I had a way to get my $50 back, I'd still consider it a loss with all the time I've wasted trying to get this game to work (more time than the support staff have spent, I'd wager).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an early access review, so this could change at any time if the developer addresses the problem. This game has a lot of good ideas, however regardless of how many good ideas it has it's all for naught if the game isn't fun to play.

In this case, the thing that lets it down are janky controls. They feel unresponsive at sporadic intervals; with my character lurching around rather than gracefully sidestepping like I want it to. This problem is enough to mire whatever else could be great about the Repopulation. Regardless of whatever inspired ideas and glorious gameplay are contained within, the controls being so un-fun mean I cannot in good concience give this a favorable review until the controls are sorted.

As far as I'm aware the game has been alpha and beta tests for a long time already, and if the controls haven't been fixed at this stage, then I don't see any reason why the developer ever will. And that concerns me. The controls are pretty much the most important thing in a game. Whatever a person does in the game, whatever their interests, whatever they are or aren't interested in, they will still be involved in the fundamental control of their character. The controls are such a basic and rudamentary thing, that I cannot believe that a developer would not get basic movement fixed before moving on to other features.

All the other features are all good and well, but if I don't want to play the game becasue the controls are a slog, then I won't be here to enjoy any of the other features anyway.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off I want to say that I like this game, it has a very solid rule system behind its gameplay that's almost in depth enough to be a pen and paper RPG.

However charging for it at this point is just embarrassing for the devs and mildly insulting for players. Between getting stuck on the edge of a handrail while jumping(go into stealth or change stance to crouch), to getting the first person scope overlay stuck on your screen all the way out to distant third person(go back to character select), to hostile raiders running into the giant tree for cover and firing out of it at you(retreat out of range so they charge out of their perma shield). Add in words that are plain out wrong (ofs where ifs should be ect.) this game just isn't at a point functionally where I'd really feel good paying more then $10 for it.

That being said, I love the massive skill/crafting/gathering system. It took me a couple hours to get my head around it, but as your knowledge of specific plants/recipes and you applicable skill increase you get better quality materials and make better items and equipment out of it. This is not as simple as it sounds, gather water and log trees then purify the water using the logs as a heat source, then breakdown logs with distilled water and some logs for the heat source to just to make glue. Combat is broken down into 4 melee, 6 ranged, 3 armor classes, plus tactical knowledges, multiple healing types, plenty of different pet-like things, driving and vehicle repair, stealth and awareness.

It's massive and I love it and it has so much promise, they need to pay a horde of english students to edit all the flavor and information text, preferably drop the entry price or make it a full demo until it's solidly in beta (I know devs, it hurts not getting the money but you'll get more good interest out of free then why did I pay $20)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As it currently stands Repopulation has an incredible amount of potential, but is NOT ready for players. From minor complaints like text boxes containing overlapping text to more annoying things, like the action bars working in strange and unexpected ways, there are a plethora of problems with this MMO that irritate and frustrate the player.

There have been a number of updates since I came on board, but not a single update has addressed problems to the User Interface that cause so much irritation. What good are dialog boxes and option settings you can't read?

This game might be great, in a year or so, but right now you are better off playing solitare than spending money on it. Come back in a year.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing through the current version of the game it is fair to say that Repopulation has copied some things from SWG -- the worst parts -- then added some new stuff into the mix.

What did it copy? The grind. Yes, RePop is a grindfest of epic proportions. A second job if you want to call it that.

The claim of the developers is that the game doesn't have XP at all. Rather that by using skills you randomly gain skill points for that skill. The end result is the same, you progress by repeating the same activity over and over. Some missions do reward skill points but these are far from the primary soruce of progression. In some ways this is actually worse than SWG when you think about it. You level defensive skills by taking damage, so to progress you have to allow yourself to get hit -- how is that meant to be fun? Want to level resource gathering? You need to spend time cracking rocks open one by one and chopping trees down by hand. At least in SWG you didn't need to sit there repeatedly clicking the screen to level gathering skills. You would actually get more fun out of MS Word.

For some bizzare reason they claim their crafting system is inspired by SWG. Don't be fooled! They have completely missed the spirit of what SWG had for crafting. Resources do not shift or change in the world. They are static resource nodes. The quality of the resource is defined by your skill in extracting it. They took the idea of item and resource quality from SWG but removed the best parts which made the SWG economy feel alive. A unique item is certainly produced, but only due to random bonus events which sometimes become available for the crafter to use. Player A and Player B can easily make exactly the same item due to the mechanics so there is no way for someone to gain a reputation for being an especially skilled crafter.

Speaking of skills. RePops developers claim that apparently characters have no levels and yet they do have levels for mobs. So that basically means that players DO have levels, but they aren't displayed. Someone needs to explain to them that no levels means that you stand an equal chance of defeating all enemies in the game equally unless they are intended to require multiple players. Again, the developers seem to be intentionally misleading players who haven't played the game yet.

Next, you have the 'sandbox' element. True enough, you can go anywhere and do anything. Except that there isn't really anything to do. Your motivation? Gain levels. Collect stuff. Kleptomaniacs would love this but in this day and age MMOs have learned put enjoyable narratives alongside sandboxes and RePop doesn't do this. All missions are generic and there is no 'plot' which pulls you into this fictional world they claim to have crafted. It feels as if what made SWG enjoyable was its franchise and universe. RePop unfortunately lacks character and has a look and feel that is rather generic which contributes to its faults.

It actually kind of reminds me of Tabula Rasa in many ways... and that game didn't last long either.

Early development means there is room for change, but you would need to gut the game entirely and start over to get away from these failings and that isn't going to happen. I actually regret donating now, so save your cash until post-launch and see how popular the Repopulation is after a couple months.
