I'm an old Ultima Online player and I was hoping this to be the next of the amazing gameplay that Ultima Online offered, but no I was wrong and I know that for sure because I have installed and played Ultima Online just to make sure and the game still is good and how it was before so I was very disappointed to say that I believe this game to be bad.

First it was a kickstarter, then somehow their engine GOT ROBBED??? like WTF they lost their engine, how someone can be so irresponsible about their contracts and people they work with??? like I'm from Brazil and here we have much more professionalism than what was shown by the developers of this game.

Now they will make a game that is like completely unrelated, It will be a FPS. Like wheres the RPG, wheres the building and fun stuff. In the Repopulation Game they made like tons of crafting ranks like who the **** would even bother to search for something so difficult to access. As the people of this planet evolve the gameplay must evolve as well.

We do not want a hard system, in fact we want easy systems that can cooperate with full gameplay time and half or quarter or weekly gameplay, like we want an afk gathering resource system (like EVE"/"RF ONLINE" has). Also in Ultima Online we could always relay to UO Assist

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tried to love this game but it's clearly not ready at the moment and really should not be a paid early access. I may change my mind once it releases but currently, no, it's not a worthwhile purchase unless you specifically want to support the project. I wish Steam gave the option of a caveat and not just a yes/no choice in this matter as while i cannot recommend the game in it's current state, it is still something quite unique in the current mmo genre and is to be commended for trying to do something old school and not follow the usual mmo cookie-cutter path.

The main problem is this game relies on an active community of players to drive the economy and the social aspects of the game, currently the population on EU is around 20-30 players at peak times which renders the ecnonomy sterile and the world more so.

Their biggest problem and the main reason for this is there will be a server wipe pre-launch, so anyone who owns the game is staying away as there is no point in playing or progressing as it'll be wiped. This is cyclical as you can imagine. No players, no economy, no social aspects to a player economy driven social centric mmo.

Additionally the likenesses made to SWG should be taken with a pinch of salt. SWG without the Star Wars aspect loses a massive amount of it's draw. The crafting in TR is touted as deep, but it's not really the case, it's just unnecessarily complicated.

Players complain of lag and latency issues, which i also experienced although not as bad as some have claimed. My computer is high spec as well, It seems the issues are client side. Most likely poor optimisation but this is to be expected from an alpha really.

The combat is one of it's biggest flaws, i have hopes they will improve it pre-launch but right now it's pretty basic, glitchy and feels extremely dated and clunky. For a game that claims to emulate SWG it's mildly annoying that it's combat is inferior to a game that predates it by about 12 years.

With beta approaching i still have hopes the devs will step-up and fix the multitude of problems, but the real issue for me is its impossible to know how this game will be come release. If nothing changes, it might be a serious flop and thats a concern for anyone invested in games of this type.
voteText: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm sorry but, this honestly makes me wish more than ever that you could get a refund on  games.

I had high hopes, the game was released. A good time leap after that, I entered the game after purchase, and it was flawed immensely. It was as if development had no focus towards optimization at all, and the animations were choppy, insanely simplistic, the control layout sucked, the emotes were dry or stupid, the walking to foot movement speed ratio was off significantly, and the questing and interface interactions were sour. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not downvoting this because it's a bad game.  Whether you wish to find the following comment deniable or not, this game specifically caters to people who played SWG.  The learning curve is badly conveyed, unless you are familiar with SWG's mechanics.  Even GM's on the server will resent helping you should not understand what to do.  I was not a victim of this, but saw this kind of behavior twice attempting to learn the game myself.

As for someone who has never played SWG, I'm going to need something that I too am use to to help me approach the mechanics, and learning curve necessary to push forward.  I'm not asking for a theme-park;  but something needs to be in place to help guide players on what they should be doing after the tutorial, during the tutorial.

The mail system for missions seems place-holder, and the animations are clunky.  Yes, yes -- I know it's Early Access.  But it's been known that most people who opt. in to EA generally will never see it finished, or still feel incomplete when it has its initial release.

So then why am I stating it's not a bad game?..  Well because it has potential.  There's a lot of growing room here, and I hope that players of both SWG's and not can balance out what they both want for the Repopulation.

I'll update this review once the game releases a few more builds and see where it's going.

Totally regret dumping my money on this :/

Well, this all is a bit very optimistic vision. In reality a lots of basic interface functions doesn't work. If you jump on the wall you stuck..if you jump on the tree you stuck...you can stuck everywhere... The trees mesh cooliders are simple boxes instead of complicated meshes what means that you can't walk next to tree... This indicates how simplistic this project is...
Objects disappear randomly...example...I attached harvester to mining node I walk few steppes away then I came back and... node wasn't even visible...(btw it didnt despawned) the object coolider was still there, my harvester still worked but becasue I couldn't click on the object I couldn't take my ore.... node object itself was not visible...only reloging fixed it...but its quite annoying have to relog every time when you coming to mining node(big one for harvesters) and want to use it....

Besides... anyone who played ANY other professional MMOPRG will noticed very fast that game really looks not very good... it looks cheap....and rough.... like kind of game anyone can make in Unity engine with few cheap/free props...

After conversation with NPC your camera movement using right mouse button stops working.... Normally in any mmorpg people use "W" to move forward and they just choose direction by using right mouse button and changing camera direction... here after conversation with NPC it stops working and you have to click ESC or use left mouse button for a while....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really wanted to like this game, I have been following its progress for a few years, I like Sci-Fi, MMO's and sandbox games so this really should be a hit with me.

Game: The graphics, animations and game play are bad. I understand this is early access and the final Alpha testing phase but that does not account for how bad the core game looks and feels. There are bugs, which is understandable, these can be ironed out and fixed through the Alpha and beta. The mob AI and pathing is very weak but I believe I did see a post from the dev's saying this is one thing to be updated later. The graphics and game play however, I think the game needs to go back to square one with a new engine and artists (Trying not to be rude to the artists, but they really should look into something called colour! Large portions of  grass, mountains, buildings are black, which is also the primary colour for players and most mobs. Seriously it hurts my eyes at times.) The performance seems rather poor, given there are very few NPC's and players. I expect spikes, crashes and disconnects but being stood still with players/mobs jerking past in the open is not what I would expect, nothing seems to flow smoothly.

Crafting: Very complicated, too complicated for an average gamer I imagine. Personally I don't mind this, I think it can help the community stronger, force players and nations to work more closely.  It is very confusing and I would hope to see more detailed tutorials played out in the beta's. Where crafting falls down is that you obviously need to gather materials before you can craft; Gathering is boring, looting the same flower three or four times, killing mobs in mind numbing combat, running around an ugly world. I struggle to find a reason to explore when everything looks so bad right now.

Sandbox: My sandbox experience was rather disappointing. The first training zone seemed a small instanced area and then loaded into a new city area. A quest in this city sends you to visit an apartment/tower block, which was also instanced! A building in the main city is instanced, even though it seemed to lead to one room with one NPC? Then there were quests to go to another zone and housing area which are also seemed to be separate instances/areas.

Conclusion:
For modern day gamers and MMO fans, I would advise avoid this game, certainly for this phase. I think the game requires a large investment of resources to make the graphics and game play enjoyable.  I believe The Re-population, as things stand, will have a small niche market of retro ex Star Wars galaxies fans who really don't mind playing something without the graphics and game play we have come to expect from games in the last 10 to 15 years.

Personally I will check back in a few months to see how the artists have changed the textures, colours, animations and how smooth the game runs; hopefully I will come back and find the game has ported over to the CryEngine  then Im sure I will be happy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early access or not, I had the feeling of traveling 15-20 years in the past.

I'm okay with the graphic being outdated like some other says but nothing in this game is fluid, clear or easy to use.

The HUD is painfull most of the time, missions are really cryptic and there is nothing to help you find where is that specific NPC beside a tracking skill that basically show you a list of NPC that are already visible on your map.

Crafting seemed interesting at first but I soon realized that I would have to waste so much material to figure out what is good and what isn't that it just demotivated me to even try to go further.

The music stutters most of the time and the game don't seem to handle multiple cores.

I would rather play Anarchy online.
At least I would know why the game feels so oldschool.
I now regret spending 40$ on this.

I may revisit this later but I don't expect much changes as most of this seem to be as designed or is part of how the engine works.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Revised my review with a bit more detail.

Purchased after reading the description, seeing a few videos and thought i might give it a go. It is too early to tell given the state of the current game. Keeping in mind that Steam doesn't offer refunds, the price of entry into the Early Access build and the general state of the game right now, my recommendation is NO.

After 10 hours of playing this game i can not recommend this game in its current state. Knowing that it is in alpha you expect problems, bugs or things that just dont work. Well a lot of things don't work and it makes it very difficult to enjoy the alpha build.

The main draw of this game is going to be the extensive crafting system which will requires lots of time and resources to get to. Not going in to that in 10 hours of exploration/experimentation.

GAMEPLAY ISSUES
- Graphics: It's like we went back in time to 2004. The graphics are dated, the textures are muddy, it looks quite horrible. I don't think I can stand much more than 1-2 hour sessions at a time. Frame rates dip drastically between zones when i assume loads new assets into the game, but then the client stutters and freezes and continues to do so until you quit the application and restart.
- Crafting requires lots of experimentation, which also means that you have to spend hours gathering material or killing things. Not seeing much fun in either ventures in the current build. Some people love this sort of thing but I don't see the point in spending so much time to build a basic weapon early on. Sucks all the fun out of the game for casual crafters.
- Background Music: I turned it off. It was quite annoying.
- Controls / UI: Clunky. Half of the time all the buttons stop animating so you have to reset the game to resolve UI glitches. WASD makes the character move, but the camera leaves little to be desired. When walking into rooms with low ceilings i tend to clip the floors or have to zoom into first person to see anything. I play the game at isometric aerial view because it gives me better spatial awareness. Playing over the shoulder or in first person gives me headaches.
- Poor navigation / pathfinding: The game needs better cartographic elements. Symbology is also rubbish. The mini map also do not reflect the landmarks on the ground so it's a constant struggle to find important NPCs and places of interest. Developer needs to take cartographic lessons and map making classes. You're expected to use your tracking skill to locate certain NPCs, man i could not be bothered after an hour or so running around the city spamming that tracking button.
- Frustrating learning curve because of cryptic tutorials / quest information. Job offered to player: Go to A and pick up package to delivery to B. No information as to where A or B is. Up to you to track down A and figure out where B is. Reward is not worth the effort.
- No audio feedback: Fire a weapon, no audio. Monster attacks you, no audio.
- Questing system is a chore, and you struggle to do basic fetch, delivery and kill quests because of insufficient information. These are staple game mechanics in sandbox MMOGs and it struggles to even deliver basic missions.
- Looting needs to be quicker. Right now it takes up to 5 seconds to begin the looting process, then a window takes over the screen. If you cross into the path of another beast, you begin your attack rotation but then the loot screen from your previous action blocks your view. You die.
- Extracting process needs to be quicker/efficient. Took me a long time to figure out what enhance corpse" and "enrich nodes" meant. It is more of a hassle in hostile zones too because you're taking around 30 seconds between corpses trying to improve the grade of the corpse
date: and then you cross the path of a hostile  roaming player / monster
recommended: and you die.\n- On the advice of many people playing the alpha
hoursPlayed:
I skipped the crafting and focused only on combat jobs and killing things. There are other job offers that are sent to your mailbox but I lost all motivation to do them because of the struggles with finding NPCs and places of interest.

COMBAT
- Roleplayed a sniper. Take a rifle out in to the woods. Interesting that the damage varies depending on distance between you and the target. Problem arise when monster agro circle is larger than the optimal range of my weapon. So you run into the monster's range

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not worth 40 dollars if you are looking for a playable game.  This is a very very early alpha draft and is a good start, but paying for such an early draft is not worth 40 dollars. I feel as if I paid to help fund a friends programming project.

This game is no where close to the playable level the in game pics imply.  I would wait for a couple of years and then try the game if you want to really want to evaluate a alpha closer to beta version.

Alpha testing to help develop a project is fun and rewarding.  I have done it for many games.  You should not have to pay for such an early draft.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BUYERS REMORSE:

As a long time hardcore player of SWG I was excited by the hype and anticipation for this game and have followed its development since 2012.  When I saw early access on steam I opened my wallet and decided to give it a go... it took me a single session of frustration to realize what a mistake I had made and what a lie the advertising has been.

Where to start... well first thing you will notice is character creation.  Simply put, it is awful.  It is one of those systems that is intended to make the player feel like you have unlimited customization but in the end still cannot produce the result you want.  The player is given lots of meaningless options but even then it is frustrating to control (more on this later) as it is one of those" character creators where adjusting one slider pushes three others.  Character design is ultimately unappealing so you better like wearing your helmet.  The entire character creator (and the character models for that matter) needs to be rebuilt from the ground up IMO.

My next and probably largest complaint is with the controls and interface.  Much like character creation
date: we are given the illusion of lots of choice
recommended: but none of the choices we want or need.  I found myself wrestling with the controls constantly... not a good sign and it really takes away from getting into the game.  Remember the smooth
hoursPlayed: user friendly controls and interface from SWG that felt good to the touch and allowed you to become easily immersed in the world?  Apparently this design team does not.  Being able to ALT between mouse mode and third person would be a huge step in the right direction
voteText: but merely scratching the surface of what requires a complete overhaul.\n\nGraphics:  Well
helpfulPercent: in fairness one should not expect too sophisticated of graphics from any MMORPG if you want complexity in the world while maintaining playability.  But some of the design choices here are just.... baffling.  The aspect ratios and fonts are such that I was suffering eyestrain and a headache after a mere 2 hours of play.  On top of that
votesHelpful: the world is drab and lifeless aesthetically.  All browns and greys.  Lots of darkness.  It simply does not LOOK interesting.  Already mentioned that the characters look like garbage.  I do not kid that in addition to the physical discomfort I felt a bit depressed after playing for a couple hours from looking at such an uninspired landscape and world.\n\nThe game world is horribly scaled
votesTotal: a trend I see shared with more and more MMOs of recent times.  By this I mean
votesFunny: every structure you enter is enormous and out of proportion... large vacant spaces with colossal head space and lots of meaningless filler.  Remember in SWG
commentsCount: you would enter a structure and the proportions made sense?  The rooms were filled with items in what appeared a logical and meaningful way?  When you walked the streets of say
column16: Coronet
column17: nearly all of the buildings had some function and the scale of it all made sense?  This new style of MMO world gives us big
column18: vacuous structures meant to provide the illusion of vastness.  It asks you to walk 3 minutes from one drab structure which is identical to the next in order
column19: save for some stupid billboard outside.\n\nTo further compound the frustration of the experience
column20: I could still feel the "rails" beneath it all.  This game is by no means a true sandbox in any sense.  It may have some sandbox-like qualities
column21: but to compare it to SWG is an insult.  I was getting more of a "Star Trek Online" and "Old Republic Online" vibe from this game.  If you are a fan of those games but prefer a drab
column22: lifeless
column23: brandless sci-fi setting
column24: then this may be the game for you.\n\nIf you came looking for the next SWG...... "move along"."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is so terrible on so many levels I dont know where to start. reviewText:
Early Access Review

DING DONG THE GAME IS DEAD!
WHICH DUMB GAME?
THE REPOP GAME!
DING DONG THE STUPID GAME IS DEAD!




Everyone keeps comparing this game to SWG when, in fact, there is no comparison.  The skill system is straight out of every Elder Scrolls game, resource mining is straight out of every WoW clone and it honestly doesn't have anything in common with SWG other than being a science fiction game.

Even for an alpha this feels unpolished.  Worse, it feels empty.  Under the graphics (which are nice) there is just a repetition of the same standardized MMO systems that we've already seen a hundred times before.  Much has been lauded about the complex crafting system, but that can't make up for the fact that this is not a sandbox game by any sense of the genre.  It is, rather, a traditional theme-park game that just hasn't had the rides installed yet.

Also, lead developer J.C.Smith is rather touchy about making sure that everyone thinks this game is the spiritual heir" to SWG
date: because he's banking heavily on old SWG players buying his product.  To that end he will happily delete & ban people simply for mentioning that http://www.swgemu.com even exists
recommended: lest his desired customers find out about and go play the real thing instead.  That attitude of placing greed above all else is about as unprofessional as it gets
hoursPlayed: and is a terrible way to dump on people who've already paid for the product.  Likewise I am sure that
voteText: after reading this
helpfulPercent: he will go petition Steam themselves to delete this very review for those same reasons.\n\nThe bugs I can forgive
votesHelpful: for such is expected in alpha releases
votesTotal: but the flagrant marketing deception
votesFunny: the lack of true innovation and the terrible attitute by the staff are enough to earn it a well-deserved thumbs down even if the game was already fully finished.\n\nDon't make the same mistake I did - give this one a pass and keep looking elsewhere.  I can think of a good place to start

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know this game is in Alpha, and they have many disclaimers posted all over the game and on Steam stating the game is in Alpha. We are told to expect bugs and an overall unfinished product. This game will be a free to play business model whenever it finally 'releases'. As such, I don't know what possessed me to plop $40 of my hard earned money on this game, and I sincerely wish I could get a refund.

First, before the Fanboys start the flaming, let me say I am a hardcore SWG fan and played the game from initial release until the end, and let me say this game does a good job at recreating the general feel of SWG right down to the UI. But something is lacking.

I find it ireprehensible that this game is in such a horrid state of development after the amount of money people have pourd into it and the amount of time the game has been in development. The development of this game began in 2008...yes, almost seven years ago. It's 2015 now and we are no closer to release then we were in 2010 when they switched engines for this game.

The problems of this game start in character creation. with the general premise of the game, I understand there is only one race, humans. Thats fine. The issue is in the general lack of options. The control scheme in creation isnt very intuitive, and your face always looks the same. The only real way to change the general look is to make your character fat or skinny and slap facial hair on them. Even after that they still look like shiny claymation characters.

Then you get in the gameworld and get to stumble through the shoddy tutorial. SWG honestly had better graphics and ran jus as choppy. and how old is SWG. Also, when you get in game you realize the terrain is horrendous, the rocks and stones look like cardboard and the grass looks like pipecleaners. The town's feel vacant. Most NPC's don't serve a purpose or show any signs of AI. When you get into combat, the laser effects are downright cheap and goofy.

The premise for this game is great, the vision is epic and the spirit of SWG is there, but after close to seven years of development and a lot of consumer investment, I expect better than this rough shod heap. If you are thinking about paying $40 for an Alpha, remember it's an alpha...seriously. And there are no signs after playing it there will be a release any time soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Going to have to give this a thumbs down in it's current state.
I will revisit the game in several months and see if it merits a change to this review.

The game has overly complex, poorly implemented, and poorly defined game mechanics.
Entry barriers, to do anything other than shoot stuff, are very high.

The crafting system is very complex, overly so, and relies on an in game database that is hard to navigate and only vaguely describes the processes required.

Combat is very weak, especially melee, and the mob ranking system is convoluted.
(sometimes a mob is easy to kill and sometimes the same mob will kill you in one hit because you forgot to take time to mouse over every mob and decipher the bizarro rank system)

2/3rds of the maps are PvP, only 1/3rd of the game maps are available to players that do not
wish to PvP.

The mapping system is both weird and broken, needless arrows constantly popping up, can't find mission goals some of the time. The minimap is completely useless and I covered it with the shift-m map (because the regular M map is totally trash no one uses it).

The housing system is not easy to use and provides nothing in the way of storage, it has no benefit except to set up a player store and that store can only be used if players stumble across it or you have sent them a waypoint to find it.

Progression is based on repeatedly using a skill and will require many, many, hours to gain ground. (casuals will not progress much)

Every activity is super grindy, you will have to spend dozens of hours searching and gathering before you can make even simple items.

The mission system is the same, repeat, repeat, repeat, with most missions just running back and forth for very little reward.

The game will cater only to the hardcore that can spend many, many, hours in game.
If you have no life, no job, no family, this game will help to fill that emptiness.

The UI is poorly implemented, windows are not locked to screen edges, text overlaps and overruns windws and text on the mission review is so small it is nearly impossible to read.

It's graphically at least a half dozen years out of date, characters are truly ugly and the maps are quite dull and colorless (with the exception of dull green/brown.)
Character animations are absolutely awful, very amateur.

Zone lines are the worst I have ever seen in an MMO, textures do not match and it is a horrific stutterfest of 2 FPS crossing them.
(oh what fun to stutter across a zone line only to be insta killed by a plant...)

Runs on the Hero engine...

I understand this is an alpha" but as it sits this game has too many weaknesses and a super grind style gameplay that will only appeal to a small number of people.


Do I regret spending $15 on this game ?

No.

Would I buy it given what I know now ?

No."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Regret!

I tried playing this game over a few play sessions.  I've been missing SWG for some time.  At first I thought it was great, it feels a lot like SWG, interface looks very much like it and the combat feels like it too.  But the more I played the more frustrated I became.  To me the game feels like it has not depth just circular complexity.   The crafting system is in depth in a way but where  SWG's made sense this one seems to invent complexity and compounds it with no real beneficial outcome.  There is no real logical reason for the way they've developed the crafting and it got on my nerves.  No one can be a crafter unto themselves but it just felt like every profession needed 10 different other professions to make the simplist of components so you could make an item finally.  I regret buying this.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you don't like crafting constantly don't play it. If you don't like unnecessarily complicated crafting, don't play it. If you don't like spending the majority of your in-game time harvesting resources of unnecessarily largley varying quality"
date: don't play it.\nLet's also dispel the myth that this is SWG reborn. Nonsense. I played SWG for years and this game does not even come close. In some ways it is similar

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Repopulation is one of those early access titles I spent a loooong time following, and am very sad to finally experience.

The idea of the game has me drooling; a basebuilding sandbox MMO designed after my favorite games (Ultima Online and Star Wars Galaxy). Potential for intrigue and politics; an actual death mechanic! Loss of items! WOW. Finally! A game to replace my glory days in Ultima Online battling reds in the Britain graveyard.

However, the execution of the game leaves much to be desired, and it's quite clear to me now that the developers are making a game without designing it from the ground up to be what they are advertising it as, in order to draw that same tired demographic out.

Concerns:

- The animations for movement feel unnatural; there is no transition from moving to not moving, so your character almost seems sp.astic (sp.astic is filtered? Weird) in the way they move.

- First person is not actually first person. You're off to the side of your head, and if you look down, you see your entire character. It's very, very weird. Not sure if this was intended or not? Maybe it's just me.

- The UI needs a redesign, or some significant tweaks. Nothing is intuitive. Everything is dull, drab, and feels very much like older versions of an operating system; functional, but by comparison to modern aesthetics, not very pleasing.

- The entire reason I bought the game was based on the fact that it was being advertised as a replacement for old hardcore MMOs like UO/SWG; however, the hardcore ruleset doesn't even appear to exist yet. The game's community from my brief foray into it feels like it is being dragged in the complete opposite than the advertised direction, with constant concern about PvE and player safety, and consensual pvp
date: etc. This feeling is validated by the fact that the game doesn't even appear to have a hardcore ruleset yet, and that hardcore" appears to be altered version of the "normal" ruleset that the game is TRULY designed for (why else would you design a game from the ground up without one of it's core features?). I am really incredulous that the developers are choosing to advertise a game as being inspired by one of the most brutal experiences in MMO history (Ultima Online) and yet it appears to be designed from the ground up for PvE players
recommended: with PvP AGAIN as an after thought.\n\nNot only is it an afterthought
hoursPlayed: the hardcore ruleset is not even a core feature:\n\n"Most of the major features are already in game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Potential is a poor justification, and an even poorer measure. You need to review what is present, and not what it may, or in fact may not become. This is a sandbox game that isn't quite delivering on the promise of open world freedom. The reality is that beneath the veneer of choice. Is a virtual lack thereof. In a lot of ways it is the worst of two worlds. Either the game demands an obscene amount of interdependency to get anything done, or its so simplistic a cave man can do it. If you will pardon the pun.

I am torn as to whether the combat is laughable or awful. The game supports two combat styles first person mode, or the standard hot button mode. The problem with the first is that while it makes it easier to navigate it makes combat pretty easy as it make decissions for you. The problem with the second is while it is somewhat more challenging it is also more of a pain to use to navigate. Not that it matters either way virtually no strategy or movement is required. Either you are going to dominate or you are going to die.

The loot system is perhaps the worst I have ever seen, and it has nothing to do with the odds involved with random rolls. This game makes use of a slot machine that can take between thirty or forty seconds to finish its roll. Just to give you a random loot that probably wont apply. In other words you will not only have to wait for loot, but it wont even be close to being something you might be able to use.  What you end up doing is spinning for quality of you know not what, at least if you knew. Then you could decide in advance to abandon the roll, and abandon the corpse.

The reason for this awful loot system is the horribly convoluted crafting system. That is predicated on a slavish devotion to a perverse notion of interdependency. Crafters are relegated to nothing more then cogs in a machine. Everyone can craft, but nobody can make something on their own. There are at least half a dozen harvesting lines in the game, and it is a foregone conlusion that if a schematic requires three ingredients that all three ingredients will require different kinds of harvesting, and at least one, and possibly two will require an intermediate refining before they can be used, and all of that is the case if you are lucky. You might be unlucky, and one of the ingredients might be a crafted component that has to be purchased from another player, and well if one isn't up for sale wow it really sucks to be you.

Worse still for the crafter, and the resultant buyer the quality of ingredients matters, and they are the product of random rolls. So as it stands the real question should be why have the crafting system at all. Is the crafter supposed to wait for an accomplished harvester to get a few good rolls, and what of the other crafter, and what if their rolls don't pan out. It is a recipe for conniption fits if I saw one.

Beyond all of that however. The user interfase is pretty abysmal. I mean basic functionality isn't even there.  I hope that is temp music we are hearing, and that they intend for it to be instance appropriate, and the graphics are pretty bad in a lot of ways. It is one thing for the world to be muddy, but the animals are too, and seeing as how everything is hostile it is a pretty big problem.

Potential or not there are some pretty bad design philosophies present in this build, and while I would love to play a real successor to star wars galaxies. Which is what this developer is going after. What made that game fun wasn't so much its complexities as much as it was the sense of freedom, and this game doesn't seem to be promoting freedom of choice. It is forcing crafters to network, boring combat players with idiotic looting systems, and the combat isn't very involved. It could get better, but then again it could get worse, and I am concerned it will be the latter.

It is a sad fact of life that a number of sandbox players just don't have any life to speak of, and they often operate under the delusion that theirs is a common playstyle. A lot of the testers don't appear to be making allowances for this, and are likely to encourage the developer to keep the system as is, because it favors their style of play while punishing the player that has a life outside of the game.

I can't really recommend this game at this time. There is a lot of mindless grinding, but not much else to recommend it. It  is so hard in some regards, and so terribly easy in others. That it is a hard place to have much fun. You shouldn't pay much attention to the positive reviews. Most of them are coming from ex star wars galaxies players who are going on a decade thirsty for a proper title in the genre. It is to be expected that they would be far more forgiving, and frankly far easier to give themselves over to self delusion.

That all said there is hope in the developer. As they seem to be very responsive, and they seem to be very attentive. It is usually a good sign when the developers are listening closely.  Which is why I intend to revisit the game periodically to see if it is improving. If it manages to do that I will probably amend this review.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'm getting really tired of companies putting unfinished products out there and then asking for more money to fix all the problems that they couldn't be bothered to fix before they sold us this crap. This game sounded interesting, then I bought it. Most of the quests don't give clear directions as to where you need to go, and the ones that seem simple enough end up not working right. I had two quests to kill vultures but the descriptions didn't give clear directions as to where these vultures were at. I found plenty of vultures around the starting area, killed about 50, and none of them counted for either quest. Got a quest to escort a lady to a camp down the road and she just stood there. There was no indication in the quest log saying there was a command that need to be given to get her to move either. Picked up the animal taming skill and tamed a wierd mutant dog. It kept getting injured and I was seeing a notification that it need to be healed but I wasn't told how or where. Then there's the crafting. I love crafting in any game but it seems like the developers just tried purposely to make the crafting in this game so hard that you'd give up on it. It takes forever to get the materials for crafting, the skills go up slowly, and half of the things you need for crafting you can't find the recipes for and the npc's in the game are no help. It's just confusing. You need 10 different components just to make a crappy low level piece of armor. After just a few hours of playing this game I gave up and had to write this stupid review, and I hate writing reviews. So thanks for that The Repopulation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm basing this review on other Beta testing that I have participated with over the years including City of Heroes, Red Orchestra 2, Eve, Defiance, 7-Days to Die and a whole slue of other non memorable and indie games.

I really really really want to LIKE this game but after 17+ hours of Beta testing I would NOT recommend wasting your money on the Early Access or the company's supportive memberships.

THAT IS UNLESS:

1) You don't mind waiting a few more years for a working version (if they do get a working version) because this game is a LONG way off from being completed as a finished product. Compared to other Beta games that I've played... there is no comparison. IMO The Repopulation's Early Access Beta is still in Alpha testing.

2) You have tones of gaming time to waist on developing a robust character that has no place in the simplistic and redundant world the game takes place in. They went way too heavy on developing an extremely complicated, confusing and complex character build, recipe and crafting system that takes HOURS to understand and absolutely no effort, imagination or originality on developing the game world, enemies or NCPs that the characters are suppose to interact with. This is an extremely unbalanced game.

3) You like frustration and enjoying long and arduous wild goose" missions that have very little reward. In the 17+ hours I spent Beta testing I was only able to complete 4 missions. My first mission "pick 5 lilacs" took over 2 hours to complete because there is absolutely no hints or help on where the missions objectives or resources were. The map is so scares in resources that it was pure luck that I stumbled upon the lilacs only after searching the entire map and dying 2 dozen times only to have to start over at "point A" each time. After searching 3 map zones and spending over 5 hours I still have yet to find the "Rhydanian trees" for my 4th mission.

#gameFAIL"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game should be called Craftasticle. The SImplest recipes in game arent worth the manhours required to craft them. BLABLABLA you're supposed to buy from AH for ingredients used by a different crafting skill, this promotes an in game economy. There is zero reason why i should spend the same amount of hours crafting the shitiest item in this game compared to other games where the best items take less time to craft.

In the future this games economy will be ruined by botters due to its lack of a skill cap as well as the impossible amount of manhours need to craft.

Other than that the game would be great, but as it stands without any incentive for players to actually progress in content, such as equipment upgrades or weapon upgrades, none of which that are better than what you start with can be purchased. The games grind wall for crafting shouldnt hit you at the door it should build up at the least to hook players into the game.

-Enjoy as you spend hours reading wikis and external websites trying to figure out how to craft pretty much anything.

-Have a great time wandering around as you struggle to make sense of the map.

-Hurt your eyes trying to read NPC text as your camera jerks around.

-Bask in the magnificant cutting edge graphics from 2004.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright now that i have got the game working ive played it for a fair bit and ive come to find it enjoyable even for an early access game.
for starters this game is a sci fi sort of open world based multiplayer game.
I like the fact that you can enjoy this gaming experience with countless of other players
It has outstanding graphics that apeal well toward the eye and its many handful of different biomes to explore.
Its good that its a sci fi buyt you dont come across any games like this one because not only sci fi it is an open nworld based game which can be very rare for a sci fi genre game.
The crafting system is complicated and hard, to some people that may be bad but i like it! Because after a while you will get the hang of it and takes some of your time to master it.
I like its creativity for combat and armor and weapon choice and the ability to pvp with other players in certain areas.
I would reccomand this game highly for people who enjoy sci fi, open world exploration,muiltiplayer and combat.
I enjoyed this game very much and look forward to future updates.

Oh and dont forget the great sandbox system that allows to to build your own home/base.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I never quite recovered from Star Wars Galaxies' demise. No game offered as much freedom, depth and complexity as that game in its heyday. This game is the true spiritual successor to that game but adds plenty of modern mechanics like the action mode. The game is still in alpha, but is much more playable than Day-Z and H1Z1. If you want a complex RPG with no hand-holding and an open sandbox, the Repopulation is for you.


2/20/2016 update.


All of that was true until the devs suspended development becuase of financial issues with the Hero Engine. The game will now have to be rebuilt from the ground up with Unreal Engine 4. I won't ask you to save your money since you can't even buy the game right now. Perhaps in 2019 the game will be playable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a lot of potential, good developer and GM interaction, and a great community! If you want to support a growing game please buy this. Be warned though, this game is rough around the edges and has some FPS issues and the questing system isn't 100% there.

I think it's already a lot of fun and I'm ready to plunge in and get more playing time when I can!

Edited on Jan 22: 2016 - The game is dead now, I bought in to the hype and yet another early access game died. I don't buy the engine excuse for a second. This is why it is so hard to support early access games - I wasted my $60.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So after being a leader of two of the largest and greatest nations in the game (first Raiders of Muspelheim and secondly Tanstaafl Alliance) I really do have to give it a thumbs down.  I understand there were a lot of issues with Hero Engine but, really no one should have been left in the dark for so long.  I poured my heart and soul into this game and sometimes put up with more than I should have just because of blind faith.  There were nights where it took me 5 or 6 attempts to log in without crashing, then to travel and crash and restart that cycle of log in, crash, log in, crash, log in, crash, log in, load world, crash. Disapearing items, broken combat, broken crafting, and tormentingly complex systems for crafting all kinda wore me out and made me quit.  I only stayed around for my nation.

After a while though as population on the servers died and became barren there was no more reason to stay around.  Everyone left due to engine issues, again I don't blame Repop for this.

Now with the game practically dead they have announced that they're releasing a new game on the unreal engine... which seems pretty sweet!  It seems like it may actually be a winner... but, will it be free to those who bought Repopulation?  Or are we getting more hands in our wallets?  I feel bad for the people who put money into buying the higher level packages... I only bought three copies of this game.

Only time will tell but, currently Repop is dead to me.
